BASALT MUNICIPAL CODE 
1991 
A Codification of the General Ordinances 
  
of the Town of Basalt, Colorado 
  
A Home Rule Municipality 

PREFACE 
The Town of Basalt, a statutory town, has published its Municipal Code in a format which features the following: 
The Table of Contents is the table containing each chapter and article title, with reference to page location. Preceding each chapter is a chapter table of contents, also identifying each article by the subject name provided. 
The two-place section numbering system places the chapter number first, followed by a hyphen and section number. This two-place system is simplified by the elimination of article numbering. Each section may be cited by the chapter and section numbers which, together with reserved section numbers, are in sequence within each chapter. 
The open chapter and page numbering system creates reserved chapter and page numbers for expansion or revision of the code without undue complication when changes are made to the code by supplementation. 
The Disposition of Ordinances Table identifies the source for the contents of the code. This table provides ordinance numbers in chronological order and location by section number for the present code contents. Thus, if there is interest in determining whether an ordinance, or a portion thereof, is contained within the code, the Disposition of Ordinances Table will provide that information. The Table of Up-to-Date Pages lists all of the current pages through the most recent supplementation. 
The Index provides references by common and legal terminology to the appropriate code sections. Cross references are provided with the Index when appropriate. 
Supplements to the code provide regular updating of the code to maintain it as a current compilation of all the legislation which has general and continuing effect. Without regular supplementation, the code would soon lose its usefulness as a complete source of the general law of the municipality. Supplementation is accomplished by the periodic publication of additions and amendments to the code. 
TOWN OF BASALT, COLORADO 
ORDINANCE NO. 22 
SERIES OF 1991 
    AN ORDINANCE OF THE TOWN OF BASALT, ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE TOWN OF BASALT; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
    Be It Ordained by the Board of Trustees of the Town of Basalt, Colorado: 
    Section 1. The code entitled Municipal Code of the Town of Basalt published by Colorado Code Publishing Company, consisting of Chapters 1 through 18, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before December 30, 1991, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal established in the foregoing section shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that had been previously repealed by any ordinance which is repealed by this Ordinance. 
    Section 4. The following codes were adopted by reference and incorporated in the Municipal Code of the Town of Basalt. One (1) copy is on file in the Town Clerk's office: 
(1)  The Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities , 1977 edition, published by the State Department of Highways, as adopted and amended in Section 8-1 et seq ; 
(2)  The Uniform Fire Code , 1988 edition, published by the Western Fire Chiefs Association and International Conference of Building Officials, as adopted and amended in Section 18-61 et seq ; 
    Section 5. The following codes are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in the Municipal Code of the Town of Basalt. One (1) copy is on file in the Town Clerk's office: 
(1)  The Uniform Building Code , 1991 edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, as adopted and amended in Section 18-1 et seq ; 
(2)  The Uniform Building Code Standards , 1991 edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, as adopted and amended in Section 18-1 et seq ; 
(3)  The Uniform Mechanical Code , 1991 edition, published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, as adopted and amended in Section 18-1 et seq ; 
(4)  The Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings , 1991 edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, as adopted in Section 18-1; 
(5)  The Uniform Plumbing Code , 1991 edition, published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, as adopted and amended in Section 18-1 et seq ; 
(6)  The National Electrical Code , 1990 edition, published by the National Fire Protection Association, as adopted and amended in Section 18-1 et seq ; 
    Section 6. The penalties provided by the Municipal Code of the Town of Basalt are hereby adopted as follows: 
(1)  Sec. 1-82.   General penalty for violations. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person violating any provisions or failing to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of the ordinances of the Town shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person convicted of a misdemeanor under the ordinances of the Town shall be punished by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment except as hereinafter provided in Section 1-83. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of the ordinances of the Town is committed, continued or permitted by any such person, and he or she shall be punished accordingly. 
(2)  Sec. 1-83.   Application of penalties to juveniles and to convictions of lesser offense. 
Every person who, at the time of commission of the offense, was at least ten (10) but not yet eighteen (18) years of age, and who is subsequently convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to, a violation of any provision of this Chapter, shall be punished by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) per violation or count. Any voluntary plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the original charge or to a lesser or substituted charge shall subject the person so pleading to all fines and/or penalties applicable to the original charge. 
(3)  Sec. 6-10.   Delinquent charges. (Article I, Business Licenses) 
Any person failing to pay any license fee levied under this Article by January 31 shall thereafter be deemed delinquent and the license deemed expired. To renew the license, licensee shall be subject to a delinquent fee charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each month thereof during which said fee is delinquent, assessed on the first day of the month, in addition to any other penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this Code. 
(4)  Sec. 7-141.   Dangerous and potentially dangerous dogs. 
(c)  Any potentially dangerous dog as described in Section 7-131(24) that has caused no human injury or a domestic animal injury and has been found running at large may be impounded, and the owner shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense and one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the second offense. The third offense will result in a mandatory court appearance of the dog's owner. 
(5)  Sec. 7-149.   Penalties. (Article VII, Dogs) 
(a)  Any person convicted of violating any provisions of this Article, which violation does not result in bodily injury to any person, shall be punished for such offense by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by both such imprisonment and fine, plus the customary court costs as applicable. 
(b)  The following fines (penalty assessment), except those stated in Section 7-150, shall apply to any such violation and shall be applied either through the penalty assessment procedure of Section 16-2-201, C.R.S., or by the court after conviction, in which case the court shall also assess the appropriate court costs: 
(1)  First offense: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(2)  Second offense: One hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(3)  Third offense: Two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(4)  Fourth offense and any subsequent conviction: The court may impose a fine of up to the three hundred dollar ($300.00) maximum or imprisonment in the county jail for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, for each separate offense. 
(5)  Any violations of Sections 7-111 or 7-112 shall be subject to the following penalties, which shall be assessed at the discretion of the court within the limits set forth below: 
a.  First offense within any one (1) year period, fifteen dollars ($15.00) to fifty dollars ($50.00). 
b.  Second offense within any one (1) year period, thirty dollars ($30.00) to one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
c.  Third offense within any one (1) year period, sixty dollars ($60.00) to three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
d.  Fourth or subsequent offense, no less than one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a mandatory court appearance. 
(h)  Any violation of any provisions of this Article which results in bodily injury to any person or animal caused by a dog shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and imprisonment for three (3) months, or both, up to a maximum fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and imprisonment for twelve (12) months.

(8)  Sec. 8-6.   Violations and penalties. (Article I, Model Traffic Code) 
The following penalties, herewith set forth in full, shall apply to this Chapter: 
(1) It is unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions stated or adopted in this Chapter. 
(2) Except as provided in Section 8-2(11) of this Code, every person convicted of a violation of any provision stated or adopted in this Chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(9)  Sec. 13-24.   Inspections. 
Any authorized representative of the Water Department shall have the right to enter any property or building where water furnished by the Town is used, for the purpose of making an inspection of pipes, fixtures or appliances and for the further purpose of detecting and eliminating any alteration, connection to or disconnection from meters, wasting of water, improper or unauthorized use of water facility, installation of pipes or fixtures or other improper use of water. Property owners shall make access available during regular working hours to Water Department personnel within fifteen (15) days of notification. Failure to comply shall result in a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) per quarter being added to owner's water bill and shall allow the Town to charge for the estimated usage of water, both at each billing period.. 
(10)  Sec. 13-31.   Additional service or fixtures. 
(b) Any user, owner or occupant of a structure who installs or uses additional fixtures or plumbing services and does not report same shall be charged at double the ordinary rates for such fixtures or plumbing service for the period of time that such fixtures are in use and remain unreported, in addition to a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each violation, such amount to be added onto and collected with the water bill at each billing period. 
(11)  Sec. 16-268.   Penalty for violations. (Article XIII, Zoning Administration and Enforcement) 
Failure to comply with all of the provisions of the Chapter, unless a variance has been authorized by the Board of Zoning Adjustment, shall constitute a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisonment for a period of not more than thirty (30) days, or both. Each day that such a violation continues to exist shall be considered as a separate offense subject to penalty as specified herein. 
(12)  Sec. 18-3.   Violation and penalties. (Article I, Construction Code) 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this code shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this code is committed, continued or permitted, and upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punishable by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(13)  Sec. 18-5.   Amendments to the Electrical Code. 
(12) Violations and penalties. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert or demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure in the Town or cause or permit the same to be done contrary to or in violation of any or the provisions of this code. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this code shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this code is committed, continued or permitted, and, upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punishable by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(14)  Sec. 18-63.   Penalties for violations. (Article IV, Fire Prevention Code) 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of the Uniform Fire Code and amendments thereto or any other provisions of this Chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Upon conviction of each such violation such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any the provisions of the Uniform Fire Code and amendments thereto is committed, continued or permitted 
    Section 7. Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the Town to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 8. Ordinances adopted after December 30, 1991, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to those provisions of the Code. 
    Section 9. The Board of Trustees herewith finds, determines and declares that this Ordinance is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public health and safety in order to make this ordinance applicable to the Town at the earliest possible date so that administrative efficiency may be obtained therefrom and to assure that the purposes of this Ordinance are met. This Ordinance shall become effective thirty (30) days after publication thereof. 
    INTRODUCED this 11th day of December, 1991. 
      TOWN OF BASALT, COLORADO

CHAPTER 1 - General Provisions 
ARTICLE I - Code 

Sec. 1-1. - Adoption of Code. 
    The published code known as the Basalt Municipal Code , of which one (1) copy is now on file in the office of the Town Clerk and may be inspected during regular business hours, is enacted and adopted by reference as a primary code and incorporated herein as if set out at length. This primary code has been promulgated by the Town of Basalt, Colorado, as a codification of all the ordinances of the Town of Basalt, of a general and permanent nature through Ordinance No. 22, for the purpose of providing an up-to-date code of ordinances, properly organized and indexed, in published form for the use of the citizens and officers of the Town. 
(Prior code 1-6; Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-2. - Title and scope. 
    This Code constitutes a compilation, revision and codification of all the ordinances of the Town of Basalt, of a general and permanent nature, and shall be known as the Basalt Municipal Code . 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-3. - Purpose and construction. 
    The provisions of this Code and all proceedings under it shall be construed with a view toward effecting the objectives of this Code and promoting justice. 
(Prior code 1-4) 
Sec. 1-4. - Adoption of codes by reference. 
    Codes may be adopted by reference, as provided by state law. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-5. - Repeal of ordinances not contained in Code. 
    All ordinances and parts of ordinances of a general and permanent nature adopted by the Town Council, and in force on the date of the adoption of this Code and not contained in the Code, are hereby repealed as of the effective date of the adopting ordinance, except as hereinafter provided. 
(Prior code 1-9; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 1-6. - Matters not affected by repeal. 
    The repeal of ordinances and parts of ordinances of a permanent and general nature by Section 1-5 above shall not affect any offense committed or act done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract, right or obligation established prior to the time when said ordinances and parts of ordinances are repealed. 
(Prior code 1-10) 
Sec. 1-7. - Ordinances saved from repeal. 
    The continuance in effect of temporary and/or special ordinances and parts of ordinances, although omitted from this Code, shall not be affected by such omission therefrom, and the adoption of this Code shall not repeal or amend any such ordinance or parts or part of any such ordinance. Among the temporary and/or special ordinances not repealed or amended by the adoption of this Code are ordinances: 
(1)  Creating, opening, dedicating, vacating or closing specific streets, alleys or other public ways. 
(2)  Naming or changing the names of specific streets and other public ways. 
(3)  Establishing the grades of specific streets and other public ways. 
(4)  Establishing the grade or lines of specific sidewalks. 
(5)  Authorizing or relating to specific issuances of general obligation bonds. 
(6)  Creating specific sewer and paving districts and other local improvements districts. 
(7)  Authorizing the issuance of specific improvement district bonds. 
(8)  Making special assessments for local improvements and authorizing refunds from specific local improvement district and bond proceeds. 
(9)  Annexing territory to or excluding territory from the Town. 
(10)  Dedicating or accepting any specific plat or subdivision. 
(11)  Calling or providing for a specific election. 
(12)  Authorizing specific contracts for purchase of beneficial use of water by the Town. 
(13)  Approving or authorizing specific contracts with the State or with others. 
(14)  Authorizing a specific lease, sale or purchase of property. 
(15)  Granting rights-of-way or other rights and privileges to specific railroad companies and other public carriers. 
(16)  Granting a specific gas company or other public utility the right or privilege of constructing lines in the streets and alleys or of otherwise using the streets and alleys. 
(17)  Granting a franchise to a specific public utility company, or establishing rates for and otherwise regulating a specific public utility company. 
(18)  Appropriating money. 
(19)  Levying a temporary tax or fixing a temporary tax rate. 
(20)  Relating to salaries. 
(Prior code 1-11) 
Sec. 1-8. - Code supersedes prior ordinances. 
    This Code shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances and parts of ordinances passed by the Town Council prior to the enactment of this Code, except such ordinances as are expressly saved from repeal or continued in full force and effect, shall hereafter be set forth by reference. 
(Prior code 1-7; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 1-9. - Changes in previously adopted ordinances. 
    In compiling and preparing the ordinances of the Town for adoption and revision as part of the Code, certain grammatical changes and other minor changes were made in one (1) or more of said ordinances. It is the intention of the Town Council that all such changes be adopted as part of the Code as if the ordinances so changed had been previously formally amended to read as such. 
(Prior code 1-13; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 1-10. - When effective. 
    All provisions of this Code shall be in full force and effect on and after the effective date of this ordinance. 
(Prior code 1-8) 
Secs. 1-11-1-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Definitions and Usage 

Sec. 1-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in the ordinances of the Town of Basalt, and/or any codification of the same, shall be construed as defined in this Section, unless from the context a different meaning is intended or unless a different meaning is specifically defined and more particularly directed to the use of such words or phrases: 
    Charter means the Home Rule Charter of the Town of Basalt, Colorado, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
    Code means the Basalt Municipal Code. 
    Computation of time means the time within which an act is to be done. It shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day; and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
    County means the County of Eagle, Colorado, or the County of Pitkin, Colorado, as the case may require, recognizing that the Town is located in both counties herein mentioned. 
    C.R.S. means Colorado Revised Statutes. 
    Law denotes applicable federal law, the Constitution and statutes of the State of Colorado, the ordinances of the Town and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder. 
    May is permissive. 
    Month means a calendar month. 
    Must is mandatory; shall is mandatory. 
    Oath includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed. 
    Ordinance means a permanent law of the Town. Action required by the Charter to be in the form of an ordinance shall be taken only by ordinance. A temporary or special law, administrative action, order or directive, statement of policy or declaration of intent may be in the form of a resolution or motion. 
    Owner , as applied to land or a building, includes any part owner, joint owners, tenants in common or joint tenants of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person means natural person, a joint venture, joint-stock company, partnership, association, firm, club, company, corporation, business, trust or organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
    Personal property includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
    Preceding and following mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property includes real and personal property. 
    Real property includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    State means the State of Colorado. 
    Street includes streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs or other public ways in the Town which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and opened to public use, or such other public property so designated in any law of this State. 
    Tenant and occupant , applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Title, title of office, officer, office, board, etc. The use of the title of any officer, employee, department, board or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of the Town or his or her designated representative. 
    Town means the Town of Basalt, Colorado, and such territorial limits of the Town of Basalt, and such territory outside the Town over which the Town has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
    Town Council means the Town Council, consisting of one (1) Mayor and six (6) Councilors, of the Town of Basalt. All its members or all Council members means the total number on the Council entitled to vote in any particular circumstance upon any question, as provided by the general laws of the State of Colorado. 
    Written or in writing means any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year means a calendar year. 
(Prior code 1-1; Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 33, §§B1, B2(1), 2003) 
Sec. 1-32. - Usage of terms. 
    All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-33. - Interpretation and usage. 
    The following grammatical rules shall apply in the ordinances of the Town: 
(1)  Gender. The use of one (1) gender shall be interpreted to include any other gender unless the context clearly requires another interpretation. 
(2)  Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural, and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
(3)  Words used in the present tense include the past and future tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable. 
(Prior code 1-2) 
Secs. 1-34-1-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - General 

Sec. 1-51. - Titles and headings not part of ordinances. 
    Chapter and Article titles and headings, and titles of sections and other divisions of the Code, or in supplements made to the Code, are inserted for the convenience of users of the Code and are not a part of the ordinances. 
(Prior code 1-14) 
Sec. 1-52. - Authorized acts. 
(a)  Whenever a provision appears requiring an officer of the Town to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
(b)  The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; but if the time for an act to be done shall fall on Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, the act shall be done upon the next regular business day following such Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-53. - Prohibited acts. 
    Whenever in Town ordinances any act or omission is made unlawful, it includes causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering or concealing the fact of such act or omission. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-54. - Acts by agents, representatives. 
    When an act is required by an ordinance, the same being such that it may be done as well by an agent or representative as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed by any authorized agent or representative. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-55. - Repeal of ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of such ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-56. - Publication of ordinances. 
    All ordinances, as soon as may be after their passage, shall be recorded in a book kept for that purpose and authenticated by the signatures of the Mayor or Mayor Pro Tem and Town Clerk or Deputy Town Clerk. All ordinances shall be published in accordance with the requirements of the Charter. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 33 §B2(2), 2003) 
Sec. 1-57. - Severability of Code provisions. 
    If any sections, section, subsection or provision of this Code, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by any competent court, such invalidity shall not affect the other sections, subsections, provisions or applications of this Code if they can be given effect without the invalid sections, section, subsection, provision or application. 
(Prior code 1-21) 
Sec. 1-58. - Amendments to Code. 
    Ordinances and parts of ordinances of a permanent and general nature passed or adopted after the adoption of this Code may be passed or adopted either in the form of amendments to the Code adopted by this ordinance or without specific reference to said Code. But in either case, all such ordinances and parts of ordinances shall be deemed amendments to said Code, and all of the substantive, permanent and general parts of such ordinances and changes made thereby in the Code shall be inserted and made in the Code as provided in Section 1-62. 
(Prior code 1-18) 
Sec. 1-59. - Examination of Code. 
    The Mayor and Town Clerk shall carefully examine at least one (1) copy of the Code adopted by this ordinance to see that it is a true and correct copy of the Code. Similarly, after each supplement has been prepared, printed and inserted in the Code, the Mayor and Town Clerk shall carefully examine at least one (1) copy of the Code as supplemented. The copy of the Code as originally adopted or amended shall constitute the permanent and general ordinances of the Town and shall be so accepted by the courts of law, administrative tribunals and all others concerned. 
(Prior code 1-16) 
Sec. 1-60. - Copy of Code on file. 
    At least one (1) copy of the Code shall be kept in the office of the Town Clerk at all times, and such Code may be inspected by any interested person at any time during regular office hours, but may not be removed from the Town Clerk's office except upon proper order of a court of law. 
(Prior code 1-17) 
Sec. 1-61. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  The Town Clerk shall cause supplementation of the Code to be prepared and printed from time to time as he or she may see fit. All substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the Town Council or adopted by initiative and referendum, and all amendments and changes in ordinances or other measures included in the Code since the previous supplementation, shall be included. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the Town Clerk, or someone authorized and directed by the Town Clerk, to keep up to date the copy of the book containing the Code required to be filed in the office of the Town Clerk for the use of the public. 
(Prior code 1-19) 
Sec. 1-62. - Sale of Code books; supplementation. 
    Copies of this Code and any supplements thereto may be purchased from the Town Clerk upon the payment of a fee in an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. 
(Prior code 1-20; Ord. 12 §B3, 2003) 
Sec. 1-63. - Altering or tampering with Code; penalties for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall alter, change or amend this Code except in the manner prescribed in this Article, or who shall alter or tamper with the Code in any manner so as to cause the ordinances of the Town to be misrepresented thereby shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as provided by Section 1-82. 
(Prior code 1-23) 
Secs. 1-64-1-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - General Penalty 

Sec. 1-81. - Violations. 
    It is a violation of this Code for any person to do any act which is forbidden or declared to be unlawful, or to fail to do or perform any act required, in this Code. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-82. - General penalty for violations. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person violating any provision or failing to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of the ordinances of the Town shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person convicted of a misdemeanor under the ordinances of the Town shall be punished by a fine in an amount set forth on the fee schedule for such fines adopted by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq . Further, any person convicted of a misdemeanor under the ordinances of the Town may be punished by imprisonment for a period not to exceed one (1) year, or by both such fine and imprisonment except as hereinafter provided in Section 1-83. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of the ordinances of the Town is committed, continued or permitted by any such person, and he or she shall be punished accordingly. In the event the Town shall incur court costs and/or attorney fees to prosecute a person for a violation of a Town ordinance, a person convicted of violation of a Town ordinance shall pay to the Town all attorney fees and costs reasonably incurred by the Town in such matter. 
(Prior code 1-5; Ord. 12 §B4, 2003) 
Sec. 1-83. - Application of penalties to juveniles and to convictions of lesser offense. 
    Every person who, at the time of commission of the offense, was at least ten (10) but not yet eighteen (18) years of age, and who is subsequently convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a violation of any provision of this Code, shall be punished by a fine in an amount set forth on the fee schedules for such fines adopted by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. Any voluntary plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the original charge or to a lesser or substituted charge shall subject the person so pleading to all fines and/or penalties applicable to the original charge. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 12 §B5, 2003) 
Sec. 1-84. - Penalty for violations of ordinances adopted after adoption of Code. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of any ordinance of a permanent and general nature passed or adopted after adoption of this Code, either before or after it has been inserted in the Code by a supplement, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as provided by Section 1-82, unless another penalty is specifically provided for the violation. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 1-85. - Interpretation of unlawful acts. 
    Whenever in this Code any act or omission is made unlawful, it is also unlawful to cause, allow, permit, aid, abet or suffer such unlawful act or omission. Concealing or in any manner aiding in the concealing of any unlawful act or omission is similarly unlawful. 
(Prior Code 1-3) 
Secs. 1-86-1-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Inspections 

Sec. 1-101. - Inspections by authorized officials. 
    Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any ordinance or resolution, or whenever there is reasonable cause to believe there exists an ordinance or resolution violation in any building or upon any premises within the jurisdiction of the Town, any authorized official of the Town may, upon presentation of the proper credentials, enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon him or her by ordinance; provided that, except in emergency situations, the authorized official shall give the owner and/or occupant, if they can be located after reasonable effort, twenty-four (24) hours' written notice of the authorized official's intention to inspect. In the event that the owner and/or occupant refuses entry, the official is hereby empowered to seek assistance from any court of competent jurisdiction in obtaining such entry. 
(Prior code 10-4) 
Sec. 1-102. - Authority to enter premises under emergency. 
    Law enforcement officers, members of the Fire Department, other fire departments operating under a mutual assistance agreement or automatic aid agreement with the Town, certified emergency medical technicians and paramedics during the course of employment with a governmental agency are hereby granted the authority to enter private residences within the Town without invitation from the occupant or occupants of the residence at any time such person has reasonable grounds to believe a medical emergency is in progress within the subject premises and the occupant or occupants of such premises are incapable of consenting to the entry because of such medical emergency. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Secs. 1-103-1-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI - Seal 

Sec. 1-121. - Corporate seal. 
    There is hereby established and declared to be a seal for the Town of Basalt, the impression of which shall be as follows: in the center the word "SEAL," and around the outer edge the words "Town of Basalt, Colorado." 
(Prior code 2-37) 
Secs. 1-122-1-140. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 2 - Administration and Personnel 
ARTICLE II - Mayor and Town Council 

Sec. 2-21. - Corporate authority; appointment of other officers; compensation of Mayor and Councilors. 
    The corporate authority of the Town is vested in a Town Council, consisting of one (1) Mayor and six (6) Councilors. The Town Council shall have the power to appoint such other officers and officials as provided in the Charter. The Mayor of the Town and each member of the Town Council shall receive compensation as established in the annual budget. 
(Prior code 2-1; Ord. 2, 2000; Ord. 33 §B2(3), 2003) 
Sec. 2-22. - Regular meetings. 
    The Town Council shall hold regular meetings on the second and fourth Tuesdays in each and every month at a time as set forth on the agenda for the meeting; provided, however, that when the date fixed for any regular meeting of the Town Council falls on a day designated by law as a legal or national holiday, the Town Council may, by resolution passed at the next preceding meeting, vacate the meeting date which falls on a holiday and may designate some other date upon which the meeting shall be held. All regular meetings of the Town Council will be held in the Town Hall unless posted on the agenda as to another location. 
(Ord. 03, 2005) 
Secs. 2-23-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Officers and Employees 

Sec. 2-51. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-52. - Town Clerk; oath and bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the Town Clerk shall take an oath of office and furnish a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful discharge of his or her duties as Town Clerk. 
(Prior code 2-11; Ord. 33 §B2(6), 2003) 
Sec. 2-53. - Duties of Town Clerk. 
    The Town Clerk shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Be the Clerk of the Town Council, attend all meetings of the Town Council and keep a permanent journal of its proceedings. The journal of the proceedings shall reflect the names of all Councilors who vote against or abstain from voting on any particular motion. 
(2)  Be the custodian of all of the Town's records, and such records shall be kept open at all reasonable times for inspection by electors of the Town. 
(3)  Attest by his or her signature all ordinances and resolutions enacted or passed by the Town Council. 
(4)  Provide and maintain in his or her office a supply of forms for all petitions required to be filed for any purposes provided by the Town Council. 
(5)  Be the custodian of all bonds of all officers and employees of the Town. 
(6)  Manage the Town Clerk's office and supervise and direct the work of all other employees in that office. 
(7)  Maintain a direct and close working relationship with the Town Council, the Mayor, Town Manager and other administrative and executive personnel. 
(8)  Regularly use discretion and independent judgment to carry out the policies and objectives of the Town Council and other executive and administrative officers. 
(9)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by laws of the State, the Town Council or the Code. 
(Prior code 2-12; Ord. 5 §1, 1991; Ord. 05 §1, 2004; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(6), 2003) 
Sec. 2-54. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-55. - Finance Director; oath and bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of the office, the Finance Director shall take an oath of office and furnish a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), to be approved by the Town Council, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties as Finance Director. When he or she shall vacate such office, the Finance Director shall turn over and deliver to his or her successor all money, books, papers, property or things belonging to the Town and remaining in his or her charge as Finance Director. 
(Prior code 2-14; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(6), 2003) 
Sec. 2-56. - Duties of Finance Director. 
    The Finance Director shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Receive all money belonging to the Town and give receipts therefor, keep his or her books and accounts in such manner as may be prescribed by the Town Council or by state statute, keep a separate account of each fund or appropriation and of the debts and credits belonging thereto, and report to the Town Council at each regular monthly meeting thereof the state of the treasury at the date of such account and the balance of money in the treasury. The Finance Director shall also accompany such statement of accounts with a statement of all monies received in the treasury and on what account during the preceding month, together with all warrants redeemed and paid by him or her, and their supporting vouchers shall be delivered and filed in the Town Clerk's office upon every day of such statement. All books and accounts of the Finance Director shall always be subject to inspection by any member of the Town Council. 
(2)  Annually, within ten (10) days after the close of the fiscal year, make out and file with the Town Clerk a full and detailed account of all receipts and expenditures of the Town and of all his or her transactions as Finance Director during the preceding fiscal year, and show in such account the state of the treasury at the close of the fiscal year. The Town Clerk shall immediately make available such account to the public. 
(3)  If there shall be no funds in his or her hands for the payment of any Town warrant presented to him or her for such payment, register such warrants in a book to be kept by him or her for such purpose, and endorse upon all such warrants so presented to him or her the time and date of such registry. Whenever he or she shall pay such warrants, he or she shall enter the payment and the amount of interest allowed or paid on such warrant in the registry. 
(4)  Manage the Finance Director's office and supervise and direct the work of all other employees in that office. 
(5)  Maintain a direct and close-working relationship with the Town Council, the Mayor, the Town Manager and other administrative and executive personnel. 
(6)  Regularly use discretion and independent judgment to carry out the policies and objectives of the Town Council and other executive and administrative officers. 
(7)  Serve as Assistant Budget Officer and prepare a budget annually. 
(8)  Perform all other duties, keep all records and make all reports that are required by the provisions of this Code or by the state laws. 
(Prior code 2-15, Ord. 5 §2, 1991, Ord. 11 §1, 1991; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(6), 2003) 
Sec. 2-57. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-58. - Duties of Town Attorney. 
    The Town Attorney shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Act as legal advisor to and be attorney and counsel for the Town Council, and be responsible solely to the Town Council. The Town Attorney shall advise any officer or department head of the Town in matters relating to his or her official duties when so requested by the Town Council and file with the Town Clerk a copy of all written opinions given by him or her. 
(2)  Prosecute ordinance violations and conduct cases for the Town in Municipal Court. He or she shall file with the Municipal Court Clerk copies of such records and files pertaining thereto. 
(3)  Prepare or review all ordinances, contracts, bonds or other written instruments which are submitted to him or her by the Town Council, and promptly give his or her opinion as to the legal consequences thereof. 
(4)  Call to the attention of the Town Council all matters of law and changes or developments therein affecting the Town. 
(5)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed for him or her by the Town Council. 
(Prior code 2-17; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(6), 2003) 
Sec. 2-59. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-60. - Acting Town Manager. 
    The Town Council, by majority vote, may appoint an Acting Town Manager during the period of each vacancy in the office or during the absence or disability of the Town Manager. Such Acting Town Manager shall, while he or she is in such office, have all the responsibilities, duties, functions and authority of the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 3-2; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-61. - Town Manager - Powers and duties. 
    The Town Manager shall be responsible to the Town Council for the proper administration of all affairs of the Town placed in his or her charge, and to that end he or she shall have the power and duty and be required to: 
(1)  Be responsible for the enforcement of the laws and ordinances of the Town. 
(2)  Cause a proposed budget to be prepared annually by the Assistant Budget Officer and submit it to the Town Council and be responsible for the administration of the budget after its adoption. 
(3)  Prepare and submit to the Town Council, as of the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the administrative activities of the Town for the preceding year and, upon request of the Town Council, make written or verbal reports at any time concerning the affairs of the Town under his or her supervision. 
(4)  Keep the Town Council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the Town and make such recommendations to the Town Council for adoption as he or she may deem necessary or expedient. 
(5)  Except as limited by the Charter, exercise supervision and control over all executive and administrative departments, including the consolidation or abolishment of administrative departments, the creation or abolishment of positions within existing or new departments and the hiring and firing of all personnel. The Town Manager may change the title or responsibilities of any employee or with regard to any position of employment in the Town as long as the Town Manager assures that all of the duties and responsibilities that are outlined for that position below and throughout this Code are assigned to an employee and/or contractor of the Town. The Town Manager shall be responsible for ensuring that each employee of the Town is informed of his or her responsibilities under the Charter or this Code. 
(6)  Be responsible for the enforcement of all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the Town in any contract or public utility franchise and, upon knowledge of any violation thereof, report the same to the Town Council for such action and proceedings as may be necessary to enforce the same. 
(7)  Attend Town Council meetings and participate in discussions with the Town Council in an advisory capacity. 
(8)  Provide for engineering, architectural, maintenance and construction services required by the Town at the direction of the Town Council. 
(9)  Perform the duties of Building Inspector and Zoning Enforcement Officer in whatever functions that may be required in these capacities. 
(10)  Perform such other duties as may be required of him or her by the Town Council which are not inconsistent with this job. 
(Prior code 3-3, Ord. 11 §2, 1991; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(6), (7), 2003; Ord. 09 §2, 2013) 
Sec. 2-62. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-63. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-64. - Appointment of Building Inspector; term. 
    The Town Manager may appoint, at any time after this Article becomes effective, a qualified person as a Building Inspector. The Building Inspector shall serve until the next regular election or until his or her successor is appointed. 
(Prior code 10-1; Ord. 33 §B2(8), 2003) 
Sec. 2-65. - Powers and duties; Building Inspector. 
    The Building Inspector shall be the chief enforcement officer for all building regulations, zoning regulations and subdivision regulations. He or she shall have all powers of inspection and all other powers granted by ordinance and allowed by law. He or she shall issue applications for permits in accordance with the above regulations, and perform all other duties as the Town Council may direct or as are compelled by law. 
(Prior code 10-2; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(6), 2003) 
Sec. 2-66. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-67. - Town Planner. 
    The Town Manager shall appoint a Town Planner. It shall be the duty of the Town Planner to: 
(1)  Advise the Planning and Zoning Commission, Board of Adjustment and Town employees on all matters relating to planning and zoning within the Town. 
(2)  Review all plans and proposals by Town employees or private individuals which concern planning and zoning matters, to determine whether such plans and proposals conform to the master plan and the rules and regulations of the Town and the laws of the State. 
(3)  Manage the Town Planner's office and supervise and direct the work of all other employees in that office. 
(4)  Maintain a direct and close-working relationship with the Town Council, the Mayor, the Town Manager and other administrative and executive personnel. 
(5)  Regularly use discretion and independent judgment to carry out the policies and objectives of the Town Council and other executive and administrative officers. 
(6)  Carry out such other duties, and prepare such other records and reports as prescribed by the Town Council, this Code or state law. 
(Ord. 5 §4, 1991; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(9), 2003) 
Sec. 2-68. - Public Works Director. 
    The Town Manager shall appoint a Public Works Director. It shall be the duty of the Public Works Director to: 
(1)  Oversee and act as chief administrator of the Maintenance and Building Inspection Departments. 
(2)  Manage the Town Public Works office and supervise and direct the work of all other employees in that office. 
(3)  Maintain a direct and close-working relationship with the Town Council, the Mayor, the Town Manager and other administrative and executive personnel. 
(4)  Regularly use discretion and independent judgment to carry out the policies and objectives of the Town Council and other executive and administrative officers. 
(5)  Undertake such other duties and responsibilities as the Town Council or this Code shall prescribe. 
(Ord. 5 §5, 1991; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(10), 2003) 
Sec. 2-69. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-70. - Oaths of office. 
    Whenever it is required that an officer or other appointee under this Code shall be required to take an oath before entering upon the duties of such office and no oath is specifically prescribed, such oath shall be in substantially the following form: 
"I, ......................., do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of the United State of America and the State of Colorado and that I will well and faithfully perform the duties of the office of ....................... of the Town of Basalt, Colorado, upon which I am about to enter." 
(Prior code 2-30; Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 2-71. - Personnel Review Board. 
(a)  There is hereby created a Personnel Review Board consisting of six (6) regular members and three (3) alternates, appointed by the Town Council. The members of the regular Personnel Review Board shall be as follows: two (2) members from the Town Council; two (2) members from the Town staff; and two (2) members from the citizenry of the Town, other than Town staff or Town Council members. The initial terms of office of one (1) member from the Town Council, one (1) member from the Town staff and one (1) member from the citizenry shall expire on December 31, 1980; and terms of office of the remaining three (3) Board members shall expire on December 31, 1981. After these initial terms, the regular terms of membership shall be for two (2) years. The Town Council shall select three (3) alternate members from the citizenry, who may or may not be members of the Town Council or of the Town staff, who shall serve for two-year terms but whose initial terms shall expire December 31, 1980. 
(b)  Upon the resignation or discharge of a member of the Personnel Review Board, a successor shall be chosen to serve out the remaining term. 
(c)  If a regular member of the Personnel Review Board fails to attend, without being excused by the Chairman, three (3) consecutive meetings or five (5) meetings within any twelve-month period, the member shall be discharged by the Chairman of the Personnel Review Board. 
(d)  The Personnel Review Board may adopt, upon the prior approval of the Town Council, rules and regulations governing its procedures, which shall not be inconsistent with this Code or with the Personnel Code. The rules and regulations shall provide, among other things, that the Personnel Review Board shall elect a Chairman and a Secretary, shall meet at least quarterly and shall submit minutes of its meetings to the Town Manager and, upon request, to the Town Council. 
(e)  If a regular member cannot attend a meeting, an alternate member selected by the Chairman shall take his or her place, and the alternate member shall have at such meeting all the duties and privileges of the absent regular member. 
(Prior code 2-31; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-72. - Discharge or suspension of Town employees. 
(a)  No employee or officer of the Town shall be deemed to have a vested or property right to continued employment with the Town. Any employee may be discharged, demoted or suspended for not more than thirty (30) working days without pay if the Town Manager determines at any time, with or without the recommendations of the Personnel Review Board after appeal, that the employee committed any of the following: 
(1)  Any unlawful conduct which affects, interrupts or interferes with the employee's performance of his or her job duties. 
(2)  Willful, reckless or negligent failure to perform the employee's job duty. 
(3)  Refusal or repeated inability to follow orders of superiors relating to the performance of job duty. 
(4)  Repeated inefficiencies or incompetency in performing job duties or in following orders of superiors relating to the performance of job duties. 
(5)  Violation of department regulations of the department in which the employee works. 
(6)  Conviction of any act constituting a felony or a misdemeanor, or involving dishonesty or other moral turpitude. 
(7)  Working while under the influence of or impaired by intoxicating liquor. 
(8)  Appearing for scheduled work under the influence of or impaired by intoxicating liquor. 
(9)  Appearing for work or working under the influence or consuming during work narcotic drugs or dangerous drugs without a valid doctor's prescription. 
(10)  Working in violation of the orders of the employee's physician which direct the employee not to work. 
(11)  Willful, reckless or negligent destruction of the Town's property. 
(12)  Excessive tardiness. 
(13)  Refusal to accept and comply with any promotion, demotion or other job reassignment. 
(14)  Incurring a physical or mental condition which renders the employee unfit or unable to perform his or her job duties. 
(15)  Making or allowing any false statement in the employee's application for employment. 
(16)  Being absent from work without authorized vacation leave or emergency leave. 
(b)  The choice of ordering demotion, discipline or discharge shall be the Town Manager's, who shall select a choice which in his or her opinion is suited to the gravity of the situation. 
(Prior code 2-31.3; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-73. - Disciplinary action. 
    Discipline may include suspension without pay for not more than thirty (30) workdays, private reprimand, public reprimand, removal of merit increase for not more than twelve (12) months, demotion, reassignment, requiring further job training and requiring the employee to pay for damages caused. 
(Prior code 2-31.4) 
Sec. 2-74. - Discipline of officer. 
    If the Town Manager or a majority of the members of the Town Council determines that one (1) or more of the grounds for discharge or discipline set forth in Section 2-72 has been committed by the Chief of Police, the Town Clerk or the Finance Director, the Town Council shall hold a hearing within seven (7) days' notice to the officer involved. At the hearing, the officer may present evidence and witnesses on his or her own behalf, be represented by counsel and cross-examine witnesses. Such officer may be discharged by the Town Council if the Council finds that such officer committed one (1) or more of those acts set forth in Section 2-72 above. 
(Prior code 2-31.5; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-75. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-76. - Personnel Code. 
    The Town Council shall enact by resolution a Personnel Code for all the Town's officers and employees, except the Town Manager, Town Attorney and Municipal Judge. The Personnel Code shall establish rules and regulations for the employment relationship between such persons and the Town and shall include, among other things, provisions for hiring, probationary employees, part-time employees, job position designations, pay rates, overtime, holidays, vacations and any other provisions convenient or necessary to assist, direct and manage the employees of the Town. To the extent there is any inconsistency or conflict between the Personnel Code and sections 2-71 through 2-74 above, the Personnel Code shall govern and control. 
(Prior code 2-31.7; Ord. 33 §B2(11), 2003) 
Secs. 2-77-2-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Social Security 

Sec. 2-91. - Benefit of insurance to both personnel and Town. 
    It is the opinion of the Town Council that the extension of the social security system to certain employees and officers of the Town will benefit said employees by allowing them to participate in the provisions of the Old Age and Survivor's Insurance System and will benefit the Town. However, it is the opinion of the Town Council that the social security system should not be extended to police officers and the Chief of Police, or to extend the social security system or provide Old Age and Survivor's Insurance System benefits to police officers or the Chief of Police. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to refer to or include police officers or the Chief of Police, or to extend the social security system or provide Old Age and Survivor's Insurance System benefits to police officers or the Chief of Police. 
(Prior code 2-32; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-92. - Enabling act; authorization of plan and agreement. 
    The 38th General Assembly of the State of Colorado, in regular session, enacted a statute, known as "House Bill No. 291," which is the enabling Act provided for in Section 218 of Public Law 734, 81st Congress, which designated the Department of Employment Security, State of Colorado, to act as the department to implement the coverage of employees and officers under said Old Age and Survivor's Insurance System. The Town is hereby authorized to execute and deliver to the Department of Employment Security a plan or plans, and agreement, required under Section 5 of said enabling Act and the Social Security Act, to extend coverage to employees and officers under the Old Age and Survivor's Insurance System. 
(Prior code 2-33) 
Sec. 2-93. - Authorization to establish payroll deduction system. 
    The Finance Director is hereby authorized to establish a system of payroll deduction, to be matched by payments by the Town, to be paid into the Contribution Fund of the State through the Department of Employment Security, and to make charges of this tax to the funds from which wage or salary payments are issued to employees of the Town. Such payments are to be made, in accordance with the provisions of Sections 1400 and 1410 of the Federal Insurance Contribution Act, on all services which constitute employment within the meaning of that Act. Payments made to the Department of Employment Security shall be due and payable on or before the 18th day of the month immediately following the completed calendar quarter, and such payments which are delinquent shall bear interest at the rate of one-half of one percent (.5%) per month until such time as payments are made. 
(Prior code 2-34; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-94. - Appropriation. 
    Appropriation is hereby made from the proper fund or funds of the Town in the necessary amount to pay into the Contribution Fund as provided in Section 5(c)(1) of the enabling Act and in accordance with the plan or plans and agreement. 
(Prior code 2-35) 
Sec. 2-95. - Authority to enter into agreement. 
    Authority is given to the Mayor and the Town Clerk to enter into an agreement with the Department of Employment Security, which agreement shall be in accordance with House Bill No. 291 and with Paragraph 218 of the Social Security Act. Such plan and agreement shall provide that the participation of the Town shall be in effect as of July 1, 1966. 
(Prior code 2-36) 
Secs. 2-96-2-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Police Department 

Sec. 2-111. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a Police Department for the Town, which shall consist of one (1) Chief of Police and as many police officers as may from time to time be deemed necessary for the safety and good order of the Town. 
(Prior code 2-18) 
Sec. 2-112. - Departmental rules and regulations. 
    The Police Department shall be operated and managed in accordance with such departmental rules and regulations as may from time to time be adopted by the Town Council. 
(Prior code 2-19; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-113. - Chief of Police: appointment; powers and duties; oath and bond. 
(a)  The Town Manager, with the approval of the Town Council, shall appoint a Chief of Police, who shall be the head of the Police Department. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to: 
(1)  See that the ordinances of the Town are duly enforced and the rules and regulations of the Police Department obeyed, and perform such duties as may be required by the Town Council. 
(2)  Direct the operations of the Police Department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof, and supervise the work of all the other employees in that department. 
(3)  Arrest any person violating any of the Town ordinances and take such violator before the Municipal Court for trial. 
(4)  Take charge of the Town jail and all prisoners confined therein, and all those who are sentenced to labor on the streets or public works of the Town, and see that orders and sentences with reference to such are fully executed and complied with. 
(5)  Render such accounts of the Police Department, his or her duties and receipts as may be required by the Town Council, and keep the records of his or her office open to the inspection of the Town Council at any time. 
(6)  Act as the town disaster coordinator and his or her department shall act as the municipal disaster agency. The salary of the Police Chief shall not be increased by reason of his or her performing the duties of disaster coordinator, as such responsibilities are deemed to be incidental to the office. 
(c)  Before entering upon the duties of such office, the Chief of Police shall take and subscribe to an oath that he or she will support the Constitution and laws of the State, the Constitution of the United States and the ordinances of the Town, and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he or she is about to enter. He or she shall furnish a surety bond, to be approved by the Town Council, in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of his or her office. 
(Prior code 2-20, Ord. 5 §3, 1991; Ord. 05 §2, 2004; Ord. 33 §§B1, B2(12), 2003) 
Sec. 2-114. - Duties of police officers. 
    All members of the Police Department shall have powers and duties as follows: 
(1)  Perform all duties required bythe Chief of Police. 
(2)  Suppress all riots, disturbances and breaches of the peace, apprehend all disorderly persons in the Town, and pursue and arrest any person fleeing from justice in any part of the State. 
(3)  Be the enforcement officers of the Town and see that the provisions of this Code and the laws of the State are complied with. They shall arrest without process all persons engaged in the violation in their presence of any provision of this Code or the laws of the State. Upon such arrest they shall forthwith convey such offenders before the proper officer, to be dealt with according to the law; provided, however, that they may incarcerate any person whom they shall arrest at a late or unusual hour of the night until the following morning; and provided further that, in special cases relating to traffic offenses, they may release the arrested person upon his or her promise to appear in court. 
(4)  Report such offenses as may come to their knowledge to the proper Town official or report the same to the Municipal Judge, securing a warrant for the arrest of offenders when desirable. 
(5)  Execute and return all writs and processes directed to them by the Municipal Judge in any case arising out of a Town ordinance, and may serve the same in any part of the County in which the Town is situated. 
(6)  Observe the conditions of the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the Town, and of any obstruction, nuisance or impediments therein, and shall take necessary measures to remove or abate the same. 
(Prior code 2-21) 
Sec. 2-115. - Uniforms. 
    Every police officer shall wear at all times while on duty a uniform of the type and quality prescribed by the Town Council. 
(Prior code 2-24; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-116. - Extraterritorial duty. 
    The Chief of Police may, in his or her discretion, upon the request of the chief of police or person exercising the functions thereof in any other jurisdiction, assign police officers under his or her control, together with such equipment as he or she shall deem proper, to perform temporary duty in the requesting jurisdiction. 
(Prior code 2-26) 
Secs. 2-117-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI - Municipal Court 

Sec. 2-131. - Creation of Municipal Court. 
    A qualified Municipal Court of record in and for the Town is hereby created and established pursuant to and governed by the provisions of state law. 
(Prior code 6-1; Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 2-132. - Jurisdiction. 
    The Municipal Court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction to hear, try and determine all causes arising under this Code or any of the ordinances of the Town. 
(Prior code 6-8) 
Sec. 2-133. - Procedure governed by Colorado Municipal Court Rules and the Court. 
    The procedure, unless otherwise provided in this Article, in the Municipal Court shall be governed by Colorado Municipal Court Rules. The Municipal Judge may make rules for procedures which are not inconsistent with such Colorado Municipal Court Rules, including powers incident to compelling attendance of witnesses, punishment for contempt, and enforcement of orders of Court. 
(Prior code 6-9) 
Sec. 2-134. - Record of proceedings. 
    It shall be a further duty of the Court Clerk to keep and maintain a verbatim record of all proceedings and evidence at trials, by either electric devices or stenographic means. 
(Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 2-135. - Sessions. 
    There shall be regular sessions of Court for the hearing of cases. The Municipal Judge may hold a special session of Court at any time. All sessions of Court shall be open to the public. Where the nature of the case is such that it would be in the best interests of justice to exclude persons not directly connected with the proceeding, the Municipal Judge may order that the courtroom be cleared. 
(Prior code 6-3) 
Sec. 2-136. - Municipal Judges: appointment, oath, salary, powers. 
(a)  The Court shall be presided over by a Municipal Judge appointed for the term of two (2) years at the first regular Town Council meeting following each biennial election. Additional Judges may be appointed as may be needed to transact the business of the Court. If the Municipal Judge shall find it necessary to disqualify himself or herself in a given case, or should he or she be unable to serve for any reason, including vacation or illness, the Town Council may, by resolution, appoint a Judge to hear cases for such time as the presiding Judge is absent. A vacancy in the office of Municipal Judge shall be filled by appointment by the Town Council of the Town for the remainder of the unexpired term. In order for a person to be qualified for the office of Municipal Judge, such person shall be admitted to and be currently licensed in the practice of law in the State. 
(b)  Compensation of the Municipal Judge shall be an annual salary in an amount to be set by the Town Council and shall be payable as other salaries to the municipal employees are paid. The annual salary of the Municipal Judge may not be decreased during his or her term of office. 
(c)  Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the Municipal Judge shall take an oath by affirmation that he or she will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State and the ordinances of the Town and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of his or her office. 
(d)  In addition to other powers, the Municipal Judge shall have full power and authority to make and adopt rules and regulations for the conduct of the business of the Municipal Court, consistent with the Municipal Court Rules of Procedure promulgated by the Colorado Supreme Court. 
(Prior code 6-4; Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-137. - Court Clerk: duties and reports, bond. 
(a)  The presiding Municipal Judge shall act as ex officio Clerk of the Court. The Municipal Judge, in his or her capacity as ex officio Court Clerk, shall file monthly reports with the Finance Director of all monies collected, and on the last day of each month shall pay to the Finance Director all monies then in the hands of the Court. 
(b)  The Municipal Judge shall, as ex officio Clerk, execute a performance bond in the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), payable to the Town, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties and the faithful accounting for and payment of all funds deposited with or received by the Court. Such bond shall be approved by the Town Council prior to the time the Municipal Judge takes office. 
(Prior code 6-5; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 2-138. - Appropriations. 
    The Town Council shall, on an annual basis, budget and appropriate funds to pay the annual salary of the Municipal Judge, together with such other expenses as many be necessary for the proper operation of a Municipal Court. 
(Prior code 6-6) 
Sec. 2-139. - Imposition of Court costs. 
    The Municipal Judge is empowered, in his or her discretion, to assess the following costs against any defendant who is found guilty of violating any provision of this Code or any of the ordinances of the Town or against any defendant who is granted deferred prosecution or deferred sentence: 
(1)  Court costs. Court costs in an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. Penalty assessment or traffic infraction citations postmarked or received by the Municipal Court more than twenty (20) days after the date issued shall be be assessed court costs; 
(2)  Bench warrant fee. A bench warrant fee in an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq., plus any costs incurred for transporting the defendant from his or her place of arrest to the Town; 
(3)  Probationary, incarceration or other services. Actual costs incurred either by the Town or the defendant for probationary or treatment services for the defendant, incarceration or useful public service by the defendant as such may be ordered by the Court; 
(4)  Letter fee. A letter fee in an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq., for any letter sent to a defendant where the defendant has failed to respond to a written notice of court or a summons. Such letter fee shall not limit the Court's ability to fine or sentence a defendant for contempt for such failure to respond. 
(5)  VALE surcharge. Victims and Witnesses Assistance. A surcharge equal to a percentage of the fine imposed for violation of municipal ordinances, including violations under the Model Traffic Code, in the amount of twenty-five percent (25%) shall be charged. All calculated surcharge amounts resulting in dollars and cents shall be rounded to the nearest whole dollar. In the event a portion of the fine is suspended, the surcharge levied shall be computed based upon the original fine, regardless of whether a portion of said fine has been suspended. Said surcharge shall be paid to the Clerk of the Court by the Defendant, and said Clerk shall deposit the money so received in the Victims and Witnesses Assistance Fund. Disbursement of funds shall be in accordance with the guidelines set forth in Section 2-362(d). 
(6)  Police training surcharge. A surcharge equal to a percentage of the fine imposed for a violation of municipal ordinances, including violations under the Model Traffic Code, in the amount of twenty-five percent (25%) shall be charged. All calculated surcharge amounts resulting in dollars and cents shall be rounded to the nearest whole dollar. In the event a portion of the fine is suspended, the surcharge levied shall be computed based upon the original fine, regardless of whether a portion of said fine has been suspended. Said surcharge shall be paid to the Clerk of the Court by the Defendant, and said Clerk shall deposit the money so received in a separate fund allocated for Town of Basalt police officer training. 
(Prior code 6-10; Ord. 10 §1, 1992; Ord. 23 §1, 1996; Ord. 17 §2, 2001; Ord. 12 §§B6-B9, 2003; Ord. 23 §1, 2013) 
Sec. 2-140. - Restitution. 
    The Municipal Judge is empowered to order a defendant who is found guilty of violating any provision of this Code or any of the ordinances of the Town or who is granted a deferred prosecution or deferred sentence to make restitution or reparation, or both, to the victim of the defendant's conduct for the damage or injury which was sustained. 
(Prior code 6-11) 
Sec. 2-141. - Failure to appear unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor offense for any person to fail to appear in Municipal Court when directed to do so by a summons or when ordered to do so by the Municipal Court. Upon conviction of a violation of this Section, such person shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 1, Article IV of this Code. 
(Prior code 6-12; Ord. 18 §1, 1997; Ord. 22 §1, 1998) 
Sec. 2-142. - Appearance by counsel acceptable. 
    A written promise to appear in the Municipal Court may be complied with by an appearance by counsel. 
(Prior code 6-13) 
Secs. 2-143-2-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII - Planning and Zoning Commission 

Sec. 2-161. - Creation; composition. 
(a)  Creation. There is hereby created and established a Planning and Zoning Commission in and for the Town. 
(b)  Composition. 
(1)  Regular Members. Such Commission shall consist of seven (7) members to be appointed by the Town Council, five (5) of whom shall be citizens at large and two (2) of whom may be either citizens at large or incumbent Councilors. The citizen-at-large members shall be bona fide residents of the Town, having maintained their primary place of residency within the Town for a minimum of six (6) months, and shall hold no paid office or position in the Town staff. 
(2)  Any member who is no longer a bona fide resident of the Town, no longer maintaining his or her primary place of residency within the Town, shall be removed from the Commission by the Town Council. 
(3)  Alternate Members. The Town Council may appoint one (1) or two (2) alternate members to the Commission. The alternate member or members shall sit with the Planning and Zoning Commission in all hearings and may participate in all discussions as a regular member. An alternate member may vote only in the event a regular Commission member is unable to vote because of absence, illness, conflict of interest or any other reason. Alternate members shall serve for a term of three (3) years. If there is more than one (1) alternate member, then at meetings where only one (1) alternate member's vote is needed, the alternate members shall rotate with one (1) alternate member voting for all votes taken at a Commission meeting and the other alternate member voting in all votes taken at the next Commission meeting where a single alternate member vote is needed. 
(c)  Terms. 
(1)  Citizen-at-large members shall have overlapping three-year terms. At the end of each such member's term, the Town shall advertise and seek applicants for a vacancy on the Commission. Any member whose term is expiring may apply for reappointment to the Commission. Any appointment or reappointment shall be at the discretion of the Town Council pursuant to Subsection (b) of this Section. 
(2)  The term of an incumbent Councilor appointed to the Commission before or during his or her tenure as a Councilor shall be concurrent with his or her term as Councilor. Incumbent Council members appointed during their tenure as Councilor shall continue as a member so long as they remain a Councilor, including any term as Councilor to which they are reelected. Upon expiration of the term of a Councilor appointed to the Commission prior to said person becoming a Councilor, the position occupied by the incumbent Councilor shall be filled by a citizen at large. 
(3)  The term of a citizen-at-large Commissioner elected to the Town Council shall expire with the completion of the Commission term. However, such Commissioner/Councilor shall be eligible for reappointment to the Commission by the Town Council as an incumbent Councilor Commissioner. 
(4)  Any Planning and Zoning Commission member who fails to attend three (3) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without excuse from the Commission may be removed from the Commission by the Town Council upon recommendation of the Commission. The Commission may excuse the absence of any Commissioners for just cause. 
(5)  Upon the resignation or discharge of a regular citizen-at-large member of the Planning and Zoning Commission, the Councilors shall appoint a new regular member as provided in Subsection (b) of this Section. 
(d)  Officers. 
(1)  The Planning and Zoning Commission shall, at the regular annual meeting in May, organize and elect from among the appointed regular members a chairperson and vice chairperson. Such officers shall serve one-year terms and shall be eligible for reelection. 
(2)  The chairperson shall preside at all meetings and public hearings of the Planning and Zoning Commission, shall decide all points of order or procedure and shall certify plans and transmit reports and recommendations of the Commission to the Town Council. 
(3)  Town staff shall act as the recording secretary, carry on all routine correspondence of the Planning and Zoning Commission, maintain the Commission's files and present, before the next meeting, a copy of the minutes of the Commission's preceding meeting. 
(e)  Meetings.
