(b)  Any person, knowing he or she has insufficient funds with a drawee who, with intent to defraud, issued a check, in an amount less than four hundred dollars ($400.00), for the payment of services, wages, salary, commissions, labor, rent, money, property or other thing of value, commits fraud by check, which is a misdemeanor. 
(c)  This Section does not relieve the prosecution from the necessity of establishing the required knowledge by evidence. However, for purposes of this Section, the issuer's knowledge of insufficient funds is presumed, except in the case of a post-dated check or order if: 
(1)  He or she has no account upon which the check or order is drawn with the bank or other drawee at the time he or she issues the check or order; or 
(2)  He or she has insufficient funds upon deposit with the bank or other drawee to pay the check or order, on presentation within thirty (30) days after the issue. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Section, no violation of this Section occurs if: 
(1)  The check alleged to be fraudulent was for a sum in excess of an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq., or more; 
(2)  The person issues two (2) or more checks within any thirty-day period in the State totaling an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq., or more in the aggregate; 
(3)  The person issuing the check has been twice previously convicted under Section 18-5-205, C.R.S., or any former state statute of similar content and purpose; or 
(4)  The allegedly fraudulent check was drawn on an account which did not exist or which has been closed for a period of thirty (30) days or more prior to the issuance of said check. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to open a checking account using false identification or an assumed name for the purpose of issuing fraudulent checks. 
(f)  If deferred prosecution or sentencing is ordered, the court as a condition of such disposition may require the defendant to make restitution on all checks issued by the defendant which are unpaid as of the date of commencement of the deferred period in addition to other terms and conditions appropriate for the treatment or rehabilitation of the defendant. 
(g)  A bank or other savings institution shall not be civilly or criminally liable for releasing information relating to the drawer's account to a police officer, town attorney, assistant town attorney or authorized investigator for a town attorney investigating or prosecuting a charge under this Section. 
(h)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person violating any provisions or failing to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of this Section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code 38-1, 38-2; Ord. 17 §§1, 2, 1992; Ord. 12 §B30, 2003) 
Sec. 10-24. - Petty theft. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commit theft. A person commits theft when he knowingly obtains or exercises control over anything of value of another without authorization, or by threat or deception, where the value of the thing involved is less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), and: 
(1)  Intends to deprive the other person permanently of the use or benefit of the thing of value; or 
(2)  Knowingly uses, conceals, or abandons the thing of value in such manner as to deprive the other person permanently of its use or benefit; or 
(3)  Uses, conceals, or abandons the thing of value intending that such use, concealment or abandonment will deprive the other person permanently of its use and benefit; or 
(4)  Demands any consideration to which be is not legally entitled as a condition of restoring the thing of value to the other person. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, a thing of value is that of "another" if anyone other than the defendant has a possessory or proprietary interest therein. 
(c)  Every person who obtains control over any stolen thing of value, where the value of the thing involved is less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), knowing the thing of value to have been stolen by another, may be tried, convicted and punished, whether or not the principal is charged, tried or convicted. 
(d)  Questioning of person suspected of shoplifting without liability. If any person conceals upon his person or otherwise carries away any unpurchased goods, wares or merchandise held or owned by any store or mercantile establishment, the merchant or any employee thereof or any police officer, acting in good faith and upon probable cause based upon reasonable ground therefor, may detain and question such person in a reasonable manner for the purpose of ascertaining whether the person is guilty of theft. Such questioning of a person by a merchant, merchant's employee or police officer does not render the merchant, merchant's employee or police officer civilly or criminally liable for slander, false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution or unlawful detention. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, any reference or mention of stealing, false pretenses, or shoplifting shall be interpreted as if the word "theft" were substituted therefor. 
(f)  Any person who fails to comply with any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine as specified in Chapter 1, Article IV of this Code. 
(Ord. 17 §3, 1992; Ord. 12 §B31, 2003; Ord. 07 §1, 2014) 
Sec. 10-25. - Obstructing highway or passageway. 
(a)  An individual or corporation commits an offense if without legal privilege such individual or corporation intentionally, knowingly or recklessly: 
(1)  Obstructs a highway, street, sidewalk, railway, waterway, building entrance, elevator, aisle, stairway or hallway to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access or any other place used for the passage of persons, vehicles or conveyances, whether the obstruction arises from his or her acts alone or from his or her acts and the acts of others; or 
(2)  Disobeys a reasonable request or order to move issued by a person the individual or corporation knows to be a peace officer, a firefighter or a person with authority to control the use of the premises, to prevent obstruction of a highway or passageway or to maintain public safety by dispersing those gathered in dangerous proximity to a fire, riot or other hazard. 
(b)  For purposes of this Section, obstruct means to render impassable or to render passage unreasonably inconvenient or hazardous. 
(c)  Obstructing a highway or passageway is a petty offense punishable under Chapter 1, Article IV, Section 1-82 or 1-83 of this Code. 
(Ord. 12, 1998) 
Sec. 10-26. - Excreting in public. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate on any public street, upon any public sidewalk, in any other public place, in any public vehicle or in any store, assembly hall, corridor or other place open to or used by the public except restrooms and toilets which are provided for this purpose. 
(b)  Any person found to be in violation of this Section shall be punished in accordance with Chapter I, Article IV, Sections 1-82 and 1-84 of this Code. 
(Ord. 11, 1998) 
Sec. 10-27. - Unlawful use and possession of marijuana and related offenses. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this Chapter, the following words shall have the following definitions: 
    Marijuana means all parts of the plant cannabis sativa L., whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of the plant, and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant, its seeds, or its resin, It does not include fiber produced from the stalks, oil, or cake made from the seeds of the plant, or sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination, if these items exist apart from any other item defined as marijuana in this subsection. Marijuana shall include any product containing marijuana, which shall include but not be limited to extracts, by-products and vapors. 
    Registry identification card shall have the same meaning as is set forth in Article XVIII, Section 14(1)(b) of the Colorado Constitution, or as may be more fully defined in any applicable state law or regulation. 
    Underage person means any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(b)  Consumption of marijuana in public prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall consume any marijuana in public. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, in public means: 
a.  In or upon any public way or public right-of-way, whether in a vehicle or not; 
b.  On any property or in any building that is owned, leased, used by, or open to the public; or 
c.  In or upon those portions of any private property upon which the public has an express or implied license to enter or remain or for which the public can observe such use in plain view. 
(3)  No person shall drive or sit in any motor vehicle, other than one licensed to carry passengers for hire, in which a violation of subsection (b)(1) of this section is occurring. 
(4)  The maximum penalty for a conviction, based on date of violation of this section, is a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  Unlawful to sell or give to or procure for minors. No person shall sell, serve, deliver, or give away any marijuana or any product containing marijuana to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) or purchase marijuana or marijuana-infused product for an person under the age of twenty-one (21). 
(d)  Possession and sale by minors unlawful. 
(1)  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) shall consume, possess or have under such person's control or request that any other person purchase for such person under the age of twenty-one (21) or sell, serve, give away or offer for sale any marijuana or any product containing marijuana, which shall include but not be limited to extracts, by-products and vapors. 
(2)  Prima facie evidence that a violation of this chapter occurred within the Town shall consist of: 
a.  Evidence that the defendant was under the age of twenty-one (21) years and possessed or consumed marijuana or any product containing marijuana, which shall include but not be limited to extracts, by-products and vapors within the Town; 
b.  Evidence that the defendant was under the age of twenty-one (21) years and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated with marijuana use or impairment while present anywhere within the Town; or 
c.  Indicia including bloodshot eyes, watery eyes, eyelid tremors, green particulate on tongue, dilated pupils, dry mouth or any other indicator of marijuana consumption. 
(3)  An underage person and one (1) or two (2) other persons shall be immune from criminal prosecution under this section if they establish the following: 
a.  One (1) of the underage persons called 911 and reported that another underage person was in need of medical assistance due to marijuana consumption; 
b.  The underage person who called 911 and, if applicable, one (1) or two (2) other persons acting in concert with the underage person who called 911 provided each of their names to the 911 operator; 
c.  The underage person was the first person to make the 911 report; and 
d.  The underage person and, if applicable, one (1) or two (2) other persons acting in concert with the underage person who made the 911 call remained on the scene with the underage person in need of medical assistance until assistance arrived and cooperated with medical assistance and law enforcement personnel on the scene. 
(4)  In any judicial proceeding in any court of this state concerning a charge under this section, the court shall take judicial notice of methods of testing a person's blood, breath, saliva or urine for the presence of Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and of the design and operation of devices certilied by the department of public health and environment for testing a person's blood, breath, saliva or urine for the presence of Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). This subsection shall not prevent the necessity of establishing during a trial that the testing devices were working properly and that such testing devices were properly operated. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude a defendant from offering evidence concerning the accuracy of testing devices. 
(5)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a charged violation of this section that the underage person (1) on the date of the alleged offense lawfully possessed a current registry identification card issued by the state of Colorado to the underage person, and (2) possessed no more marijuana than the amount permitted by Article XVIII, Section 14 of the Colorado Constitution. Before evidence of this affirmative defense is presented to a jury, the underage person shall first provide written notice of this defense to the court and prosecution and a photocopy of the underage person's registry identification card, at least ten (10) days prior to trial. An underage person who raises this defense waives doctor-patient privilege and confidentiality concerning the underage person's patient registry information. 
(6)  The maximum penalty for a conviction, based on date of violation of this section, is a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(e)  Evidence of marijuana in trials. 
(1)  In any trial for a violation of this chapter, any witness with prior personal experience of the appearance, taste, or smell of marijuana may state an opinion that a substance was marijuana, based on his or her observations and experience. The witness need not be offered as an expert witness. 
(2)  In any trial for a violation of this chapter, any witness may testify that a person manifested characteristics commonly associated with marijuana use if the witness has personal experience or training that would enable the witness to recognize the characteristics. The witness need not be offered as an expert witness. 
(3)  In any trial for a violation of this section, any container or wrapper with labeling indicating the contents of the container or wrapper shall be admissible into evidence and the information on any label on such container or wrapper shall be admissible into evidence and shall not constitute hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon such label in determining whether the contents of the container or wrapper were composed in whole or in part of marijuana. A label identifying the contents of the container as "marijuana," "MJ," "weed," "bud," "saliva," "indica," or "kush" or any other slang term used for the identification of marijuana or its by-products shall constitute prima facie evidence that the contents of the container were composed in whole or in part of marijuana. 
(4)  In any trial for a violation of this section, testimony of a competent witness, including the arresting officer, that the substance possessed exhibited the smell, appearance or other characteristics of marijuana shall be sufficient to establish that the substance in question was marijuana. The defendant may rebut such testimony with a laboratory test, performed at the defendant's expense demonstrating that the substance was not marijuana. 
(f)  Possession in schools, daycares or governmental buildings. No person shall consume, possess or have under such person's control or sell, serve, give away or offer for sale any marijuana or any product containing marijuana, which shall include but not be limited to extracts, by-products and vapors, in or upon the property of any public or private primary or secondary school, daycare center or governmental building. 
(g)  Except as otherwise specified herein, any person who fails to comply with any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine as specified in Chapter 1, Article IV of this Code. 
(Ord. 17, 2009; Ord. 08 §1, 2014) 
Sec. 10-28. - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  Drug paraphernalia determination, considerations. In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court, in its discretion, may consider, in addition to all other relevant factors, the following: 
(1)  Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use. 
(2)  The proximity of the object to controlled substances. 
(3)  The existence of any residue or controlled substances on the object. 
(4)  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the knowledge of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, or evidence that such person reasonably should know that it will be delivered to persons who such person knows or reasonably should know could use the object to facilitate a violation of this section. 
(5)  Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use. 
(6)  Descriptive materials accompanying the object that explain or depict its use. 
(7)  National or local advertising concerning its use. 
(8)  The manner in which the object is displayed for sale. 
(9)  Whether the owner, or anyone in control of the object, is a supplier of like or related items to the community for legal purposes, such as an authorized distributor or dealer of tobacco products. 
(10)  The existence and scope of legal uses for the object in the community. 
(11)  Expert testimony concerning its use. 
(b)  Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to possess any drug paraphernalia if such person knows or reasonably should have known that the drug paraphernalia could be used in a manner which would violate the laws of this State or of this Town. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person who fails to comply with any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine as specified in Chapter 1, Article IV of this Code. 
(Ord. 14 §1, 1998; Ord. 17, 2009; Ord. 09 §1, 2014) 
Sec. 10-29. - Curfew. 
(a)  Child's responsibility. It is unlawful for any child under the age of eighteen (18) years to remain or loiter, including being in a vehicle that is moving or stationary, in or upon any street, alley or other public place subsequent to the hour of 12:01 a.m., or prior to the hour of 6:00 a.m., except for lawful employment or unless there exists a reasonable necessity thereof; or unless such child is accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or other person of the age of twenty-one (21) years having the permission of the parent or legal guardian to have the custody and care of such child. 
(b)  Parent's responsibility. It is unlawful for any parent, legal guardian or other person having the care or custody of any child under the age of eighteen (18) years, to allow or permit such child to remain or loiter, including being in a vehicle that is moving or stationary, in or upon any street, alley or other public place subsequent to the hour of 12:01 a.m., or prior to the hour of 6:00 a.m., except for lawful employment or unless there exists a reasonable necessity thereof; or unless such child is accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or other person of the age of twenty-one (21) years having permission of the parent or legal guardian to have the custody and care of such child. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating this Section shall be punished as set forth in Chapter 1, Article IV, Section 1-82 (adults) or 1-83 (minors) of this Code. 
(Ord. 15 §1, 1998) 
Secs. 10-30-10-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Offenses Relating to Alcoholic Beverages 

Sec. 10-41. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Drink or consume, or permit the drinking or consumption of, any alcoholic beverage as defined by Section 12-47-102, C.R.S., or any fermented malt beverage, as defined by Section 12-46-102, C.R.S., in or about any street, alley, road, highway, sidewalk, automobile parking lot, store or other public place that does not have a liquor license, or inside vehicles while upon streets, alleys, roads, highways or automobile parking lots. 
(2)  Have in his or her possession any open container containing any alcoholic beverage as defined by Section 12-47-102, C.R.S., or any fermented malt beverage, as defined by Section 12-46-102, C.R.S., in or about any street, alley, road, highway, sidewalk, automobile parking lot, store or other public place that does not have a liquor license or inside vehicles while upon streets, alleys, roads, highways or automobile parking lots. 
(Prior code 18-1) 
Sec. 10-42. - Nonapplicability. 
    The above provisions shall not apply to Town parks, and they shall not apply to the designated section of the Town and for the designated period of time as set forth in any permit issued by the Town Council pursuant to the provisions of Section 10-43 of this Code. 
(Prior code 18-2; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 10-43. - Permit for public consumption. 
    Upon application by any person, group or organization, the Town Council may issue a permit allowing the consumption of any beverage described in Section 10-41 of this Code and allowing the possession of any open container of any beverage described in Section 10-41 of this Code within a designated section of the Town and during a designated period of time. The Town Council may issue such a permit only if it finds that the applicant is qualified under state law, a responsible person, group or organization and is sponsoring a specific public event that will promote the Town or its business and commerce or that will contribute to the amusement and entertainment of its citizens and visitors. 
(Prior code 18-3; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 10-44. - Restrictions and exceptions in force after 9:30 p.m. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or operator, or agent or employee of any licensee or operator, of any establishment selling alcoholic beverages for on-the-premises consumption to allow or permit any person under the age of twenty-one (21) to enter or remain in such establishment after 9:30 p.m., or for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) to enter or remain in such establishment after 9:30 p.m. except: 
(1)  Persons under twenty-one (21) may remain in a dining room where meals are served and sold, where not more than twenty-five percent (25%) of the gross income generated within such dining room results from the sale of alcoholic beverages, where the sale of alcoholic beverages is incidental to the sale and consumption of food and where such dining room is physically separated, by walls or other means, from the bar. 
(2)  Persons under twenty-one (21) may pass through a bar for purposes of obtaining access to a dining room or rest room. 
(3)  Persons over the age of eighteen (18) years may sell or dispense malt liquors or vinous liquors in a bar of an establishment licensed to sell or dispense malt liquors or vinous liquors but not licensed to sell spirituous liquors. 
(4)  Persons under the age of twenty-one (21) may enter or remain in a bar when the establishment is closed and alcoholic beverages are not being sold. 
(Prior code 18-5) 
Sec. 10-45. - Restrictions and exceptions in force before 9:30 p.m. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or proprietor, or agent or employee of any licensee or operator, of any establishment selling alcoholic beverages for on-the-premises consumption to allow or permit any person under the age of twenty-one (21) to enter or remain in such establishment from the time the establishment opens for business until 9:30 p.m., or for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) to enter or remain in such establishment during such times, unless: 
(1)  The person under twenty-one (21) is accompanied and supervised by his or her parent, legal guardian or an adult over the age of twenty-one (21) who expressly assumes responsibility and liability for the acts of the person under twenty-one (21); 
(2)  The person under twenty-one (21) is lawfully engaged in selling or dispensing malt liquors or vinous liquors in a bar of an establishment licensed to sell or dispense malt liquors or vinous liquors, but not licensed to sell spirituous liquors; or 
(3)  The bar of the establishment is closed and alcoholic beverages are not being served. 
(Prior code 18-6) 
Sec. 10-46. - Display of warning card. 
    Every proprietor of an establishment selling alcoholic beverages for on-the-premises consumption shall display at all times in a prominent place a printed card with a minimum height of eighteen (18) inches and a minimum width of eleven (11) inches, with each letter a minimum of one-half (1/2) inch in height, giving notice of the prohibitions of this Article concerning persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years in said establishment. The failure to post such sign shall not be a defense in any prosecution against a person charged with being under the age of twenty-one (21) and unlawfully entering or remaining in an establishment selling alcoholic beverages for on-the-premises consumption. 
(Prior code 18-7) 
Sec. 10-47. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-48. - Unlawful possession of alcoholic beverages by a minor. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Alcoholic beverages or alcoholic liquors means malt, vinous or spirituous liquors; except that alcoholic beverages and alcoholic liquors shall not include confectionery containing alcohol within the limits prescribed by Section 25-5-410(1)(I)(II), C.R.S., which section is incorporated herein by this reference. 
    Fermented malt beverage means any beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any similar product, or any combination thereof, in water containing not less than one-half of one percent (.5%) and not more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol by weight; except that fermented malt beverage shall not include confectionery containing alcohol within the limits prescribed by Section 25-5-410(1)(I)(II), C.R.S., which section is incorporated herein by this reference. 
    Malt liquors includes beer and shall be construed to mean any beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar product, or any combination thereof, in water containing more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol by weight. 
    Spirituous liquors means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation, mixed with water and other substances in solution, and includes among other things brandy, rum, whiskey, gin and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing at least one-half of one percent (.5%) alcohol and which is fit for use for beverage purposes. 
    Vinous liquors means wine and fortified wines which contain not less than one-half of one percent (.5%) and not more than twenty-one percent (21%) alcohol by volume and shall be construed to mean alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural sugar contents of fruits or other agricultural products containing sugar. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to possess one (1) or more alcoholic beverages, malt liquors, vinous liquors and/or spirituous liquors, as such terms are defined herein or to possess fermented malt beverages as such term is defined herein, in a public place including public streets, alleys, roads or highways; upon property owned by a public or governmental entity, or any subdivision thereof, including the Town; or inside vehicles while upon the public streets, alleys, roads or highways. A person convicted of a violation of this Section shall be punished as set forth in Chapter 1, Article IV of this Code, Section 1-82 and 1-83. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 1998) 
Secs. 10-49-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Offenses Relating to Firearms 

Sec. 10-61. - Unlawful discharge of firearms. 
(a)  For purposes of this Section, the term firearm shall include any gun, pistol, rifle, shotgun, fowling piece, cannon, spring-operated device or any other device designed or used to propel projectiles in a dangerous manner, including but not limited to BB and pellet guns of any description. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm within the Town. 
(c)  This Section shall in no event be applied to the discharge of a firearm relating to: 
(1)  The carrying out of the duty of any authorized peace officer. 
(2)  The activities of any military exercise under the direction of an officer in any branch of the United States Armed Forces, active or reserve, or the activities of any recognized militia organized under and authorized by the laws of the United States or the State. 
(3)  The recreational activities of any firing or target range validly operating under all appropriate federal, state and local laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(4)  Any activity for which the Mayor has given written permission in behalf of the Town ten (10) days in advance, including but not limited to military parades and funerals. 
(5)  The self-defense of any person or the defense of a person's home from attack. 
(d)  This Section is not intended in any way to disturb or prevent the operation of legitimate and duly licensed businesses dealing in firearms, including but not limited to sporting goods stores, gunsmiths and pawnbrokers. 
(Prior code 20-1) 
Sec. 10-62. - Unlawful carrying of concealed weapons. 
(a)  For purpose of this Article, the term weapon shall include any firearm as defined in Section 10-61(a) above and any knife, switchblade, stiletto or gravity knife, bowie knife, dirk, dagger, razor, axe, slingshot, stone, bludgeon, club, blackjack, billy, metal knuckles or any other device designed or used to inflict bodily harm. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or have concealed upon or about his or her person any weapon or to exhibit any weapon in a rude, angry or threatening manner. 
(c)  This Section shall in no event be applied to weapons carried by: 
(1)  A peace officer in the performance of official duty. 
(2)  A person duly licensed to carry a weapon concealed on his or her person. 
(3)  A person in his or her house, dwelling or other area or premises to which he or she is entitled to exclusive possession unless such premises are open to the public. 
(Prior code 20-2) 
Secs. 10-63-10-80. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 11 - Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property 
ARTICLE I - General Provisions 

Sec. 11-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Sidewalk means that portion of the street which is set aside for the use of pedestrians and which has been surfaced with cement, stone or other similar material. 
    Street means the entire width of every dedicated public way, and includes the traveled portion thereof, known as the "roadway," the portion used for sidewalks and the portion between the property line and the roadway, known as the "parking." The term also includes an alley. 
(Prior code 55-1) 
Sec. 11-2. - Grade determination. 
(a)  For the purpose of establishing uniformity in the construction of streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, as well as to provide suitable surface drawings of the Town streets, it shall be the duty of the Town Council to cause the several streets to be surveyed to determine the grades for streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, and to establish said grades by ordinance. 
(b)  Until such time as the Town establishes grades by ordinance, the Town Manager shall establish the grades and lines of all streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to construct any sidewalk, curb or gutter upon any grade or line other than the one furnished by the Town Manager or by the Town Council. 
(Prior code 55-2; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-3. - Civil liability imposed on owners or occupants of land abutting sidewalks, curbs or gutters. 
    The owner or occupant of any parcel of land within the geographical boundaries of the Town which abuts a sidewalk, curb or gutter shall be subject to civil liability for injuries caused by his or her failure to repair, maintain or remove accumulations of ice and snow from such sidewalk, curb or gutter in violation of this Code. 
(Prior code 55-3.5) 
Sec. 11-4. - Public Works Manual. 
    The Public Works Department shall prepare and provide for approval of the Town Council by ordinance a Public Works Manual establishing technical standards and specifications for improvements in or affecting public areas, improvements to be dedicated to the public and improvements connected to public systems. Such Public Works Manual may be amended from time to time by ordinance of the Town Council on recommendation from the Public Works Department. The Public Works Department will be responsible for enforcement of the Public Works Manual. A copy of the Public Works Manual shall be available on request at Town Hall or from the Public Works Department to all members of the public on payment of a reasonable fee established by the Town. 
(Ord. 28 §2, 2004) 
Secs. 11-5-11-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Sidewalk Construction and Repair 

Sec. 11-21. - Construction required; permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lay out, construct or reconstruct any sidewalk, curb or gutter without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Prior code 55-4; Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 11-22. - Application for permit; designation of grade and line. 
(a)  Application for the permit required shall be made to the Town Manager on a form furnished for that purpose. 
(b)  Before any construction or reconstruction is commenced, the Town Manager shall designate the grade upon which, and the line or location at which, the sidewalk, curb or gutter shall be constructed. 
(Prior code 55-5; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-23. - Specifications. 
    All sidewalks, curbs and gutters which are constructed or reconstructed shall be of concrete and shall be constructed or reconstructed in accordance with the specifications adopted by the Town Council and filed in the office of the Town Clerk. All sidewalks within the incorporated limits of the Town shall be of a uniform width of five (5) feet, except where the Town Manager specifies a different width, with the approval of the Town Council. 
(Prior code 55-6; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-24. - Maintenance and repair. 
    All sidewalks, curbs and gutters shall be maintained with an even surface, in good repair and in conformity with the established grade of the streets along which they are constructed. All sidewalks shall be repaired with concrete. 
(Prior code 55-7) 
Sec. 11-25. - Town Council order for construction or repair. 
    The Town Council, when it deems it necessary that a portion of a sidewalk, curb or gutter be constructed or repaired, may on its own motion order the same to be done. 
(Prior code 55-8; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-26. - Notice to property owner. 
(a)  An order of the Town Council for construction or repair of a sidewalk, curb or gutter, by resolution duly adopted, shall be directed to the Town Manager. 
(b)  The Town Manager shall serve notice by certified mail upon the owner or owners of the property adjacent to or abutting the sidewalk, curb or gutter ordered improved to make such construction or repair as ordered within thirty (30) days from the date of registering the notice for mailing. Such construction or repair shall conform with plans and specifications to be prepared by the Town Manager. 
(c)  The notice shall be in the form on file in the office of the Town Clerk, for use and examination by the public. 
(d)  Any failure by the Town, Town Council or Town Manager to serve the notice required by this Section shall not absolve the owner or occupant of land abutting the sidewalk, curb or gutter to be repaired from civil liability for injuries caused by the landowner's or occupant's failure to maintain or repair said sidewalk, curb or gutter, in accordance with Sections 11-3, 11-24, and 11-95. 
(Prior code 55-9; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-27. - Failure to comply with notice. 
    The Town Manager shall forthwith report to the Town Council any owner or owners of property adjacent to or abutting the sidewalk, curb and gutter ordered improved who have failed, refused or neglected to comply with the notice to construct or repair the sidewalk, curb and gutter. The Town Council may thereupon, by resolution duly adopted, order the construction or repair to be done by contract to the lowest responsible bidder on open bids, after ample advertisement. 
(Prior code 55-10; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-28. - Assessment of costs. 
    The cost of any improvement ordered by the Town Council shall be assessed against the owner or owners of adjacent or abutting property. Where such cost has not been paid within thirty (30) days after completion, notice of completion having been given by certified mail to said owners by the Town Clerk, the Town Clerk shall certify said assessment to the Treasurer of Eagle or Pitkin County, as the case may be, who shall extend the assessment upon the tax roll and collect the same in the same manner as other taxes assessed upon said property. 
(Prior code 55-11; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-29. - Inspection. 
    The Town Manager shall have the right to assign an inspector to check on any and all work performed under a permit issued for sidewalk, curb, gutter and driveway construction, including preparation of the base, condition and type of forms, etc., to be used, materials to be incorporated in the work and construction methods and practices. Inspectors shall be assigned to call the attention of contractors to infringements of these instructions, and they shall have authority to reject defective materials and workmanship and to stop work until such time as the contractor corrects the situation in question, subject to the final decision of the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 55-12; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-30. - Contractor to furnish inspection facilities. 
    The contractor shall furnish the inspector with all reasonable facilities and assistance necessary for the proper inspection of materials to be used and construction methods to determine compliance with these instructions. 
(Prior code 55-13) 
Sec. 11-31. - Rejection of materials and work. 
    Whenever the inspector finds it necessary to reject materials or defective work, the contractor shall promptly remove such rejected materials and defective construction from the site. In the event that the contractor fails to remove rejected items promptly, the Town Manager may arrange for such removal at the expense of the contractor. 
(Prior code 55-14; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-32. - Curb cuts. 
    At curb cuts, the contractor shall remove as much of the curb and gutter as necessary to permit proper construction of the driveway entrance and maintenance of the gutter. Removed materials shall be removed from the site by the contractor. New construction shall conform with plans as prescribed by the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 55-15; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-33. - Power line poles. 
    Whenever power line poles are located within the limits of proposed construction, the office of the Town Manager shall be so advised by the contractor at the time application is made for a permit. Arrangements will then be made for relocating such poles outside the area to be concreted, if relocation is feasible. Concrete shall not be placed at pole locations until they have been moved or until the Town Manager advises the contractor it is satisfactory to proceed without the poles being moved. 
(Prior code 55-17; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-34. - Trees. 
    When trees are located within the area to be concreted, and approval is given by the Town Manager for such trees to be left in place, an open space eighteen (18) inches wide shall be left around each tree. It will not be necessary to leave eighteen (18) inches of open space between a tree and the edge of a walk extending along only one (1) side of a tree. 
(Prior code 55-18) 
Sec. 11-35. - Water stop boxes. 
    Water stop boxes located within areas to be concreted shall be adjusted by the contractor to be flush with the surface of the finished concrete. 
(Prior code 55-19) 
Sec. 11-36. - Duty of property owner to prune or remove trees or shrubs; notice. 
(a)  The Town's right-of-way landscape policy is necessary to ensure that street trees planted on public property are consistent with the Town's landscaping standards, in the interest of public safety, and to preserve public welfare. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the property owner to cut, trim, prune or remove as necessary any trees or shrubs located upon the property of such owner in order to provide for the safe and convenient use of streets, sidewalks, alleys or other Town-owned property in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Tree branch growth must be maintained at a height no lower than eight (8) feet over a public sidewalk and not less than fourteen (14) feet over the travel lanes of a street or alley. 
(2)  Branches, trees and shrubs must not obscure street name signs. 
(3)  Branches or trees that are broken, hanging, decayed or otherwise defective in any way that threatens public property or the safe use thereof must be removed. It shall be the duty of the Town to do any cutting, trimming, pruning or removing of trees and shrubs necessary for the safe use of Town utilities or Town traffic-control devices and signs, with the exception of street name signs. 
(c)  Except where properties are subject to a site specific land use review, prior to any planting which will be within the Town's rights-of-way, the Public Works Director and the Town Planner shall review and approve landscape plans and/or proposals. Plan submittal and approval shall be part of any development review process or in direct response to a proposal to modify or add new landscaping to existing rights of way. Following submittal of plans, the Public Works Director may request additional information, plans, details and specifications as necessary to review the proposal. 
(d)  Should a property owner fail to maintain trees and shrubs in the manner required by Subsection (a) of this Section, the Public Works Director shall follow these enforcement guidelines: 
(1)  First contact : Notification by personal visit or phone to the property owner requesting compliance with the requirements in this Section. The property owner will be given fourteen (14) days to come into compliance. In the event that the property owner cannot be reached by personal visit or phone, the Public Works Department, after first making this attempt, shall send a letter to the property owner requesting compliance. 
(2)  Additional contact : If compliance is not completed within the above fourteen (14) days of first contact as described in Paragraph (1) above, the Public Works Department shall recontact the property owner by personal visit, phone or letter reminding him or her of the Town's regulations related to landscaping adjacent to the right-of-way and asking him or her to comply within the next seven (7) days. 
(3)  Notice of violation : If compliance is not completed within the time period allotted in Paragraph (2) above, the Public Works Department shall send a certified letter to the property owner reminding him or her of the Town's regulations related to landscaping adjacent to the right-of-way and requiring compliance within two (2) business days and identifying penalties for noncompliance as set forth in Section 1-82 of this Code. The Town Manager can extend the compliance time period if it is determined at the sole discretion of the Town Manager that there are special circumstances. By way of an example, special circumstances may include, but are not limited to, a property owner not being able to be contacted. 
(Ord. 11 §4, 2011) 
Secs. 11-37-11-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Excavations 

Sec. 11-51. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig up, open or excavate, or cause to be dug up, opened or excavated, any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place within the incorporated limits of the Town without first having secured a permit therefor from the Town Manager or his or her authorized representative. 
(Prior code 55-20) 
Sec. 11-52. - Application. 
    Application for a permit to excavate, required by this Section, shall be made upon a blank form provided by the Town Manager or his or her authorized representative. The application shall recite specifically and illustrate by sketch or plan the exact location, depth, extent, nature and purpose of the excavation desired to be made, the purpose for which the privilege is requested and the duration of time required for the work. 
(Prior code 55-21) 
Sec. 11-53. - Excavation permit fees. 
    No permit to excavate in any street or alley shall be issued unless the applicant for such permit has first paid to the Town the required fee for any minimum excavation, excavation in asphalt or concrete, excavation in gravel or excavation in dirt in amounts as approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. However, utility companies franchised in the Town registered with the Public Utilities Commission shall not be required to pay the excavation fee and may substitute the deposit with a bond, letter of credit or some other method of security approved by the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 55-22; Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 12 §B33, 2003) 
Sec. 11-54. - Issuance of permits. 
    The Town Manager shall grant permits to dig up, open or excavate, or cause to be dug up, opened or excavated, any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the Town to the following persons: 
(1)  Any person possessing, by ordinance, resolution or contract of the Town Council, general or special power to excavate in, or perform other work as aforesaid in or upon, the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places. 
(2)  Any person properly licensed under the provisions of this Code filing an application, as provided for, pertaining to excavation work which will comply with the requirements stated herein. 
(Prior code 55-23; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-55. - Permit to be available for inspection. 
    The permit required shall be kept at the site of the excavation while the work is in progress and shall be exhibited upon request to any police officer or other authorized representative of the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 55-24; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-56. - Compliance with time limit and method restrictions. 
    All permits issued under this Article shall be issued according to the provisions stated and subject to such rules, directions and limitations as the Town Manager prescribes regarding the time required for the work and the manner in which the work is to be performed. 
(Prior code 55-25; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-57. - Protection of public places. 
    Permits shall be conditioned that all work performed under such permits shall be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Town Manager, which rules shall provide for the proper care and protection of the streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public places of the Town and persons and property thereupon. 
(Prior code 55-26; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-58. - Compliance with specifications. 
    Permits shall be conditioned that all work done under such permits shall be only such work as is allowed by the Town and specified in the ordinance, resolution or contract of the Town Manager, or in the proper application. 
(Prior code 55-27; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-59. - Records to be kept. 
    The Town Manager shall keep a record of all applications made for excavation permits and of the permits issued. 
(Prior code 55-28; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-60. - License and insurance required. 
    All permittees must be licensed pursuant to this Code and must provide the insurance required. 
(Prior code 55-29) 
Sec. 11-61. - Time and space limitations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to obstruct more than the space of one (1) block and one (1) intersection at the same time in any one (1) street, or to keep the same blocked for more than three (3) days. 
(b)  In the event of unforeseen extenuating circumstances, an applicant may apply for an extension of the three (3) day limitation. The Town Manager or his or her authorized representative, after investigation of the extenuating circumstances, may grant such extension provided that valid reasons and circumstances exist and justify the extension. 
(c)  One (1) lane of traffic must remain open at all times unless prior approval is granted by the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 55-30; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-62. - Barricades and warning lights. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or cause to be dug any hole, drain, ditch or any other excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place within the Town without providing sufficient warning lights during the nighttime, to be placed with a suitable barricade or temporary fence around such hole, drain, ditch or other excavation, in order to prevent persons, animals and vehicles from sustaining injury or damage. 
(b)  During the daytime, the barricade shall be maintained, but warning lights are not required. 
(Prior code 55-31) 
Sec. 11-63. - Traffic safety appliances. 
    Every excavation shall be protected at all times by traffic safety appliances, as prescribed by the Town Manager, in order to minimize the disruption of the flow of traffic in the vicinity of the excavation. 
(Prior code 55-32; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-64. - Interference with safety devices. 
    It shall be unlawful to damage, displace, remove or interfere with any barricade, warning light or any other safety appliance which is lawfully placed around or about any street, alley, sidewalk or other excavation or construction work in the Town. 
(Prior code 55-33) 
Sec. 11-65. - Cuts; disposal of excess material. 
    Any cut in any pavement or surfacing shall be made in a neat manner, with square edges and corners, and shall be made with a pavement saw six (6) inches back from each side of the excavation. All excess material taken from the cut and excavation shall be trucked away and disposed of by the holder of the permit at the time the cut and excavation are made. 
(Prior code 55-34) 
Sec. 11-66. - Backfilling. 
    Upon completion of the work, each excavator shall backfill excavations as required herein. Backfill of any excavation made in any paved street or alley right-of-way shall conform to the conditions set out in this Code. 
(Prior code 55-35) 
Sec. 11-67. - Backfill material to be compacted. 
    Backfill material shall be placed in lifts not to exceed six (6) inches in depth by loose measurement, moistened as required and mechanically compacted to a minimum of ninety-five percent (95%) of the maximum density, to be tested and accepted by the Town Manager or his or her authorized representative. 
(Prior code 55-36; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-68. - Material for backfilling. 
(a)  All excavated material shall be removed, and backfill shall be of select material meeting the specifications established by the Town Manager. A sample of material to be used for backfill must be supplied to the Town Manager before the backfill is to be made, and such material shall have received previous approval of the Town Manager. 
(b)  In streets and alleys paved with concrete or asphalt, the top twelve (12) inches of the backfill shall be made with crushed gravel three-fourths (3/4) inch or less in diameter. In gravel streets and alleys, the top eight (8) inches of the backfill shall be made with crushed gravel three-fourths (3/4) inch or less in diameter. 
(Prior code 55-37; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-69. - Modifications. 
    The plans and specifications set out herein may be modified by the Town Manager so that they may be specifically adapted to the particular conditions of travel, load requirements, terrain, subsoil and moisture where the backfill is to be effected. 
(Prior code 55-38; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-70. - Responsibility for repair. 
    In the event of settlement or subsidence of a particular excavation or part of an excavation, the permittee who had performed the excavation work shall be responsible for all repaving and repair costs occasioned by such settlement or subsidence. 
(Prior code 55-39) 
Sec. 11-71. - Pavement or surfacing replacement. 
(a)  After an excavation in a street, alley or sidewalk, pavement and surfacing shall be replaced by the contractor in accordance with specifications provided by the Town Manager's office. 
(b)  If within the time specified in Section 11-56 the work is not completed, the Town will cause the work to be done and bill the contractor responsible. 
(Prior code 55-40; Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-72. - Surfacing material to be separated from soil. 
    Excavators in paved or hard-topped streets shall take care to separate surfacing material from the soil removed from such excavation. 
(Prior code 55-41) 
Sec. 11-73. - Obstruction of excavations prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to hinder or obstruct any paving operations or excavations conducted in conformance with the provisions of this Article. 
(Prior code 55-42) 
Sec. 11-74. - Liability. 
    Any person who undertakes work pursuant to a permit issued under the provisions of this Article or performs work under contract with the Town or by permission obtained from the Town Council in accordance with provisions adopted by the Town Council shall be answerable for any damage occasioned to persons, animals or property by reason of carelessness or negligence connected with such work. 
(Prior code 55-43; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-75. - Furnishing of information. 
    It shall be the duty of every person, on request, to furnish the Town Manager with information regarding the location in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place of the Town of any pipe or other structure installed, maintained or utilized by such person. 
(Prior code 55-44; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Secs. 11-76-11-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Encroachments 

Sec. 11-91. - Unlawful obstructions and improvements. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this Code, it shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct a street or sidewalk with any debris, lumber, sand, gravel, dirt, abandoned or wrecked automobile or other material or substance without having first obtained a written permit from the Public Works Director. Such permit may be granted only where the obstruction is necessary for the construction, alteration or repair of the adjoining property, and such permitted obstructions shall be limited to as short a time as is reasonably possible. Each day that an unlawful obstruction is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to plant any tree or shrub within the public rights-of-way of any street or upon other Town-owned property within the Town without having first obtained written approval from the Public Works Director. 
(Prior code 55-45; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 11 §5, 2011) 
Sec. 11-92. - Walkways required. 
    Whenever in the construction, rebuilding or repairing of any building it becomes necessary to blockade, obstruct or remove the sidewalk, the person in charge of such work shall build and maintain a good and substantial walkway around the obstructed portion of such sidewalk, to be approved by the Town Manager. 
(Prior code 55-46; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-93. - Ditches to be bridged. 
    Any person owning or constructing any ditch, race, drain or flume in, upon or across any public street within the Town shall keep the same open for safe and convenient travel by constructing bridges over the same. Such bridges shall be of substantial construction and shall cover the full width of the street. After such construction, the owner thereof shall keep the same in good condition and repair. 
(Prior code 55-47) 
Sec. 11-94. - Excavations to be fenced. 
    All holes, depressions, excavations or other dangerous places within the Town that are below the natural or artificial grades of the surrounding or adjacent highway or street shall be properly enclosed with fences or walls, or filled up, so as to prevent persons and animals from falling into them. The Town Manager shall notify the owner or occupant of premises on which such dangerous places exist to cause fences or walls to be built around them or to cause the same to be filled up. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant so notified to fail to comply with such notification forthwith. 
(Prior code 55-48; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-95. - Removal of snow or ice. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any lot, block or parcel of ground within the Town, or any agent in charge of such property, to allow any snow or ice to accumulate or remain upon any sidewalk alongside such property longer than twenty-four (24) hours from the time of the last accretion of such snow and ice. 
(Prior code 55-49) 
Secs. 11-96-11-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Use Restrictions 

Sec. 11-111. - Injury to streets and sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, cut, mutilate, destroy or deface any street, sidewalk, curb or gutter, the paving or other surface thereof, the trees or plants located therein or any property maintained or used in connection therewith. 
(Prior code 55-50) 
Sec. 11-112. - Littering prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in or litter any street with ashes, sod, earth, grass clippings, sand, gravel, rubbish, wastepaper, garbage or any other waste material. 
(Prior code 55-51) 
Sec. 11-113. - Certain tires prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or move upon any surfaced street in the Town any vehicles equipped with metal or solid rubber tires, or tires which have any flange, cleat, spike or other protuberances of any material other than rubber, except for studded snow tires which meet all requirements set forth by the State. 
(Prior code 55-52) 
Sec. 11-114. - Moving of buildings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any building or the contractor for its removal, or either of them, to move any building over the streets of the Town without first obtaining a permit therefor from the Town Manager. 
(b)  In granting such a permit, the Town Manager may impose such restrictions or conditions as he or she deems necessary to protect the streets of the Town or any utilities from damage, and he or she may make any other responsible requirements which he or she or she deems necessary for the protection of the public. 
(Prior code 55-53; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-115. - Camping or lodging on property without consent. 
(a)  No person shall camp within any park, parkway, recreation area, open space or other Town property without prior authorization of the Town. 
(b)  No person shall camp within any public property other than Town property or any private property without first having obtained: 
(1)  Permission of the authorized officer of such public property; or 
(2)  Permission of the owner of private property. 
(c)  This section does not apply to any dwelling in the Town, as defined Section 16-4 of the Code. 
(d)  For purposes of this section "camp" means to reside or dwell temporarily in a place, with shelter, and conduct activities of daily living, such as eating or sleeping, in such place, but the term does not include napping during the day or picnicking. The term "shelter" includes, without limitation, any cover or protection from the elements other than clothing. The phrase "during the day" means from one (1) hour after sunrise until sunset. 
(e)  Testimony by an agent of the persons specified in subsection (b) of this section that such agent is the person who grants permission to camp or lodge upon such property, or that in the course of such agent's duties such. agent would be aware of permission and that no such permission was given, is prima facie evidence of that fact. 
(f)  Any person who fails to comply with any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine as specified in Chapter 1, Article IV of this Code. 
( Ord. 10 § 1, 2014) 
Sec. 11-116. - Unlawful use of vehicles as residence. 
    No person shall occupy a vehicle upon any Town street or streets or other public property if any of the purposes for such occupation is to use the vehicle as a permanent or temporary residence, The general penalty provisions of Chapter 1, Article IV shall apply to this section. 
( Ord. 10 § 1, 2014) 
Secs. 11-117-11-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI - Roadway Names and House Numbers 

Sec. 11-131. - Adoption of procedure. 
    The procedure set out in this Article is for the naming of streets and the numbering of houses within the Town limits and new additions to the Town. 
(Prior code 55-54) 
Sec. 11-132. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this roadway-naming and house-numbering plan is to provide an orderly and contiguous pattern throughout the Town and to enable particular roadways and houses to be found as quickly as possible. 
(Prior code 55-55) 
Sec. 11-133. - Review of roadway names; assignment of numbers. 
    Plats of new subdivisions shall be reviewed by the Town Manager or his or her representative in order to avoid duplication of roadway names. House numbers in the Town shall be assigned by the Building Inspection Department as building permits are issued, or upon demand. 
(Prior code 55-56; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-134. - Naming of roadways. 
    Roadways shall be named in accordance with the following guidelines: 
(1)  All roadway designations shall be approved by the Town Manager. 
(2)  Interrupted roadways that are in alignment with streets in other parts of the Town shall have the same name. 
(3)  Roadway names shall not be duplicated in the Town. 
(4)  Roadway signs shall be readable from each direction of travel. 
(5)  Temporary signs are required during construction periods. 
(Prior code 55-57; Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-135. - Numbering of houses. 
    Houses shall be numbered according to the following guidelines: 
(1)  Odd numbers shall be on the south and east sides of roadways, with even numbers on the north and west sides. 
(2)  Numbers should not be duplicated for five (5) blocks. (For example, first house - 501; next street, first house - 503; next street, first house - 505, 507, etc.). 
(3)  House numbers shall be readable from the roadway, particularly at night. 
(4)  All new developments and numbering systems shall be submitted to the Town Manager for approval prior to recording of the final plat. 
(Prior code 55-58; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Secs. 11-136-11-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII - Cemeteries 

Sec. 11-151. - Cemetery created; recording. 
    There is hereby created a municipal cemetery, consisting of land owned by the Town, to be known and designated as the "Basalt Fairview Cemetery," to be used and sold for the burial and interment of bodies. The Town has caused the Basalt Fairview Cemetery to be surveyed by Alonzo H. Adams, a registered land surveyor, and the map is hereby accepted and declared to be the official map and plat of the Basalt Fairview Cemetery. The Town Clerk is hereby authorized to cause the plat to be recorded in the Clerk and Recorder's office of Pitkin County, and a copy of the plat shall be filed in the office of the Town Clerk. The Town Council may, from time to time, by resolution, provide for additions to the municipal cemetery, securing the platting or replatting thereof and the filing of such plats as required herein. Such added lands shall thereafter be subject to all the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Prior code 7-1; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-152. - Management. 
    The Town Manager shall be responsible for the management of the Town cemetery and shall delegate the duties involved in improvement, maintenance and operation thereof to the Chief of Maintenance. The Town Manager shall report to the Town Council the financial and physical status of the cemetery and shall incorporate in the proposed annual budget such allocation of funds as may be necessary for its proper management. The Town Council shall levy and appropriate for the cemetery the necessary funds in a manner consistent with all budgeting requirements. 
(Prior code 7-2; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-153. - Conveyance of lots. 
    Lots and grave plots shall be conveyed to the purchaser by a certificate of purchase, a copy of which shall be filed by the Town Clerk. 
(Prior code 7-3) 
Sec. 11-154. - Title subject to rules and regulations. 
    All lots and grave plots in the Town cemetery shall be held in accordance with and subject to the rules, regulations and ordinances of the Town and the laws of the State. 
(Prior code 7-4) 
Sec. 11-155. - Duties of Town Clerk. 
    The Town Clerk shall keep and have custody of all books and records pertaining to the cemetery, shall issue all permits for burial, disinterment and removal of bodies in said cemetery and, with the Town Manager or Mayor, shall execute and issue, to those having paid therefor appropriate certificates of purchase of grave space in said cemetery, in such form as the Town Manager may determine and in compliance with the provisions of this Article and any and all rules and regulations made thereunder. 
(Prior code 7-5; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-156. - Fees and charges. 
    The Town Council shall request the Town Manager to report as conditions warrant on the income and expenses of the cemetery and shall adopt by resolution a schedule of prices for: 
(1)  Grave space. 
(2)  Opening and closing of graves. 
(Prior code 7-6; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-157. - Conditions of conveyance. 
    The rights, title and interest acquired by any person in and to any grave space in the Town cemetery shall be subject to any and all rules and regulations governing the cemetery as may, from time to time, be adopted by resolution of the Town Council. The Town shall not be liable for any injury or damage to any monument, marker or other structure in the cemetery resulting from any cause beyond its reasonable control. 
(Prior code 7-7; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-158. - Maintenance responsibilities. 
    The Town shall care for and maintain all roads, walks, pathways, grass, ground, shrubbery and improvements belonging to or appertaining to the Town cemetery; provided, however, that all lot or grave section owners are to maintain all monuments and markers erected on their lots or grave tracts. 
(Prior code 7-8) 
Sec. 11-159. - Prior purchase. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to affect or alter the rights of persons who, prior to the adoption of this Article, purchased grave spaces. The Town Clerk shall maintain a list of all such prior purchases. 
(Prior code 7-9) 
Secs. 11-160-11-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII - Skateboard Park 

Sec. 11-171. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Article is to regulate the use of the Skateboard Park through the implementation of rules and regulations and the imposition of penalties for the violation of such rules and regulations. 
(Ord. 11 §2, 2002) 
Sec. 11-172. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, certain words or phrases are defined as follows: 
    Skateboard shall mean skateboard, in-line skate and any other similar device approved by the Public Works Department for use in the Skateboard Park. Skateboard shall specifically not include bicycles or scooters. 
    Skateboard Park shall mean that portion within Gissela Fiou Park which has been set aside and dedicated for use by persons using skateboards and similar devices as defined hereinafter. 
(Ord. 11 §2, 2002) 
Sec. 11-173. - Rules and regulations. 
    The Public Works Department shall promulgate such rules for conduct and use of the Skateboard Park as the Public Works Department deems reasonably necessary to protect the safety and welfare of the public and the users of the Skateboard Park. A copy of such rules shall be posted at the Skateboard Park and available at Town Hall. Any person who believes a rule is unnecessary or unreasonable may request review of such rule by the Town Council, which shall consider the reasonableness and necessity of such rule at a regularly scheduled meeting. It shall be unlawful for any person within the Skateboard Park to violate any rule posted by the Public Works Department. The rules may include, but shall not be limited to, rules concerning: 
(1)  Devices which may be ridden, operated and used at the Skateboard Park. 
(2)  Requirements concerning wearing a helmet designed for use with a Skateboard. 
(3)  Placement or utilization of additional obstacles or other material (including, but not limited to ramps or jumps) that are not specifically authorized by the Public Works Department. 
(4)  Hours of operation. 
(5)  Use of alcohol, tobacco products or illegal drugs at the Skateboard Park. 
(6)  Use of or possession of glass containers, bottles or other breakable glass products at the Skateboard Park. 
(Ord. 11 §2, 2002; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 11-174. - Public Works Department to post regulations. 
    The Public Works Department shall post on or near the entrance to the Skateboard Park a sign that clearly summarizes the regulations promulgated by the Public Works Department as set forth in Section 11-173 above. The sign to be posted shall, at a minimum, include the following language: 
WELCOME   
  SKATEBOARD PARK 
This facility has been designed for use by skateboarders and in-line skaters. In order to provide a safe and enjoyable experience, the following warning and regulations have been posted. Please heed the warning and observe all regulations. 
WARNING 
Skateboarding is a hazardous recreational activity. Use of this facility may result in serious injury or death. The Town of Basalt does not assume any responsibility for injuries or death. Each person entering the facility assumes all risks associated with the use of this facility. 
The following rules and regulations have been adopted by the Town of Basalt to protect your safety. It is unlawful to violate these rules and regulations. Any person failing to follow these rules and regulations may be subject to eviction from the park and prosecution pursuant to Section 1-82 of the Basalt Municipal Code. 
SKATEBOARD PARK RULES 
1. USE THIS FACILITY AT YOUR OWN RISK. 
2. HELMETS ARE MANDATORY. 
3. BICYCLES AND SCOOTERS ARE PROHIBITED. 
4. ALCOHOL, TOBACCO AND DRUGS ARE PROHIBITED. 
5. HOURS OF OPERATION ARE 8:00 A.M. TO SUNSET. 
6. ADDING OR MODIFYING RAMPS IS PROHIBITED. 
7. BOTTLES AND GLASS CONTAINERS ARE PROHIBITED. 
8. RESPECT EACH OTHER AND PRIVATE PROPERTY. 
REPORT ALL INJURIES TO THE TOWN OF BASALT, TELEPHONE 927-4701. 
CALL 911 FOR ALL SERIOUS INJURIES OR OTHER MEDICAL EMERGENCIES. 
(Ord. 11 §2, 2002) 
Sec. 11-175. - Eviction. 
    Any person found to be in violation of this Article or a regulation duly posted on the sign required by Section 11-174 above shall be subject to eviction from the Skateboard Park. 
(Ord. 11 §2, 2002) 
Sec. 11-176. - Penalty. 
    The privilege of any person to use the Skateboard Park is expressly conditioned upon compliance by that person with the provisions of this Article. A violation of any provision of this Article may be punishable by a fine as provided by Section 1-82 of this Code. In addition, the person shall be subject to eviction (temporary or permanent) from the Skateboard Park. 
(Ord. 11 §2, 2002) 
Secs. 11-177-11-190. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 13 - Municipal Utilities 
ARTICLE I - Sewers 

Sec. 13-1. - Use of outside privies prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any building or other structure used for residence, business or other purposes within the Town to provide for said building or to maintain an outside or open closet, vault or privy to be used for the collection or disposal of sewage from said residence or premises. 
(Prior code 50-1) 
Sec. 13-2. - Use of individual sewage disposal devices in sewered areas prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct, reconstruct, repair, place or use any septic tank, cesspool, closet, toilet, pool, drain, ditch or other sewage disposal device in or near any residence or other building in the Town, to be used for the purpose of collecting, storing or disposing of sewage from such residence or other building, where such residence or other building shall be located within four hundred (400) feet of any public or district sanitary sewer or lateral. 
(Prior code 50-2) 
Secs. 13-3-13-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Water 

Sec. 13-21. - Creation of Water Department. 
    There is hereby created and established a Water Department of the Town for the purposes of the management, maintenance, care and operation of the water system of the Town. 
(Prior code 68-1) 
Sec. 13-22. - Superintendent of Water Department. 
    The Chairman of the Water Committee of the Town Council shall act as Superintendent of the Water Department until the Town Council authorizes another qualified person to fill the position. The Superintendent shall have the immediate control and management of all things pertaining to the water system, and he or she shall perform all acts that may be necessary for the prudent, efficient and economical management and protection of said water system, subject to the approval of the Town Council. The Town Council shall have the power, by motion or resolution, to promulgate rules and regulations relative to the water system of the Town. 
(Prior code 68-2; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 13-23. - Receipts and deposits. 
    The Finance Director shall keep a correct account of receipts, fees charged and materials furnished to users, and collect the same and deposit the proceeds so collected to the credit of the Water System Fund of the Town in accordance with the direction of the Town Council. 
(Prior code 68-3; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 13-24. - Inspections. 
    Any authorized representative of the Water Department shall have the right to enter any property or building where water furnished by the Town is used, for the purpose of making an inspection of pipes, fixtures or appliances and for the further purpose of detecting and eliminating any alteration, connection to or disconnection from meters, wasting of water, improper or unauthorized use of water facility, installation of pipes or fixtures or other improper use of water. Property owners shall make access available during regular working hours to Water Department personnel within fifteen (15) days of notification. Failure to comply shall result in a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) per quarter being added to owner's water bill and shall allow the Town to charge for the estimated usage of water, both at each billing period. 
(Prior code 68-4; Ord. 22 §1, 1991) 
Sec. 13-25. - Applications for water. 
(a)  Applications for the use of water shall be made to the Finance Director at his or her office. The application must be made by the owner or authorized agent of the property to be benefited, designating the location of the property and stating the purpose for which the water will be used. 
(b)  In furnishing water for any purpose, the Town shall not be responsible for the quality or quantity of water furnished. 
(Prior code 68-5; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 13-26. - Tap charges; fee for turning water on or off. 
(a)  No water service shall be furnished to a consumer until all tap fees and other applicable fees as required herein are paid to the Finance Director. No prepayment for tap fees shall be allowed until all other requirements for the issuance of a building permit have been satisfied. Effective June 1, 2002, and thereafter until amended, and no later than the issuance of a building permit, the applicant for each new water tap shall pay a system improvement fee of five thousand two hundred seventeen dollars ($5,217.00) for each single-family residence and, for buildings other than single-family residences, a fee computed at the rate of five thousand two hundred seventeen dollars ($5,217.00) per EQR, as calculated by reference to the EQR Schedule adopted pursuant to Section 2-381 of this Code. The EQR Schedule may be amended on a periodic basis by resolution of the Town Council. 
(b)  A charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be made for initiating water service or for terminating or suspending water service for any period. 
(c)  System Improvement Fees (EQRs), as provided for in Subsection (a) above, remain with the property, may not be sold apart from the property upon which the fees were originally paid, and are transferable only to contiguous properties under the same ownership, except upon written approval of the Town Council. 
(Prior code 68-6; Ord. 15 §1, 1992; Ord. 8 §1, 1994; Ord. 7 §2, 1997; Ord. 10 §2, 2001; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 6 §1, 2004) 
Sec. 13-27. - Costs to user; special fees. 
(a)  All necessary pipes, fittings, valves, shutoffs, trenching, backfilling and installation of the tap shall be provided at the expense of the user and under the supervision of the Superintendent. 
(b)  All water service connections and extensions, both within and without the corporate limits of the Town, are subject to special fees as shall be established by the Town Council. 
(Prior code 68-7; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 13-28. - Surcharge on certain water line taps and for the Southside Water Tank. 
(a)  Surcharge C. A surcharge of seven hundred dollars ($700.00) per EQR shall be paid to the Town for each water tap served by the water line extension which is connected to the Town water main at Fiou Lane and Southside Drive and which extends from that location to the site of the RE-1 Basalt High School. Said surcharge shall also apply to any property located south of Fiou Lane and within five hundred (500) feet of said water line extension. Said surcharge shall be designated as Surcharge C. Said Surcharge C shall be reviewed by the Town Council at such time as the Town has collected full reimbursement of funds expended for the construction of said water line extension plus six percent (6%) interest on those funds that would otherwise have been collecting interest for the Town. 
(b)  Surcharge WT. A Southside Water Tank surcharge shall be paid to the Town for each new water tap connected to the Town water system, to be designated as Surcharge WT, as set forth in the Water Fee Schedule adopted pursuant to Section 2-381 of this Code. Surcharge WT shall increase by five percent (5%) annually beginning January 1, 2010, and on each January 1 thereafter, unless such annual increase is suspended or modified by an ordinance of the Town Council. Surcharge WT shall be reviewed by the Town Council at such time as the Town has collected reimbursement of more than sixty percent (60%) of the actual funds expended for the construction of the water tank. 
(Prior code 68-7.5; Ord. 16 §1, 1992; Ord. 36 §1, 1996; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 18 §1, 2008) 
Sec. 13-29. - Size of service tap. 
    No service tap shall be larger than three-fourths (3/4) inch in diameter, unless special permission is given by resolution by the Town Council. 
(Prior code 68-8; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 13-30. - Plumbing standards; permit required.
