1 Final determination of required cul-de-sac right-of-way width shall be established by the Town Council subject to the following criteria: cul-de-sacs that serve residential areas, that allow for on-street parking or have the potential for future extensions are required to maintain a 50-foot right-of-way width consistent with a local street. (Prior code 57-25; Ord. 22 §1, 1991; Ord. 19 §1, 1994; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
____________ 
Sec. 17-37. - Alleys and easements. 
(a)  Alleys may be required in any subdivision. The minimum width of alleys shall be twenty (20) feet. 
(b)  Easements for utility purposes of a minimum of seven and one-half (71/2) feet may be required along any lot line and shall be depicted on the subdivision plat. If wider utility easements are required to serve the subdivision or to provide service to any other part of the Town, or both, easements in excess of seven and one-half (71/2) feet along lot lines may be required. Easements for drainage purposes shall be designed to accommodate expected runoff based on information submitted by or required to be submitted by the subdivider and on generally accepted engineering principles and specifications, and such drainage easements may be required anywhere within the subdivision or the lots therein. 
(Prior code 57-26) 
Sec. 17-38. - Street improvements. 
    All street improvements shall be in accordance with the design standards of this Article, the Town's road specifications and the provisions of Article V, Public Improvements Acceptance and Guaranties. 
(Prior code 57-27) 
Sec. 17-39. - Drainage easements, site grading and improvements. 
(a)  On slopes greater than ten percent (10%), slope stabilization and revegetation will be required. Plans shall include a description of existing vegetation to be removed, vegetation to be planted and other slope stabilization measures to be installed. New vegetation shall be selected and located so as to be compatible with surrounding vegetation, soil and ecological characteristics of the area. Criteria for cut and fill slopes are as follows: 
(1)  2:1 slope - generally steepest slopes allowed. 
(2)  11/2:1 slope - allowed in mountainous areas if the plan contains specific erosion control, matting, hydroseeding and/or irrigation measures. These specific measures must meet the approval of the Town Engineer and the Town Council. 
(3)  Less than 11/2:1 slope - not allowed under any circumstances. 
(b)  Slopes shall be finished to match or blend with the natural contours of adjacent terrain by rounding off sharp angles at the top, toe and sides of all cut and fill slopes. 
(c)  All trees over three (3) inches in diameter, measured at four (4) feet above grade, to be preserved shall be protected during grading operations and during construction by the placement of fencing outside of the drip line of the trees. 
(d)  A drainage plan shall be submitted which provides, in general, that, after development, stormwater runoff shall not be released at a greater rate than the historical rate for the ten-year storm, unless it can be shown to the satisfaction of the Town Engineer that a stormwater drainage system can be developed or exists to convey runoff to an acceptable site. The amount of runoff to be detained on site for those developments required to release runoff at the historic ten-year rate shall be the difference between the ten-year runoff under developed conditions and the ten-year historic runoff. Conveyance facilities for the development may be designed on the basis of the ten-year storm unless it is determined by the Town Engineer that there is a potential for damage or flooding of residences or other property. Further, conveyance facilities for arterial and collector streets and for existing watercourses and dry washes, and where potential damage to residences or other property exists as determined by the Town Engineer, shall be designed on the basis of a one-hundred-year storm. All detention ponds shall be designed so that no standing water will remain beyond five (5) days after the end of the storm. 
(e)  Off-site runoff entering the development may be included in this detention system, and if this is the case, the analysis for the system must include this additional runoff. Off-site runoff should be analyzed under present conditions. 
(f)  Detention facility design shall be in conformance with the requirements of the Town Engineer. For any detention facility design, specific soil information shall be included. This report shall include but not be limited to soil-boring logs, water-table elevations and soil classifications. 
(g)  For grassed detention areas, the minimum channel slope shall be one and five-tenths percent (1.5%) to two and zero-tenths percent (2.0%). Side slopes shall not be greater than four (4) horizontal to one (1) vertical to allow access for maintenance vehicles. Space shall be provided around the perimeter of the detention area in order to permit desilting operations. 
(h)  The developer shall make all practical efforts to assure that the water quality of the postdevelopment runoff is not less than the predevelopment runoff. 
(i)  Drainage easements shall be provided if required to ensure perpetuity of detention areas when constructed as permanent drainage facilities. 
(j)  Responsibility for maintenance of detention areas shall be determined as a part of the subdivision agreement. 
(k)  Drainage for roads and streets shall be in accordance with the approved Town street specifications. 
(l)  If a proposed development causes a downstream drainage course which is unable to handle one-hundred-year or ten-year storm events as determined by the Town Manager based on a recommendation by the Town Engineer, then the storm runoff rate from the developed site shall be limited to the historic rate for the one-hundred-year or ten-year storm event as appropriate. 
(Prior code 57-28; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-40. - Bridges. 
    Any bridge planned as part of a proposed subdivision shall be designed, constructed and paid for by the subdivider in accordance with the American Association of State Highway Officials recommendations, which recommendations are incorporated herein by this reference as if set forth verbatim. Where an existing bridge is a part of a proposed subdivision and does not meet the specifications of this Chapter, it is the responsibility of the subdivider to repair or replace such bridge as necessary to meet the requirements of an H-20 live load prior to acceptance by the Town Council for maintenance. No lot served by such bridge shall be built upon or occupied until such improvements shall have been completed. The width of such bridge shall not be less than the width of the roadways approaching it on either side. 
(Prior code 57-29; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-41. - Water distribution systems. 
    Water distribution systems shall be designed to connect with the Town water system and make water available to each lot and proposed site of use in the proposed subdivision. Fire hydrants shall be located to ensure protection of each lot based on utilization of existing fire district fire-fighting equipment and recommendations made by the Fire Chief. The design and engineering of the system shall be the responsibility of the subdivider, with all plans subject to approval of the Town. Installation of the system shall be to Town specifications. Financial responsibility for the water distribution system shall be the subdivider's and shall be subject to existing Town regulations and agreements executed by the Town and the subdivider. 
(Prior code 57-30) 
Sec. 17-42. - Sanitary sewer systems. 
(a)  The sewage collection system for the subdivision shall be designed to connect with the Basalt Sanitation District's system and shall provide service for each lot and proposed site of use within the subdivision. The subdivider shall design the system and shall obtain the approval of the Basalt Sanitation District for all plans and specifications. Installation of the system shall be subject to the specifications of the Basalt Sanitation District. 
(b)  If the Basalt Sanitation District sewage collection system is not accessible, the subdivision shall not be approved. 
(c)  The developer shall pay for the sanitary sewage collection system, subject to all regulations of the Basalt Sanitation District. 
(Prior code 57-31) 
Sec. 17-43. - Energy conservation. 
    It is important that special attention be given to the conservation of energy throughout the planning, design and construction of new subdivisions. New subdivisions in the Town should be designed to provide for energy efficiency in the orientation of streets, lots and buildings. The following provide guidelines to be considered in the design and review of future subdivisions. While it may not be possible to follow these guidelines in every instance, every subdivision should be based on these fundamental site planning principles that can result in lower energy costs. 
(1)  Take advantage of south-facing slopes for solar orientation, especially for higher density development. 
(2)  Lot layouts should emphasize north-south orientation as much as possible. 
(3)  Street layout and design of single-family subdivisions should have an east-west orientation as much as possible within the limits of the topography to assure proper orientation of buildings. 
(4)  Lots should generally face on these east-west streets. 
(5)  If north-south orientation of streets is necessary, then the lots or buildings should be planned to maximize southern solar access. 
(6)  Lot lines should extend from north to south even if streets are necessarily designed intercardinally. 
(7)  Special consideration should be given to the potential shadows created on a lot by building development and by landscaping. 
(8)  Subdivision covenants should encourage building development close to the north property line, therefore allowing greater area to the south for solar access. 
(Prior code 57-32) 
Secs. 17-44-17-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Application Requirements 

Sec. 17-61. - Payment of fees; deposit requirements. 
(a)  Application fee. The applicant for a development review approval pursuant to this Chapter shall pay a nonrefundable application fee upon filing the application in an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. The application fee may include a credit for a designated number of hours of staff fees as described below. 
(b)  Payment of fees and costs. The applicant for a development review approval pursuant to this Chapter shall reimburse the Town for any and all costs, staff fees and consultant fees incurred by the Town during and after a review process associated with the property. Costs include, but are not limited to, publication fees, recording fees and any other actual out-of-pocket costs incurred by the Town with regard to the property. Staff fees include, but are not limited to, reimbursement for time spent by the Town Manager, Town Planning staff and the Public Works staff for inspection, review and other work performed with regard to the development application, at hourly rates established by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. Consultant fees shall include, but are not limited to, all actual out-of-pocket costs incurred by the Town in connection with the applicant's development review application for consultants providing the Town legal, engineering, planning and other professional advice, which consultants are not on Town staff, at the rate of the amount actually paid by the Town for such review and advice. Additionally, to partially defray administrative handling and review costs incurred by the Town with regard to the property, the applicant for any development review application shall pay to the Town an administrative fee in an amount equal to fifteen percent (15%) of all of the costs and consultant fees. Collectively, the costs, staff fees, consultant fees and administrative fees are referred to in this Section as review expenses . 
(c)  Deposit requirement. To secure the payment of the Town's review expenses, all applicants filing applications pursuant to this Chapter shall pay to the Town a deposit in an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. In the event the applicant's deposit exceeds the actual review expenses owed to the Town pursuant to Subsection (a) above, upon completion of all aspects of the development review, including the payment of all costs associated therewith, such excess deposit shall be refunded to the applicant within a reasonable time after final action by the Town or withdrawal of the application and payment of all costs associated with the application. 
(d)  Monthly payment and interest. The Town will bill the applicant on a monthly basis for all review expenses. All bills for review expenses are due and payable to the Town within fifteen (15) days of the date of the bill. Interest shall be charged on any overdue amounts unpaid within one (1) month of the date of the bill until paid at an interest rate set by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381 et seq. 
(e)  Continuing obligation. By filing an application for development review under this Chapter and accepting the benefits thereof, a property owner agrees and acknowledges that there shall be a continuing and binding obligation on the applicant, so long as the applicant owns the property, and any future owners of the property to reimburse the Town for any and all expenses associated with the property incurred by the Town for counseling and advice, including, but not limited to, monitoring compliance with development approvals, enforcement of development permits or approvals, participation in litigation or depositions (whether or not the Town is a party), consideration of potential amendments to development approvals, and any other expenses directly associated with the property and incurred by the Town. 
(f)  Reimbursement agreement. On filing an application for development pursuant to this Chapter, the applicant shall enter a reimbursement agreement with the Town providing for the payment to the Town of the application fee, deposit and review expenses and acknowledging the continuing obligation to pay such review expenses. 
(g)  Processing applications. No application for development review pursuant to this Chapter shall be processed until such time as the application fee and the deposit required above have been paid and the reimbursement agreement required above has been executed by the applicant. If at any time during the review of a development application the applicant has not paid its bill for review expenses in a timely manner, then all processing of the application, including staff review and scheduled hearings, shall cease until such time as the applicant pays all amounts outstanding. 
(h)  Use of fees. The fees and expenses paid and collected by virtue of this Section shall not be used for general or other governmental proprietary purposes of the Town, except to pay each new development's equitable share of the costs of accounting, planning, management, administration and government of the Town, and to pay each new development's costs and expenses. Other than as described in this Section, the fees charged herein shall be used solely to pay for the costs of planning, operation, administration, maintenance, repair, improvement, renewal, replacement, reconstruction or other services provided by the Town on behalf of or as a result of new development within the Town. 
(Ord. 28 §2, 1990; Ord. 13 §2, 1991; Ord. 32 §2, 1996; Ord. 12 §B43, 2003) 
Sec. 17-62. - Sketch plan. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of the sketch plan is to provide a general concept of the proposed annexation or subdivision for review by the staff, Planning and Zoning Commission and Town Council. The intent is to identify the major problems that must be resolved and the overall feasibility of the request. Detailed engineering plans are not required at this time. 
(b)  Written information. This information shall be provided on the subdivision/annexation summary form, including the following information: 
(1)  A description of proposed land uses. 
(2)  A statement of planning objectives. 
(3)  A description of adjoining land uses. 
(4)  Existing and proposed zoning. 
(5)  An estimate of proposed residential units; an estimate of population on square footage commercial area. 
(6)  The names and addresses of the owner, applicant and the individual who prepared the sketch plan. 
(7)  The total area of the parcel. 
(8)  A statement as to how the development will be served by utilities. 
(9)  A general statement describing the geological characteristics of the land, soil types, slope stability and floodplain information. This information may be based on secondary data available from the Town, soil conservation service or other sources. The Town Manager may request that an environmental summary of the above characteristics be submitted in graphic form. 
(c)  Site plans and supporting documents. The sketch plan shall be drawn to a scale of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet or larger and include the following: 
(1)  A vicinity map, drawn at a scale of one (1) inch equals two thousand (2,000) feet, showing the general location of the land for consideration and the surrounding area within a one-mile radius. 
(2)  The topography of the land. 
(3)  The location of proposed land uses. 
(4)  The approximate location of proposed public or private open space areas. 
(5)  The location of existing or proposed water and sewer lines to serve the area. 
(6)  The proposed lot or block pattern and street layout. 
(Prior code 57-36; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-63. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  Purpose. It is intended that the preliminary plat provide the necessary information to permit the staff, Planning and Zoning Commission and Town Council to properly review the proposal and to resolve potential planning or engineering details that may arise before the final plat is prepared. The preliminary plat, therefore, requires extensive information and engineering studies. 
(b)  Written information. 
(1)  The name and address of the owner and applicant. 
(2)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the surveyor, engineer and planner of the subdivision. 
(3)  The names and addresses of all property owner within a three hundred (300) foot radius of the property. This information is to be provided on forms provided by the Town. All names and addresses shall be as they appear upon the records of the County Assessor's office or on the tax records of the Town or of Eagle or Pitkin County. 
(4)  All data and information required on the subdivision/annexation summary form that is required for the sketch plan. 
(5)  A description of any proposed covenants. 
(6)  Proposed terms of reservations and dedications of public rights-of-way, easements and other public lands. 
(c)  Plans and supporting data. 
(1)  A plat of the proposed subdivision shall be drafted in preliminary form to a scale of at least one hundred (100) feet to the inch, on a sheet at least twenty-four (24) by thirty-six (36) inches, and shall show the information listed below. In addition, an eight and one-half (81/2) by eleven (11) inch reduction of the plat shall also be provided to the Town. 
(2)  The title, north arrow, graphic and numerical scale and date of preparation. 
(3)  A key diagram if the area requires more than one (1) twenty-four (24) by thirty-six (36) inch sheet. 
(4)  The name of the proposed subdivision, which shall be different from any existing recorded subdivision in Eagle or Pitkin County. 
(5)  The street layout of the proposed subdivision, including relationship to existing public rights-of-way and the widths and names of proposed streets. 
(6)  The lot and block layout of the proposed subdivision, including a block and lot numbering system, and in the case of a planned unit development, the types of uses, the supplementary requirements and area setback information on each lot, if at variance with otherwise applicable zone district regulations, are also required. 
(7)  Existing and proposed easements and structures for irrigation, drainage and utilities. 
(8)  Contours of the areas proposed for roads and buildings shall be at two-foot intervals. The Town Manager may approve contours to be mapped at lesser intervals for areas not to be developed. Topographic maps shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor or licensed engineer. 
(9)  Drainage plan. When the plat of a proposed subdivision includes a stream course, a mudflow course or dry wash subject to flood crest or heavy runoff generated by precipitation or rapid spring-thaw runoff, a drainage plan, based on an engineering analysis of the catchment and the tributary area and detailed drainage easements and structures necessary to accommodate a design one-hundred-year storm, mudflow or flooding, shall be provided by an engineer registered in the State. 
(10)  Utility plan. A plan corresponding to the preliminary plat, showing the line and related facilities' locations, sizes and gradients for the proposed subdivision in relation to existing Town installations and those of any special district. The utility plan shall also indicate underground distribution of electrical power and communications lines to be utilized, and a description of the system or systems shall be shown on the plan. 
(11)  Street profile. Center-line profiles of proposed streets shall be plotted at a horizontal scale of one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet at a distorted vertical scale, with sufficient detail to ensure that the proposed streets meet the gradient limitations established by this Chapter and bear a logical relationship to the grade of existing public streets at points of intersection. 
(12)  Geological/Soils. Sufficient field soil sampling shall be performed throughout the development to allow accurate determination of soil stratigraphy and bedrock lithology. A report shall be submitted by a registered engineer licensed by the State of sufficient detail to indicate any potential problems to development. Potential problems to development will be determined by the Town Manager based on a recommendation by the Town Engineer, and may include, by way of example only, problems resulting from groundwater, slope stability, expansive soils and soil bearing strength. The report shall include laboratory results and analyses. 
(13)  Unless waived by the Town Planner, a final comprehensive landscaping and irrigation plan shall be submitted designating all existing and proposed species, size and placement. The plan shall specify all irrigation features and a program for continued maintenance. The comprehensive landscaping and irrigation plan shall be reviewed and approved by the Public Works Director and Town Planner. 
(Prior code 57-37; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 11 §8, 2011) 
Sec. 17-64. - Final plat. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of the final map or plat for an annexation or a subdivision is to provide a legal document that will be a part of the Town and county records describing the development conditions and land descriptions for the property. The final plat application shall include all binding agreements between the owner(s) and the Town. 
(b)  Written information. The final plat shall include: 
(1)  All information required for the preliminary plat. 
(2)  The title under which the subdivision is to be recorded. 
(3)  The names and addresses of all property owners within three hundred (300) feet of the property to be annexed or subdivided. 
(4)  A surveyor's certificate, signed and sealed by a licensed Colorado surveyor responsible for the survey and preparation of the final plat. 
(5)  A Planning and Zoning Commission certificate, certifying that the final plat is consistent with the approved preliminary plat and is approved subject to acceptance by the Town Council. 
(6)  A Town Council certificate of approval and acceptance. 
(7)  A Clerk and Recorder's certificate for time and date of recording. 
(8)  Three (3) copies of any protective covenants or restrictions placed on the subdivision. 
(9)  The name and address of the person to whom the notice of public hearing should be sent. 
(10)  A subdivision agreement, to be executed by the Town and by the subdivider, wherein the subdivider covenants and agrees to perform all conditions imposed by the Town. Such conditions and agreement may include, and the Town is empowered to require, the obligation of the subdivider to pay for and install or cause to be installed all required water distribution systems; trash collection facilities and areas; storm drain structures; devices to inhibit access to such structures by children; curbs and gutters; street base course material; asphalt wearing course material; bridges; underground wiring; ornamental streetlighting; underground communications systems; underground gas distribution systems; underground cable television wiring; fire hydrants; fire alarms; street signs; traffic control devices; measures to stabilize soil or to limit floods, mudslides and snowslides, as may be required by and according to the specifications of the Town; and sanitary sewer collection systems as required by the Basalt Sanitation District. The Town may also require specific procedures to be followed in order to mitigate potential problems caused by and during construction activities. Such measures may include, but are not restricted to, dust control, fencing, road patch requirements, provision of temporary sanitation facilities, scheduled work hours, emergency access and off-street parking for construction employees. 
(11)  An agreement and covenant of the subdivider to convey ownership to the Town of any or all of the foregoing facilities and improvements upon demand of the Town, except the following: sanitary sewer facilities of the Basalt Sanitation District; cable television wiring and related facilities; those facilities which by public utilities tariffs become the property of the public utility, its customer or its user. At the time of the conveyance, the subdivider shall supply a statement of the costs of the facilities conveyed; mechanic's lien waivers from all involved contractors, subcontractors and suppliers; and existing as-built specifications and other available data concerning the location, construction, operation and maintenance of such facilities. The subdivider shall also warrant the conveyed facilities to be fit for the purpose intended and of merchantable quality and to be free for one (1) year from the date of conveyance from all defects in materials and workmanship. All warranties of vendors or suppliers of such facilities or components shall be assignable upon demand to the Town, and the subdivider shall notify the vendors and suppliers that the warranties are to be assigned to the Town. Nothing herein shall limit the right of the Town as to any expressed or implied warranties concerning such facilities from persons manufacturing, selling or installing the facilities. The Town Council shall require cash to be deposited in an escrow account, an acceptable letter of credit or a surety bond approved by the Town to be posted with the Town Clerk in an amount equal to the cost of installing all improvements described in the subdivision agreement. The Town Council may release all or portions of the deposited funds or reduce the amount of the bond or letter of credit upon the completion according to the Town's specifications of all or a portion of the required improvements. 
(12)  An owner's title policy shall provide verification that all owners and lienholders have signed the final plat. A title policy naming the Town as beneficiary shall be provided to the Town indicating that any property to be dedicated is free and clear of all encumbrances whatsoever which would impair the dedicated property to be utilized as proposed by the final plat. The title policies shall be effective within twenty-four (24) hours after the date of approval by the Town Council. The title policies must be provided to the Town Clerk within fourteen (14) days after action by the Town Council; provided, however, that the Town Council may extend said fourteen-day period, either before or after its expiration, for subsequent additional fourteen-day periods, each such extension to be approved by a meeting of a quorum of the Town Council. 
(13)  A copy of all other documents needed to effectuate the development approvals as determined by the Town Attorney, including but not limited to community housing deed restrictions, declaration of covenants and an estimation of the annual HOA budget and projected fees for a period of two (2) years from total build-out in current dollars. The Town will review the documents to ensure that there will be a sufficient capital improvements fund established for the development to aid in reducing the need for special assessments. Pursuant to the Community Housing Guidelines, the Town will review the documents to ensure that any community housing units in a proposed subdivision will have reasonable initial HOA fees and assessments and that there are regulations ensuring that the fees and assessments will not unreasonably increase, making the units unaffordable. 
(c)  Final plat. Plans and supporting documents: 
(1)  The final map or plat shall be drawn in ink on a permanent reproducible Mylar sheet that is twenty-four (24) by thirty-six (36) inches. The final map or plat shall be drawn to a scale of at least one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet. If the area requires more than one (1) sheet, then a key diagram shall be provided on each separate sheet. In addition, an eight and one-half (81/2) by eleven (11) inch reduction of the final map or plat shall be submitted. 
(2)  Accurate dimensions shall be shown for all lines, angles, curves used to describe lot boundaries, streets, alleys, easements, areas to be reserved for public use and other important features. All curves shall be circular arcs and shall be defined by radius, central angle, tangent, arc and chord lengths. All dimensions, both linear and angular, are to be determined by an accurate control survey in the field which must balance and close within a limit of one (1) in ten thousand (10,000). Approximate dimensions (plus or minus indications) shall not be approved on a final map or plat. 
(3)  The name of adjoining subdivisions shall be shown with dotted lines indicated for abutting lots. 
(4)  All lots or blocks shall be properly numbered in accordance with an approved identification system. 
(5)  Identification of the streets, alleys, easements, parks and other facilities as shown on the plat, and a dedication thereof to public use. Areas reserved for future public acquisition shall also be delineated on the map or plat. 
(6)  A legal description of the area to be subdivided or annexed with reference to its location in the records of Eagle or Pitkin County. The total area of the tract and the area of each lot created by the subdivision. The names of all streets within the subdivision. 
(7)  A description of all monuments, both found and set, which mark the boundaries of the property and a description of all control monuments used in conducting the survey. This shall include a tie to a section corner. 
(8)  Final engineering documents, including plans and specifications for streets, water, sewer and drainage and the engineer's cost estimates for all improvements to be installed by the subdivider in dedicated land, rights-of-way or easements or as may be required by this Chapter. 
(9)  A certification of ownership and dedication by the owner(s) that he, she or they are the sole owner in fee simple of all the real property depicted in the plat and a dedication for the public use of the streets, avenues, drives, courts, places, alleys and public lands shown on the plat for their dedicated use, a dedication of utility and drainage purposes, and a dedication for public use of other lands and areas as may be required by the Town to comply with the subdivision agreement and the contents of the plat. 
(10)  Concurrent with the recording of a final plat, the applicant shall provide to the Town a copy of the approved plat in an electronic computerized format of a type approved by the Town Engineer or Public Works Director. In addition, all as-built mapping and diagrams for utility installations shall be provided to the Town in an electronic computerized format of a type approved by the Town Engineer or Public Works Director. The as-built drawings shall be provided prior to the complete release of security for the installation of said improvements. In its sole discretion the Town may exempt certain minor subdivision plats and amended plats from the above requirements where computerized mapping is found to be inappropriate. 
(11)  The landscaping submittal requirements for preliminary plat as set forth in Paragraph 17-63(c)(13) of this Article. 
(Prior code 57-38; Ord. 29 §1, 1996; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 16 §1, 2009; Ord. 11 §9, 2011) 
Sec. 17-65. - Condominium application requirements. 
    In addition to the general requirements for a subdivision, a condominiumization request shall provide the following: 
(1)  Sketch plan. 
a.  Lot sizes of each proposed condominium unit and in relation to the overall project. 
b.  Existing and proposed off-street parking areas. 
c.  Existing and proposed landscaping. 
d.  Existing and proposed facilities, including all buildings and structures. 
(2)  Preliminary plat. 
a.  Preliminary landscaping plan. 
b.  Plans for access and egress to each condominium unit. 
c.  Building plans indicating compliance with all design, building, fireproofing, soundproofing and utility standards of the Town. 
d.  A copy of the proposed condominium documents needed to effectuate the approvals as determined by the Town Attorney, including but not limited to a copy of the proposed condominium declarations and condominium map, bylaws and rules and regulations of the condominium or homeowners' association and an estimate of the annual budget of the condominium or homeowners' association for a period of two (2) years from the conversion or creation of the condominium units. In addition to all other requirements imposed in this Section, the developer shall submit a proposed condominium agreement with the Town setting forth, at a minimum: 
1.  Notice procedures for granting existing tenants not less than ninety (90) days' written notice of intent to condominiumize, which notice shall specify the sale price of the particular unit. A provision whereby each tenant shall have a ninety (90) day nonassignable option to purchase his or her unit at said specified sale price, which price shall not be varied by more than ten percent (10%) for a period of six (6) months after completion of condominiumization. 
2.  The applicant shall state and demonstrate that the supply of low- and moderate-income housing and rental space will not be significantly decreased as a result of condominiumization. The applicant shall also demonstrate that any community housing units in a proposed condominium development will have reasonable initial homeowners' association fees and assessments, that the fees and assessments will not unreasonably increase once the project is developed and that a sufficient capital improvements fund is established for the entire development for the purposes described in Paragraph 17-64(b)(13) of this Article. 
3.  The developer shall state whether or not it intends to make special provisions for the elderly or low-income citizens now residing within the structure proposed for condominiumization. 
(3)  Final plat requirements. To the extent possible, the final plat shall correspond with all requirements of Section 17-64 of this Chapter. 
(4)  Additional public notice requirements. In addition to the public notice requirements of Section 17-151, all tenants of a building proposed for condominiumization shall be sent notices at least fifteen (15) days prior to the public hearings on the preliminary and final plats. 
(Prior code 57-39; Ord. 13 §§2, 3, 2009) 
Secs. 17-66-17-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Plat Approval Procedures 

Sec. 17-81. - Preapplication conferences. 
    Before commencing the annexation or subdivision of any parcel of land, the applicant shall consult with the Town Manager or his or her designated representative for general information regarding the Town's regulations, procedures and policies. Any statements made by the Town Manager or staff concerning a proposed development shall not be binding on the Planning and Zoning Commission or the Town Council. 
(Prior code 57-45; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-82. - Filing deadlines. 
    All applications shall be filed thirty (30) days in advance of the Planning and Zoning Commission meeting at which the matter is to be considered. Final plats shall be filed fifteen (15) days in advance of a regularly scheduled Technical Review Committee meeting. The Town Manager shall prepare a list of filing dates and meeting dates for each year. Applications to be accepted must be complete. If an application is determined to be incomplete, the Town Manager shall not schedule the matter for review by the Planning and Zoning Commission or Town Council. All application fees must be paid at the time of filing the application. 
(Prior code 57-46; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-83. - Minor subdivision procedure. 
(a)  Technical Review Committee action. Following the preapplication conference, the applicant may file a final subdivision plat meeting the requirements for final subdivision applications where applicable. The final plat shall then be reviewed by the Technical Review Committee at its next regular meeting. 
(1)  For minor subdivision applications relating to a lot line adjustment, relocation of easements, or condominiumization not involving the creation of new residential units, and correction of plat or survey errors deferred to the Town Council by the Technical Review Committee, the Technical Review Committee shall determine whether a publicly noticed hearing (as opposed to a hearing without public notice) shall be held at the Town Council for final review of the minor subdivision application. If the Technical Review Committee determines that the minor subdivision will have potential impacts on property owners within three hundred (300) feet of the proposed minor subdivision, the Technical Review Committee shall require a publicly noticed hearing for the Town Council. Following review by the Committee and after all necessary additions or corrections are made, the final plat will be scheduled for consideration by the Town. The Town Planner shall forward the final plat and the recommendations of the Technical Review Committee to the Town Council. 
(2)  For minor subdivision applications relating to Town-owned property or property under contract for purchase by the Town which does not meet at least one (1) of the other conditions under the definition of minor subdivision in Section 17-4, the subdivision application shall be forwarded first to the Planning and Zoning Commission for a recommendation to the Town Council unless the need for the Planning and Zoning recommendation is waived by the Technical Review Committee. After Planning and Zoning Commission review and recommendation, the minor subdivision request will be forwarded to the Town Council for review and either denial, approval or approval with conditions. The hearing at the Town Council shall be a duly noticed public hearing, unless the Technical Review Committee waives the requirement for public notice following the procedures in Subsection (1) above. 
(3)  For minor subdivision applications relating to the correction of plat or survey errors, or technical corrections, the Technical Review Committee may review and approve of a final plat to make such corrections pursuant to the requirements of Section 17-64, final plat, for signature by the Mayor of the Town. At the discretion of the Technical Review Committee, the Technical Review Committee may defer review of a minor subdivision application relating to the correction of plat or survey errors or technical corrections to the Town Council, in which case, the application shall be reviewed by the Town Council pursuant to the procedure established in Section 17-83(a)(1) and 17-83(b)(2). 
(b)  Town Council action. 
(1)  For all minor subdivisions involving the creation of subdivided lots, the minor subdivision application and the recommendations of the Technical Review Committee shall be considered at a noticed public hearing. The Town Council shall then make a final decision to approve the minor subdivision, grant approval of the minor subdivision subject to modifications or conditions or deny the minor subdivision application. 
(2)  For minor subdivision applications relating to a lot line adjustment, correction of plat or survey errors, relocation of easements, technical corrections, condominiumization not involving the creation of new residential units or property owned by or under contract for purchase by the Town, the Town Council shall consider the minor subdivision application and the recommendation of the Technical Review Committee at a public hearing (without the necessity of public notice unless otherwise determined by the Technical Review Committee). The Town Council shall make the final decision to approve the minor subdivision application, grant approval of the minor subdivision application subject to modifications or conditions or deny the minor subdivision application. 
(Prior code 57-47; Ord. 6 §2, 1998; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 12 §B1, 2005; Ord. 21 §B2, 2005; Ord. 6 §2(Exh. B), 2014 ) 
Sec. 17-84. - Major subdivision procedures. 
(a)  Sketch plan. 
(1)  Planning and Zoning Commission action. At its next regular meeting, not more than thirty (30) days after filing, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall consider the sketch plan and the staff comments pertaining to the application. The Planning and Zoning Commission may then recommend to the Town Council approval, approval with modification or denial. The approval of the Planning and Zoning Commission of the sketch plan does not bind the Commission to accept the preliminary plat. 
(2)  Town Council action. At a regular meeting following the Planning and Zoning Commission action, the Town Council shall consider the sketch plan. The Town Council may then approve the application, grant approval with modifications or deny the application. The approval of the Town Council of the sketch plan does not bind the Town Council to accept the preliminary plat. 
(b)  Preliminary subdivision plat or annexation map. 
(1)  Technical Review Committee action. The Town Manager shall refer the matter to the representatives of the various departments and agencies assigned to the Technical Review Committee. Copies of the plan may be mailed to the other agencies or utility companies. Within fifteen (15) days following the filing deadline, the Technical Review Committee shall meet to review the application. The applicant shall be notified of the technical meeting and invited to be in attendance. Based upon the comments of the Technical Review Committee, the Town Manager shall then prepare his or her report and recommendations to the Planning and Zoning Commission. If the deficiencies in the application warrant additional work by the applicant or require further discussion by the Technical Review Committee and the developer, the Town Manager may defer sending the matter to the Planning and Zoning Commission. In such case, the applicant will be required to waive the statutory requirement of review within thirty (30) days. 
(2)  Planning and Zoning Commission action. The Planning and Zoning Commission, at a regular meeting thirty (30) days after the filing of the complete application, shall hold a public hearing on the application and consider the recommendation of the planning staff and the merits of the proposed annexation or subdivision. The Planning and Zoning Commission may recommend to the Town Council approval, approval with modifications or denial of the application. 
(3)  Town Council action. The Town Council, at a regular meeting following the Planning and Zoning Commission hearing, shall consider the application. The Town Council may then approve the application, approve with modifications, deny the application or refer the matter back to the Planning and Zoning Commission for further study. 
(c)  Final subdivision plat or annexation map. 
(1)  Technical Review Committee action. Once the Town Council has approved the preliminary plan, the final plan may be submitted (unless considered concurrently). Within fifteen (15) days after the filing deadline, the Technical Review Committee shall meet to review the final details and to assure that the final plan is consistent with the preliminary plan. The Chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission will be requested to review the final plat to determine if the final plat is consistent with the preliminary plat approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission. If there are major changes or discrepancies between the preliminary plat and the final plat or if unanticipated or additional planning issues exist, as determined by the Chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission, the final plat shall be subject to additional review by the Planning and Zoning Commission prior to final Town Council approval and before the Planning and Zoning Commission Chairman is authorized to sign the final plat. 
(2)  Town Council action. Following review by the Technical Review Committee and if all matters are complete, the final plat will be scheduled for a public hearing before the Town Council. The Town Council may then approve the application, approve with modifications or deny the request. If the final map is an annexation request, the ordinances for annexation and zoning may be considered concurrently in the manner prescribed by state statutes. The order of consideration shall generally be as follows: 
a.  Annexation proceedings. 
b.  Zoning. 
c.  Planned unit development application. 
d.  Subdivision. 
(Prior code 57-48; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-84.5. - Community serving subdivisions and development site subdivisions. 
    Community serving subdivision with subsequent filings of development site subdivisions. Where a subdivision satisfies the requirements of a community serving subdivision per Section 17-4 and the land owner desires to create four (4) or fewer lots for future development ("development sites"), the Town Council may approve a community serving subdivision, which allows the development sites to be sold, conveyed or encumbered in order to facilitate development that furthers a specific public purpose, provided that no building permit on a development site will be issued unless and until the land owner or its successors file a development site subdivision. Once the community serving subdivision is recorded in the public records, the property may be sold, conveyed to entities that do not meet the eligibility requirements for filing a community serving subdivision but development must proceed under the conditions established in the land use approvals for that subdivision. The requirements and process for filing for community serving subdivision shall be the same as required for a minor subdivision plat, which application may be combined with an application for rezoning or site plan review with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The Planning and Zoning Commission will provide a recommendation to the Town Council on the subdivision following a public hearing; 
(2)  The application is not eligible for waiving the requirements for a publicly noticed hearing included in Section 17-83(a)(1) for minor subdivisions; 
(3)  If the land use application requires another land use action requiring a sketch plan review, the Applicant shall submit and process for approval a sketch plan subdivision application satisfying Section 17-62. 
    The Town Council's ordinance granting approval of a community serving subdivision must include the explanation of how the plat satisfies the definition of a community serving subdivision and the public purpose that the subdivision is furthering. The individual development site subdivisions for the development sites shall satisfy the requirements for final subdivision approval, except that the Council's approval of the community serving subdivision may contain procedures and requirements for the Town's approval of the development site subdivision or further subdivision or condominium approvals within the development sites to be accomplished administratively by the TRC. 
( Ord. 10 §B.5(Exh. D), 2012) 
Sec. 17-85. - Condominium review procedures. 
    A condominium is defined by these regulations as a subdivision. Therefore, all condominiums shall comply with the provisions of this Chapter insofar as they are applicable, depending on the nature of the condominium request. The review procedures shall be the same as for any subdivision, with the exception that condominiumization not involving new residential units may be reviewed as a minor subdivision in accordance with the definition and review procedures for minor subdivisions. For all other requests, a sketch plan must be reviewed prior to the filing of a preliminary or final plat. However, the developer or applicant may file a preliminary and final plat concurrently. For all condominiumizations, the applicant or developer shall file a condominium map and condominium declarations for review and approval by the Town in accordance with the requirements of state statutes. 
(Prior code 57-49; Ord. 6 §3, 1998) 
Sec. 17-86. - Time limits for approvals. 
(a)  Preliminary plat. Once a preliminary plat has been approved by the Town Council, the applicant shall have a maximum of one (1) year to file a final plat for the entire plat or for the first portion of a phased project. If more than one (1) year has lapsed, a new preliminary plat must be approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission and the Town Council. 
(b)  Final plats. Final plats shall be approved subject to a development schedule determined at the time of approval. If the final plat is a part of a planned unit development, the final plat shall be subject to the schedule approved as a part of the planned unit development. If development of buildings has not occurred in accordance with the approved schedule, the Town Council may rescind its approval of the final plat. Procedures for rescinding approval shall be the same as described for termination of special review applications in Section 16-47. 
(Prior code 57-50; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-87. - Recording of final map and plats. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days following the approval of a final subdivision plat or final annexation map, the applicant shall record the final plat, applicable covenants and restrictions and the subdivision agreement with the County Clerk and Recorder's office in the manner prescribed by that office. A notice providing proof of recording shall then be submitted to the Town Clerk within the thirty-day deadline. 
(b)  The provisions of Subsection (a) notwithstanding, the applicant shall not accomplish the required recordation prior to receipt by the Town Clerk of the title policy mandated by the provisions of Section 17-64(b)(12). 
(c)  Any alteration to an approved final subdivision plat or final annexation map prior to its recordation shall constitute fraud and shall subject the applicant to the sanctions provided in Section 17-9(b). 
(Prior code 57-51) 
Secs. 17-88-17-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Public Improvement Acceptance and Guaranties 

Sec. 17-101. - Installation. 
    Prior to the issuance of any building permits in any area within any addition or subdivision, all improvements and any other conditions and requirements imposed by this Code or by the Town Council must be installed in a manner acceptable to the Town or a satisfactory guaranty of such installation or performance must be made by the property owner in compliance with the plans and specifications approved by the Town Engineer. 
(Prior code 57-55; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-102. - Improvement guaranties. 
(a)  The Town Council shall require that the cost of providing all public improvements applicable to the subdivision shall be paid prior to the issuance of the first building permit for the subdivision. The costs shall include all improvements described in the subdivision agreement. The improvement guaranty may be provided with a surety bond, cash or acceptable collateral, an acceptable letter of credit, or other security acceptable to the Town Council. Upon final plat, the property owner shall provide either an improvement guaranty as provided for in this Section or, to ensure that lots are not sold until such time as an acceptable guaranty has been provided by the property owner, the property owner shall provide the Town with security acceptable to the Town, such as a deed of trust on the property for the benefit of the Town, until substituted with an improvement guaranty pursuant to this Section. The Town Manager may waive or partially waive the public improvement security requirements for buildings or development projects proposing considerably more affordable housing than is required by the Town Code. 
(b)  All guaranties shall be deposited with the Town Clerk in an amount not less than the estimate of the entire amount of the uncompleted public improvements required by the subdivision agreement. The cost estimates shall be prepared by a professional engineer or architect registered in the State and subject to the approval of the Town Engineer. The amount of the guaranty shall be reviewed every six (6) months and shall be adjusted to reflect actual costs. 
(Prior code 57-56; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003; Ord. 19 §C(Exh. B), 2015) 
Sec. 17-103. - Time for completion; release of bond. 
    The time for completion or performance of all such improvements shall be twelve (12) months from the date of the application for the first building permit. The Town Council may extend the time period for completion or performance. Upon completion or performance of such improvements, conditions and requirements within the required time and the approval of the Town Manager, the bond, deposit of escrow or letter of credit shall be released within thirty (30) days of written notice that the required improvements are completed or performed and have been approved in writing by the Town in its sole discretion and conveyed to the Town in a form approved by the Town Attorney. If the improvements are not completed within the required time, the moneys may be used to complete the improvements. The Town Manager may cause a portion of the improvement guaranties to be released as specific improvements are completed and approved. Such release shall be within thirty (30) days after receiving written notice that the improvements are completed and have been accepted by the Town in writing. 
(Prior code 57-57; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-104. - Development area boundaries established. 
    For developments containing ten (10) lots or less, all required improvements must be completed or the entire estimated cost of improvements must be guaranteed, as specified below, before a building permit can be issued. For larger subdivisions, the subdivider may establish boundaries for areas containing at least ten (10) lots, provided that there is a phasing plan established in the subdivision agreement and that such smaller areas be designed to be integrated with the overall system. The cost of improvement for this area must be guaranteed prior to the issuance of the first building permit; however, the subdivider must provide the Town with acceptable security, such as a deed of trust, for the entire property at final plat to secure installation of the public improvements until substituted with an improvement guaranty pursuant to this Article. 
(Prior code 57-58) 
Sec. 17-105. - Acceptance of public improvements; dual jurisdiction. 
    Utilities improvements that are under the jurisdiction of a special district or entity other than the Town must be inspected, approved and accepted by that entity prior to the final acceptance of the public improvements by the Town and the release of improvement guaranties held by the Town. 
(Prior code 57-59) 
Secs. 17-106-17-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI - Vested Property Rights 

Sec. 17-121. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Article is to provide the procedures necessary to implement the provisions of Article 68 of Title 24, C.R.S. 
(Prior code 58-1) 
Sec. 17-122. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Article, certain terms and words are hereby defined and shall have the following meanings unless it shall be apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended. 
    Commercial means those land uses not including residential dwelling units that are listed as either permitted uses or as uses allowed by special review in the C-1, C-2 and C-3 Zone Districts. 
    Development agreement means an agreement between the Town and a land owner or developer which shall include, but not be limited to, size and density of development, phasing of a development, construction of public improvements, and shall be the agreement referred to in Section 24-68-104(2), C.R.S. The development agreement may be part of a subdivision improvements agreement referred to in Section 17-64(b)(11) or a PUD final development plan agreement referred to in Section 16-66(4)e. 
    Residential means those land uses listed as permitted uses allowed by special review in the R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, C-2 and C-3 Zone Districts which are designed to be dwelling units for long-term occupancy by citizens of the Town. Major residential subdivision projects shall mean any residential subdivision project that does not fall within the definition of a minor residential subdivision project. A minor residential subdivision project shall mean three (3) residential lots or less. 
    Site specific development plan shall mean the last of any of the following required for development of property to be finally approved and recorded in the County records: special review approval pursuant to Section 16-44(f); planned unit development approval pursuant to Section 16-65(5); site plan review or site plan exemption review pursuant to Section 16-111(b) or (c); flood damage prevention pursuant to Section 16-360 or 16-362; environmentally sensitive areas approval pursuant to Section 16-463 or 16-468; minor subdivision approval pursuant to Section 17-83(b); or final plat for major subdivision approval pursuant to Section 17-84(c)(2) 
    Vested property rights means the right to undertake and complete the development and use of property under the terms and conditions of a site specific development plan and development agreement with the developer or owner. 
(Prior code 58-2; Ord. 31 §5, 2000) 
Sec. 17-123. - Duration. 
    A property right which has been vested pursuant to this Article shall remain vested for a period of three (3) years or longer if agreed to by the Town and Developer and warranted in light of circumstances. In the event amendments to a site specific development plan are proposed and approved, the effective date of such amendments, for duration of a vested property right, shall be the date of the approval of the original site specific development plan, unless the Town Council specifically find to the contrary and incorporates such finding in its approval of the amendment. 
(Prior code 58-3; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-124. - Notice and hearing. 
    No site specific development plan shall be approved until after a public hearing, preceded by written notice of such notice and hearing as required by Section 24-68-103(1), C.R.S. Such notice and hearing may, at the Town's option, be combined with notice and hearing required by Section 16-269 or with any other required notice or hearing affecting the proposed development. At such hearing interested persons shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Prior code 58-4) 
Sec. 17-125. - Establishment and forfeiture of vested property rights. 
(a)  Establishment. Vested property rights shall be established upon the execution of an approved development agreement with a developer which shall specifically provide that property rights are vested at that time, but in no case shall rights be vested prior to approval of a site specific development plan as provided in Section 17-122(1). In the event that no development agreement is entered into between the Town and a developer, then property rights shall vest at the time of site specific development plan approval. 
(b)  Forfeiture. The failure of a developer to abide by the terms and conditions contained in the development agreement, the site specific development plan, a subdivision improvements agreement referred to in Section 17-64(b)(11) or a final PUD development plan agreement referred to in Section 16-66(4)e, shall result in a forfeiture of vested property rights. 
(Prior code 58-5) 
Sec. 17-126. - Subsequent regulation and review. 
(a)  A vested property right, once established as provided for in this Article, precludes any zoning or land use action by the Town or pursuant to an initiated measure which would alter, impair, prevent, diminish or otherwise delay the development or use of the property as set forth in a site specific development plan except: 
(1)  With the consent of the land owner; 
(2)  Upon the discovery of a natural or manmade hazard on or in the vicinity of the subject property, which hazards could not reasonably have been discovered at the time of the development plan approval, and which hazards, if uncorrected, would pose a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare; or 
(3)  To the extent the affected land owner receives just compensation for all costs, expenses and liability incurred by the land owner, after the creation of the vested right, including but not limited to, all fees paid in consideration of financing, and all architectural, planning, marketing, legal and other consultant fees incurred after the approval by the Town, together with interests thereon at the legal rate until paid. Just compensation shall not include any diminution in the value of the property which is caused by such action. 
(b)  Establishment of a vested property right shall not preclude the application of ordinances and regulations which are general in nature and applicable to all property subject to land use regulations by the Town, including, but not limited to, building, fire, plumbing, electrical and mechanical codes. 
(Prior code 58-6) 
Sec. 17-127. - Notice of approval. 
    Each site specific development plan shall contain the following language: "Approval of this plan may create a vested property right pursuant to Article 68, Title 24, C.R.S., and pursuant to Chapter 17 of the Municipal Code of the Town of Basalt." Failure to contain this statement shall invalidate the creation of a vested property right. In addition, a notice describing the type and intensity of use, the specific parcel or parcels of property affected and stating that property right has been created shall be published once and not more than fourteen (14) days after approval of the site specific development plan and execution of the development agreement, in a newspaper of general circulation. 
(Prior code 58-7) 
Sec. 17-128. - Payment of costs. 
    In addition to any and all other fees and charges imposed by this Code, the applicant for approval of a site specific development plan shall pay all costs incurred by the Town as a result of the site specific development plan review, including for example, costs of publication of notices, public hearings and review. 
(Prior code 58-8) 
Sec. 17-129. - Other provisions unaffected. 
    Approval of a site specific development plan and development agreement shall not constitute an exemption from or waiver of any other provisions of this Code pertaining to the development and use of property. 
(Prior code 58-9) 
Sec. 17-130. - Limitations. 
    Nothing in this Article is intended to create any vested property right, but only to implement the provisions of Article 68, Title 24, C.R.S. In the event of the repeal of said Article or a judicial determination of that said Article is invalid or unconstitutional, this Article shall be deemed to be repealed, and the provisions hereof no longer effective. 
(Prior code 58-10) 
Sec. 17-131. - Effective date. 
    This Article shall apply to development approvals by the Town occurring after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article. 
(Prior code 58-11) 
Secs. 17-132-17-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII - Administration 

Sec. 17-151. - Public notice requirements. 
(a)  A public hearing shall be required for consideration of preliminary subdivision plats by the Planning and Zoning Commission and for consideration of final subdivision plats by the Town Council. 
(b)  The following public notice requirements shall be met: 
(1)  A public notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the Town at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the hearing. 
(2)  Notice shall be sent to all property owners within three hundred (300) feet of the property in question at least ten (10) days in advance of the hearing. Postage shall be paid by the applicant. 
(3)  A notice shall be posted on the subject property for at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. 
(4)  All notices shall include the following information: 
a.  A description of the nature of the request. 
b.  The time, date and place of the public hearing. 
c.  The agency or office and phone number where further information may be obtained. 
(Prior code 57-65; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Sec. 17-152. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The Planning and Zoning Commission may recommend the granting of exceptions from the design and improvement standards set forth in Sections 17-32 through 17-43, inclusive, at a public hearing conducted upon notice as set forth in Section 17-151. In recommending the granting of an exception, the Planning and ZoningCommission can recommend the imposition of any of the conditions set forth in Section 17-64(b)(10) and (11). In order to obtain an exception, the applicant must show and the Planning and ZoningCommission must find all of the following where applicable: 
(1)  The strict application of the relevant standards will result in peculiar and exceptional practical difficulties to, or exceptional and undue hardship upon, the owner of the property in question, due to the exceptional shape, topographic condition or other extraordinary and exceptional situation or condition of the property in question, which does not occur generally to other property in the same zone district. 
(2)  The exception to be granted is the minimum necessary to alleviate the practical difficulties and undue hardship upon the owner of the property. 
(3)  The exception to be granted does not substantially impair the intent and purpose of the master plan, of this Chapter, of the Zoning Code and of the standard from which the exception is sought. 
(4)  The circumstances relating to or causing the practical difficulties or hardship upon the owner of the property were not created through or induced by any fault or action of the owner of the property, are not due to or the result of general conditions in the zone district or in the surrounding area outside the zone district and cannot practically be corrected by a means other than an exception. 
(5)  Notwithstanding the above, an exception to the subdivision regulations may be recommended by the Planning and Zoning Commission and approved by the Town Council if the exception is considered necessary to achieve the objectives of a planned unit development. 
(b)  The Planning and Zoning Commission may, in recommending the granting of an exception, recommend the imposition of any conditions set forth in Section 17-64(b)(10) and (11) above or which it deems necessary to carry out the intent of the provisions of this Chapter or any other provision of the Code. 
(c)  An exception shall not be allowed until the application for an exception is reviewed and approved by the Town Council. If the Planning and Zoning Commission recommends an exception with or without conditions, the Town Council shall review and act upon the application for exception after giving the same type of notice as was given prior to the hearing before the Planning and Zoning Commission. The Town Council may grant, deny or grant with conditions an application for an exception, and the decision of the Town Council shall be final, from which an appeal may be taken to a court of law. 
(Prior code 57-66; Ord. 33 §B1, 2003) 
Secs. 17-153-17-170. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 18 - Building Regulations 
ARTICLE I - Contractor Licensing 

Sec. 18-1. - Contractor licenses required. 
(a)  Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other legal entity ("firm") who undertakes with or for another to perform construction work within the scope of building codes adopted by the Town, is a contractor. Every contractor must have taken and passed a contractor examination and provide proof of insurance to be approved for a license. A license shall be required of any person or firm which contracts to perform labor or services in any of the following categories: 
    Arborist 
    Concrete 
    Construction Management 
    Drywall 
    Excavation 
    Fireplace 
    Framing 
    General Contractor 
    Insulation 
    Masonry 
    Mechanical 
    Metal stud/Drop ceiling 
    Roofing 
    Structural steel 
    Stucco/EIFS 
The term of all contractor licenses issued by the Town shall by three (3) years. Those exempted from this subsection are: 
(1)  Any person constructing, remodeling, or adding to a single-family dwelling or accessory building which they own and occupy, provided he or she does all the work himself or herself or with the aid of no more than one (1) other compensated person. Homeowner/builders shall be required to provide proof of builder's risk insurance with a policy limit not less than the valuation of the home as set forth in the building permit. Persons having more than one (1) employee will be required to provide proof of workers' compensation insurance to the Town. 
(2)  The owner/builder exemption in Section 18-1(a), of this Code does not apply to a homeowner/builder constructing, remodeling or adding to more than one (1) single-family dwelling or accessory building, which they own and occupy, over a three-year period. 
(3)  Any electrical contractor holding a current license from the State. 
(4)  Any plumbing contractor holding a current license from the State. 
(b)  A license in one (1) of the following classifications is required for contracting for or performing work within the scope of the building code in the Town of Basalt: 
(1)  General contractor (unlimited). This license shall entitle the holder to contract for the construction, alteration or repair of any structure of any type of construction or occupancy classification permitted by the building code. 
(2)  General contractor (commercial). This license shall entitle the holder to contract for the construction of any structure of any type of construction and occupancy classification permitted by the building code, with the exception of Type I construction. This license also entitles the holder to contract for the alteration or repair of any structure of any type of construction or occupancy classification permitted by the building code. 
(3)  General contractor (light commercial). This license shall entitle the holder to contract for the construction, alteration or repair of A-2, A-3, B, E-3, H-4, M, R, S or U occupancy classifications of any type of construction with the exception of Type I construction as set forth in the building code. 
(4)  General contractor (homebuilder). This license shall entitle the holder to contract for the construction, alteration or repair of R-3 and U occupancies of Type VB construction. 
(5)  Specialty. This license shall entitle the holder to contract for work involving any specialty trades regulated by building codes, including but not limited to: 
    Alarm installation 
    Alteration and maintenance 
    Awning installation 
    Boiler (hot water heater) 
    Carpentry 
    Concrete 
    Drywall 
    Excavation 
    Fire sprinkler 
    Gas fitter 
    Glass and glazing 
    Insulation 
    Irrigation 
    Landscape construction 
    Masonry 
    Mechanical contractor 
    Metal stud installation 
    Roofing 
    Solid fuel and gas appliance 
    Structural steel erection 
    Stucco 
    Warm air heating 
Electrical contractors, plumbing contractors and manufacturers' representatives are exempt from this licensing requirement. 
(c)  Arborist contractor license. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any business to engage in cutting, trimming, removing, pruning or other treating of trees on public property within the Town for commercial gain or profit without first procuring an arborist license from the Town in accordance with the provisions of this Section. 
(2)  Any licensee under this Article must comply with the directives and specifications established by the Public Works Director and approved by the Town Manager. Any licensee not complying with this requirement will be subject to penalties pursuant to Section 1-82 of this Code. 
(3)  The provisions of this Section shall not apply to the production and maintenance of trees in a nursery setting. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007; Ord. 11 §§10, 11, 2011) 
Sec. 18-2. - Contractor testing. 
(a)  Contractors must have taken and passed a contractor examination as described in Subsection (b) below. To be approved for a Town contractor's license, firms must appoint a person ("examinee") who is a certified arborist with the International Society of Arboriculture (ISA). Upon issuance of a contractor's license to the firm, all construction and/or tree work performed by the firm shall be under the direction and control of the examinee. Examinees must present proof of certification from SIA every three (3) years. 
(b)  The examinations given for the purpose of licensing general contractors or specialty contractors shall be the current examinations in use under the B.E.S.T. (Board of Examiners for Standardized Testing) program as participated in under a current, active intergovernmental agreement with other jurisdictions. In the licensing of general contractors or specialty contractors, the Town may recognize the examinations successfully completed by the applicant examinee in other jurisdictions, at the discretion of the Building Official. 
(c)  Examinations under the B.E.S.T. program given in the Town will be administered by the Building Official or his or her designated representative. The costs for these examinations will be an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381, et seq., of this Code. Examinations shall be in a classification appropriate for the license requested. 
(d)  To qualify for an arborist contractor's license, an individual must present proof of certification from the International Society of Arboriculture (ISA). Contractor licenses are obtained through the Building Department pursuant to Section 18-3 below. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007; Ord. 11 §§12, 13, 2011) 
Sec. 18-3. - Licensing requirements. 
(a)  Holders of contractors' licenses issued by the Town or the State shall pay a registration fee according to amounts and classifications as approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381, et seq., of this Code. 
(b)  There shall be no prorating of license fees or registration fees for a period of less than twelve (12) months. The renewal fee shall be applicable only if the applicant was properly licensed for the immediately preceding year. The term of the licenses and registrations shall be from the first day of January of each year, and the license or registration fee renewal must be applied for and the renewal fee paid prior to the first day of March in order to qualify for the renewal fee. All such fees shall be paid annually on or before the first day of March of each year. 
(c)  Holders of contractors' licenses issued by the Town shall be required to maintain throughout the time that their licenses are in effect liability insurance coverage covering fire and all risk claims for personal injury and property damage with limits not less than amounts approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381, et seq. Persons having more than one (1) employee will be required to provide proof of workers' compensation insurance to the Town. 
(d)  Any electrical contractor, properly licensed by the Colorado State Electrical Board, performing work within the Town limits shall have in force general liability insurance covering fire and all risk claims for personal injury and property damage with limits in amounts approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381, et seq. and shall have workers' compensation insurance on all employees and shall meet all other requirements set by the Colorado State Electrical Board. 
(e)  Any plumbing contractor, properly licensed by the Colorado State Plumbing Board, performing work within the Town limits shall have in force general liability insurance covering fire and all risk claims for personal injury and property damage in limits not less than an amount approved by the Town Council pursuant to Section 2-381, et seq., and shall have workers' compensation insurance on all employees. 
(f)  There shall be a multiple license rate by which the holder of one (1) license shall be charged one-half (1/2) of the license fee for each additional license held by the holder. Application for a contractor's license shall be submitted to the Building Inspector on forms provided by him or her. Said application shall be accompanied by a certificate evidencing that the person, or appointee of a firm, has passed the Town's test relating to the type of license applied for. Said application must also be accompanied by a certificate of insurance for both workers' compensation and general liability in the amount listed above. 
(g)  Failure of any person or firm holding a Town contractor's license to maintain in the Town offices a certificate of liability insurance and proof of workers' compensation insurance in compliance with this Section, showing the policies to be in force, shall be subject to immediate revocation of such license by the Building Inspector in addition to being subject to the general penalty for violations of this Code set forth in Section 1-82. If the contractor has no employees, a waiver of workers' compensation insurance may be filed with the Town. 
(h)  The general contractor or homeowner/ builder on a job site within the Town shall ensure that any subcontractor he or she has hired is in compliance with the regulations set forth in this Section. The failure of any contractor or subcontractor to be in compliance with this Section constitutes a violation of this Code, and the contractor responsible and/or subcontractor are subject to the general penalty for violations set forth in Section 1-82 of this Code in addition to immediate revocation of his or her contractor's license.
