Sec. 18-23. - Type I Sustainable Building Regulations. 
(a)  Purpose. The intent of the Sustainable Building Regulations is to encourage cost-effective sustainable building methods to create durable, energy-efficient structures that conserve natural resources, promote the efficient use of building materials and improve indoor air quality. 
(b)  Applicability. These Sustainable Building Regulations apply to all new single-family, duplex and townhouse (attached single-family) construction, additions, reconstruction of over fifty percent (50%) of the existing floor area; and exterior energy uses such as snowmelt, spas and pools over sixty-four (64) square feet or patio heaters. Prior to the issuance of a residential building permit for new construction, additions, reconstruction of over fifty percent (50%) of the existing floor area and exterior energy uses, compliance with the appropriate threshold level established by Subsection (d) below, based on conditioned building area, must be demonstrated. Exterior energy uses must be mitigated one hundred percent (100%) on site per Subsection 18-24(a) of this Article. Commitments to construction methods and materials are binding toward issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
    Exception: Manufactured housing approved by Colorado Department of Housing. 
(c)  Definitions: 
    Biomass fuel means any plant-derived fuel available on a renewable or recurring basis, including agricultural crops and trees, wood and wood waste and residues (including wood pellets), plants (including aquatic plants), grasses, residues and fibers. 
    Conditioned building area means the area in a building, inside insulated walls, being heated or cooled, containing uninsulated ducts or with a fixed opening directly into an adjacent conditioned space. 
    Renewable energy source means incoming solar radiation and photosynthetic processes; natural phenomenon, including wind, hydropower and lake or pond thermal differences; from decomposition of waste material; and processes that use regenerative materials, including wood and bio-based products; and from the internal heat of the earth. 
(d)  Minimum requirements. Residential design and construction must meet the minimum thresholds below. For projects with more than one (1) dwelling unit, each unit must meet the minimum threshold. Minimum point thresholds and individual project scores upon completion will be entered on the certificate of occupancy. 
(1)  Methods and materials identified on a checklist by the applicant will be verified as part of the plan review or on field inspections, accordingly. Checklists may be revised over the course of a project, provided that minimum threshold points are maintained. Threshold levels for residential buildings and residential portions of mixed-use buildings are: 
a.  Zero (0) to two thousand (2,000) square feet of conditioned building area would need to meet sixty (60) points or more. 
b.  Two thousand one (2,001) to three thousand (3,000) square feet of conditioned building area would need to meet seventy (70) points or more. 
c.  Three thousand one (3,001) to four thousand (4,000) square feet of conditioned building area would need to meet eighty (80) points or more. 
d.  Four thousand one (4,001) to five thousand (5,000) square feet of conditioned building area would need to meet ninety (90) points or more. 
Threshold levels increase ten (10) points for air conditioning. 
(2)  For measures where a graduated point scale is possible, the following shall apply: 
a.  Quantity Level 1: 10-25% 
b.  Quantity Level 2: 26-50% 
c.  Quantity Level 3: 51-75% 
d.  Quantity Level 4: 76--00% 
For example, if a programmable thermostat (Paragraph 18-25(d)(17), one [1] point per Quantity Level) is installed that controls fifteen percent (15%) of the habitable space, then one (1) point would be applied. If programmable thermostats controlled one hundred percent (100%) of the habitable space, then four (4) points would be applied. 
(Ord. 11 §1, 2009; Ord. 21 §2, 2015) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. 21 , adopted Dec. 8, 2015, changed the title of § 18-23 from "Sustainable Building Regulations" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-24. - Type I Sustainable Building Regulations-Exterior Energy Uses. 
(a)  Mitigation required. Sustainable Building Practices discourage exterior energy uses. Approval for snowmelt and outdoor spas/hot tubs can be gained only through one-hundred-percent on-site mitigation with renewable energy. Any energy use by snow and ice melt systems, patio heaters and similar outdoor features or equipment requiring a building permit must be offset by on-site renewable energy generation equivalent to the energy used. 
(b)  Snowmelt energy use for dwelling units is thirty-four thousand four hundred twenty-five (34,425) BTUs per square foot per year at one-hundred-percent efficiency. Outdoor hot tubs/spas energy use is four hundred thirty thousand (430,000) BTUs per square foot per year. 
(c)  To determine required mitigation, calculate the energy consumption from depletable sources used. Energy use must be adjusted for actual appliance efficiency. 
For example: 
For one thousand (1,000) square feet of snowmelt from a ninety-percent efficient boiler: (34,425/0.90)1,000 = 38,250,000 BTU/s.f./year must be mitigated. In kWh, that is 38,250,000/3,412, or 11,210 kWh per year of photovoltaic (PV) mitigation. 
(Ord. 11 §1, 2009; Ord. 21 §3, 2015) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. 21 , adopted Dec. 8, 2015, changed the title of § 18-24 from "Exterior energy uses" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-25. - Type I Sustainable Building Regulations-Point Details. 
(a)  Site/water conservation. 
(1)  Limit site impact to ten (10) feet beyond building footprint. 
a.  Benefit: Unaltered natural native vegetation outside of impacted construction area and driveway. Not applicable for sites not meeting minimum landscaping requirements or for previously impacted landscape. Thinning required for wildfire mitigation is exempt. 
b.  Qualification: Show detailed construction management plan with sediment fence/limits of construction no more than ten (10) feet around proposed building footprint. Driveway and material storage exempted. Show areas impacted by construction on landscaping plan. 
c.  Points: 3. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and foundation inspection. 
(2)  Ultra-low or dual-flush toilets. 
a.  Benefit: Toilets typically use the most water of any household fixture or appliance on a daily basis. New and improved high-efficiency models use less water per flush. 
b.  Qualification: All toilets must be ultra-low or dual-flush. A toilet using one and four-tenths (1.4) gallons per flush (GPF) or less qualifies as an ultra-low-flush toilet. 
c.  Points: 2 per fixture (6 maximum). 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(3)  Low-flow showerheads. 
a.  Benefit: According to the EPA, showering represents approximately seventeen percent (17%) of residential indoor water use in the United States. Low-flow showerheads reduce water consumption and the energy used to heat shower water. 
b.  Qualification: Showerheads emitting two (2) gallons per minute or less must be installed on all showers. Provide any documentation for on-site inspection. No more than one (1) showerhead per one thousand two hundred ninety-six (1,296) square inches of shower stall floor area and require showerheads to be at least thirty-six (36) inches apart. 
c.  Points: 1 per fixture (3 maximum). 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(4)  Low-flow bathroom faucets. 
a.  Benefit: Faucets account for more than fifteen percent (15%) of indoor household water use. Low-flow bathroom sink faucets and accessories can reduce a sink's water flow by thirty percent (30%) or more without sacrificing performance. 
b.  Qualification: Bathroom sink faucets must be WaterSense listed and labeled. Listings of approved products are available at www.epa.gov/watersense . 
c.  Points: 1 per fixture (3 maximum). 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(5)  Water efficient clothes washer and/or dishwasher. 
a.  Benefit: Traditional washing machines average about forty-one (41) gallons of water per load, but new, energy- and water-conserving models (front-loading or top-loading, nonagitator ones) use only sixteen (16) to twenty (20) gallons per load. Efficient dishwashers use about one-third ( 1/3 ) less water and forty-one percent (41%) less energy to heat water and dry. 
b.  Qualification: The clothes washer and dishwasher must be listed on www.aceee.org or www.energystar.gov or must be shown to have similar water usage. 
c.  Points: 1 per appliance. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(6)  Storm water reuse plan. 
a.  Benefit: Recycling storm water from buildings for landscape irrigation reduces water usage and restores groundwater. One (1) inch of water on one thousand (1,000) square feet of roof equals two hundred sixty-five (265) gallons of fresh water. Collection and storage of natural precipitation is prohibited by state law. 
b.  Qualification: Provide a grading plan which illustrates the principal and construct swales to maximize distribution of surface drainage to planted areas on site or direct surface drainage to a larger, neighborhood eco-system. Subsurface "deep-root" irrigation for individual plantings also qualifies. 
c.  Points: 4. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(b)  Recycling and reuse. 
(1)  Use of pine beetle salvage wood. 
a.  Benefit: Pine beetle affected lumber harvested in the State can be utilized as dimensional framing material, as well as siding, flooring, trim, etc. 
b.  Qualification: Material must be used for over fifty percent (50%) of structure. 
c.  Points: 3 per application. 
d.  Confirmation will be at framing and final inspection. 
(2)  Surplus/deconstructed materials donated to building materials exchange. 
a.  Benefit: Extra onsite materials, either new or deconstructed, can be donated to a local materials exchange yard. Currently, the RECON yard in Wolcott, the Habitat for Humanity ReStore in Glenwood Springs and Pitkin County Landfill accept most dimensional lumber and new or used building products. Site pickup is available. 
b.  Qualification: Keep records and receipts of donated materials on job site. 
c.  Points: 1 per trailer load. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(3)  Wood, scrap metal, cardboard recycled on site. 
a.  Benefit: Reduced impact on landfill from construction materials. The landfill offers a fifty-percent reduced tipping fee for separated wood waste. 
b.  Qualification: Show on construction management plan. Labeled containers for wood, metal and cardboard construction waste located on site with evidence of use and service. 
c.  Points: 2 per material type recycled. For example, if cardboard and wood scrap were being recycled in containers on site, 4 points would be given. 
d.  Confirmation will be at framing inspection. 
(4)  Reclaimed and/or recycle-content materials. 
a.  Benefit: Use of construction materials reclaimed from another structure and/or any materials with recycle content in them. Material reclaimed from local deconstruction provides added benefit. 
b.  Qualification: Provide material info with building permit. Materials that are architectural salvage, purchased from a reclaimed materials distributor, deconstructed by the owner/applicant from another structure or that are purchased from a used building materials exchange (RECON yard in Wolcott, Habitat for Humanity ReStore in Glenwood Springs, etc.) all qualify as reclaimed materials. Some common recycle-content materials include fly-ash concrete, steel studs/I-beams, composite decking, recycle-content faux shake/slate roofing, cellulose or shredded cotton batt-insulation, recycle-content carpets, countertops, tile, etc. Material must be used for over fifty percent (50%) of building component. Documentation must be on job site. 
c.  Points: 2 per material used. 1 additional point for reuse of local materials (from the Western Slope). 
d.  Confirmation will be at framing inspection. 
(5)  Built-in recycling center. 
a.  Benefit: A conveniently located recycling center in the home will encourage the process. Up to thirty (30) square feet of space dedicated to recycling will be exempted from FAR calculations as mechanical/utility space. 
b.  Qualification: Design and build a recycling center, in or adjacent to the kitchen, with at least two (2) bins for glass, cans, plastic, paper, compost and other common recycling items. 
c.  Points: 3. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(c)  Materials and framing. 
(1)  Materials manufactured within the State. 
a.  Benefit: Limit transportation and reduce the environmental effects. 
b.  Qualification: Provide documentation on site for any materials used that are manufactured in the State. Concrete does not qualify. 
c.  Points: 2 per material used. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(2)  Insulated Concrete Forms (ICFs). 
a.  For foundation. 
1.  Benefit: Insulated Concrete Forms (ICFs) are expanded-polystyrene foam blocks which are stacked with concrete poured into the internal void. ICFs provide improved insulation and reduced moisture transport over conventional foundation walls. 
2.  Qualification: ICFs shown on structural drawings. 
3.  Points: 5. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
b.  For basement/foundation walls plus above-grade walls. 
1.  Qualification: ICFs shown on structural drawings must be used for more than seventy-five percent (75%) of exterior walls. 
2.  Points: 10. 
3.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(3)  Structural/framing dimensions in two-foot increments. 
a.  Benefit: Even dimensions reduce material waste and labor. 
b.  Qualification: Show exterior dimensions on site/floor plans. Exterior dimensions in two-foot increments must be incorporated in seventy-five percent (75%) or more of the building footprint. 
c.  Points: 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
(4)  Optimum value engineering techniques used. 
a.  Benefit: Conserve building materials. 
b.  Qualification: Use twenty-four-inch on center studs for over fifty percent (50%) of the structure. Use two-stud corners for over fifty percent (50%) of framing. Use efficient headers in over fifty percent (50%) of framing. Efficient headers refers to insulated headers on exterior walls (minimum R-10) or eliminating headers in non-load-bearing walls. 
c.  Points: 2 per feature; maximum of 6. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(5)  Engineered structural lumber used in floors, walls and/or roofs. 
a.  Benefit: Smaller, fast-growing tree species are used in engineered lumber, and there is little or no waste involved in the production and end use of the products. Engineered lumber products are an innovative alternative to the solid sawn lumber materials that have to be harvested in diminishing old-growth forests. 
b.  Qualification: Must be in place for over fifty percent (50%) of the structure. 
c.  Points: 1 for floors only; 2 for floors, roof and/or walls. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(6)  Pre-cut studs, trusses, walls and/or sections. 
a.  Benefit: Pre-cut or off-site construction of structures reduces material waste. 
b.  Qualification: Use precut studs and trusses for over seventy-five percent (75%) of the structure (2 points). Use panelized or prefabricated walls. (2 additional points). Use prefabricated sections or modular construction for over seventy-five percent (75%) or more of the building (2 additional points). 
c.  Points: 2 to 4. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(7)  FSC- or SFI-certified materials used. 
a.  Benefit: Preserve old-growth forests by promoting sustainably harvested wood products. 
b.  Qualification: Wood certified by either the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) or Sustainable Forestry Initiative (SFI). Greenspot, in Glenwood Springs, and Valley Lumber, in Basalt, are certified by both organizations for chain of custody. Material must be used in over fifty percent (50%) of building. 
c.  Points: 2 points per material used. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(8)  Structural Insulated Panels (SIPs) or straw bale used for exterior walls. 
a.  Benefit: SIPs (a foam core laminated to oriented strand board) and straw bale construction provide superior R-values and reduced air infiltration to conventional two-by-six wall construction. 
b.  Qualification: Must be used for more than seventy-five percent (75%) of exterior walls. 
c.  Points: 10. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
(d)  Energy. 
(1)  HERS rated house. 
a.  Benefit: The overall energy efficiency of Home Energy Rating System (HERS)-rated homes is usually higher than minimum building code standards. E-Star is an accredited HERS provider and the major trainer and certifier of Home Energy Raters in the State. An E-Star energy rating gives each home a score expressed on a scale from zero (0) to one hundred (100), with one hundred (100) as the 2003 IECC baseline. The goal is to be "better than code" and ultimately "net zero." Complete information, including local rating professionals, is available at www.e-star.com . 
b.  Qualification: Submit documentation with plans from an HERS professional showing calculations showing an index of eighty (80) or less and, at completion of the project, an As-Built Energy Rating Report with a rating of eighty (80) or less. 5 points additional for an index rating of seventy-five (75) or less; 5 points additional for an index rating of seventy (70) or less; and 5 points additional for net zero. 
c.  Points: 5 to 20. 
d.  Confirmation will be upon presentation of the qualifying As-Built Energy Rating Report. 
(2)  Blower door test only. 
a.  Benefit: Promotes tighter construction and pinpoints areas of air infiltration. Air tightness is one (1) of the main principles of energy conservation; this is the only way to quantify it. 
b.  Qualification: Complete a blower door test by a certified professional that accurately shows air changes per hour (ACH). Test results must show ACH of 0.40 or less. 
c.  Points: 5. 
d.  Confirmation will be upon presentation of the qualifying test results. 
(3)  Roof/ceiling insulation. 
a.  Benefit: Increased insulation levels reduce heat loss. This is the most effective use of insulation to reduce overall heat loss. 
b.  Qualification: Show roof/ceiling insulation plan. Install per plan. Post completed Insulation Certificate in mechanical room. 
c.  Points: 1 to 15 - 1 point for each R-value over thirty-eight (38), up to 15 points maximum. For example, if an R-50 roof is installed, 12 points would be given. 
d.  Confirmation will be at insulation inspection. 
(4)  Reflective radiant barrier. 
a.  Benefit: A reflective radiant barrier installed in a vented attic space reduces ceiling heat gains and cooling loads in summer. 
b.  Qualification: Show and specify a reflective radiant barrier on roof/ceiling insulation plan. Install a reflective radiant barrier on the "ceiling" or "floor" of the attic or under the roof sheathing of a vaulted ceiling. 
c.  Points: 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at framing if installed on or under roof sheathing; or insulation inspection if laid over insulation. 
(5)  Wall insulation. 
a.  Benefit: Increased insulation levels reduce heat loss. 
b.  Qualification: Show wall insulation in construction plans. Install per plan. Post completed insulation certificate in mechanical room. 
c.  Points: 1 to 15 - 1 point given for each R-value over nineteen (19), up to 15 points maximum. For example, if an R-30 wall is installed, 11 points would be given. 
d.  Confirmation will be at insulation inspection. 
(6)  Exterior insulation. 
a.  Benefit: The so-called Residential Exterior Membrane Outside-Insulation Technique (REMOTE) eliminates thermal bridging, thereby increasing the effective R-value of the insulation. A REMOTE shell provides a very tight air envelope. 
b.  Qualification: Detail a REMOTE system on plans. Specify a minimum three-inch rigid (EPS or XPS) exterior insulation. Requires effective mechanical ventilation system and sealed combustion appliances. Visit www.cchrc.org/remote.aspx for more information. 
c.  Points: 5 points for three-inch minimum exterior rigid insulation; 10 points for six-inch minimum insulation. 
d.  Confirmation will be at insulation inspection. 
(7)  Slab insulation. 
a.  Benefit: Increased insulation levels reduce heat loss. 
b.  Qualification: For slab-on-grade and basement floor, show compression-resistant insulation under the slab on construction plans. Install per plan. 
c.  Points: 1 point for R-5 insulation; 2 points for R-8 insulation; 3 points for R-16 insulation; 4 points for R-20 minimum insulation. 
d.  Confirmation will be prior to slab pour. 
(8)  Crawl space/basement wall insulation. 
a.  Benefit: Increased insulation levels reduce heat loss. 
b.  Qualification: For crawl space and/or basement walls, show insulation of wall in construction plans. Install per plan. Insulation must be continuous for entire wall area below main floor. 
c.  Points: 1 to 3 - For minimum R-10, 1 point; for minimum R-15, 2 points; for R-19 or higher, 3 points. 
d.  Confirmation will be at insulation or final inspection. 
(9)  Blown or sprayed insulation. 
a.  Benefit: Blown or sprayed insulation reduces air infiltration and offers higher effective R-values than batt insulation. 
b.  Qualification: Specify blown fiberglass or cellulose or spray-foam insulation on plans. Blown insulation installed in attics/ceilings, walls and basements/ crawl spaces. 
c.  Points: 1 per Quantity Level - 1 point given for each quantity level of blown or sprayed insulation installed. For example, if eighty percent (80%) of the insulation in a structure is blown-in, then quantity level 4 (76-100%) or 4 points would be given. 
d.  Confirmation will be at insulation inspection. 
(10)  Insulate hot water pipes at all locations. 
a.  Benefit: Insulating hot water pipes reduces heat loss through the plumbing system. Hot water is delivered to point of use faster, reducing water waste. 
b.  Qualification: Closed cell foam or fiberglass pipe insulation with a minimum 2.5 R-value must be installed on all hot water pipes. Install R-5 for 2 points. 
c.  Points: 1 to 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plumbing rough-in inspection. 
(11)  Energy-efficient windows. 
a.  Benefit: High performance windows significantly increase a wall's thermal resistance, helping keep the interior warmer in the winter and cooler in the summer. 
b.  Qualification: Provide window manufacturer specifications with window schedule as part of construction plans. Leave window labels in place until inspected. 
c.  Points: 2 points for each U-.05 below U-.35 (for example, U-.30 = 2 pts). 
d.  Confirmation will be at framing inspection. 
(12)  Insulating window coverings installed. 
a.  Benefit: Windows, even high performance models, are still typically the largest point of heat loss in walls. By utilizing insulating window coverings, a window's thermal performance can be doubled or tripled. 
b.  Qualification: Window coverings must be installed on seventy-five percent (75%), or more, of the windows and have a minimum R-3 to qualify. Some common options are duet/cellular shades or quilted shades. 
c.  Points: 3. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(13)  Radiant floor/hydronic baseboard heating system. 
a.  Benefit: Buildings with hydronic heating systems have consistently shown lower heating energy use than equivalent structures with forced-air heating systems. Occupants are warmed at lower air temperatures with radiant heat. Hydronic systems can be zoned, which provides the potential for unoccupied rooms to be kept at lower temperatures, which lowers heat loss and reduces fuel consumption. 
b.  Qualification: Either in-floor radiant heat or baseboard hydronic heat qualifies, provided that over fifty percent (50%) of the heating needs of the structure are met by hydronic means. 
c.  Points: 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at mechanical rough-in and final inspection. 
(14)  Efficient boiler or furnace. 
a.  Benefit: Efficient operation reduces energy consumption and emissions. 
b.  Qualification: Specify and install a heating appliance with an AFUE rating of at least eighty-eight percent (88%). 
c.  Points: 1 to 7 - If a boiler and/or furnace with a combined AFUE rating of eighty-eight percent (88%) is installed, then 1 point is given. For each point of efficiency above eighty-eight percent (88%) up to ninety-four percent (94%), an additional point is given. For example, if a boiler has an AFUE rating of ninety-four percent (94%), then 7 points would be given. 
d.  Confirmation will be at heating inspection. 
(15)  Ductwork in conditioned spaces. 
a.  Benefit: Whenever possible, running ductwork through unconditioned space, especially attics, should be avoided. It creates a potential for heat loss, moisture and mold problems. 
b.  Qualification: Keep all ductwork within thermal envelope, or ducts in unconditioned space should be sealed with mastic at all joints and insulated to a minimum R-6; R-8 minimum in attics. 
c.  Points: 2 for all ductwork within conditioned space; or 1 for properly sealed and insulated ductwork in unconditioned space. 
d.  Confirmation will be at HVAC rough-in inspection. 
(16)  No mechanical air conditioning. 
a.  Benefit: Eliminating the need for air conditioning offers an immediate initial cost savings as well as reduced operational costs for the life of the structure. 
b.  Qualification: Proper design of building aspect, window sizing and placement, overhang shading and insulation can eliminate the need for air-conditioning systems in our climate. No components for a roughed-in system should be installed. 
c.  Points: 4. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(17)  Programmable thermostats. 
a.  Benefit: Allows occupants to set heating and cooling needs to their lifestyle. 
b.  Qualification: Thermostats that automatically change programmed temperature settings must be installed and be functional. If a programmable thermostat controls fifteen percent (15%) of the habitable space, then 1 point would be applied. If programmable thermostats control one hundred percent (100%) of the habitable space, then 4 points would be applied. 
c.  Points: 1 to 4 (graduated point scale). 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(18)  Thermostats for each room. 
a.  Benefit: A zoned system allows heating and cooling to be isolated to occupied rooms only. 
b.  Qualification: Each enclosed room must have a separate thermostat, not including storage areas, closets, bathrooms, mechanical rooms or nonhabitable space. 
c.  Points: 4. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(19)  Tankless on-demand water heater or efficient gas water heater. 
a.  Benefit: Efficient operation reduces energy consumption and emissions. 
b.  Qualification: Gas or electric tankless models qualify and must meet over fifty percent (50%) of total domestic hot water needs. Boiler side-arms (water heaters), off of a modulating, condensing boiler ninety-percent efficiency or above; a combined (space and water heating) appliance efficiency rating (CAE) of 0.85 or higher; or a condensing water heater with a thermal efficiency rating of ninety percent (90%) or higher also qualify. Units must have an intermittent ignition device (IID) instead of a standing pilot light. 
c.  Points: 3; or gas water heaters with eighty-eight-percent efficiency or above receive 2 points. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(20)  Energy Star appliances. 
a.  Benefit: Energy Star appliances are designed and tested for energy efficiency as well as water conservation. 
b.  Qualification: Appliances, other than those credited for water conservation (Paragraph 18-25(a)(4)) with the EPA's Energy Star logo on them and/or listed on www.energystar.gov website qualify. Clothes dryers are not Energy Star rated; however, an outdoor clothesline will qualify. 
c.  Points: 1 to 4 (graduated point scale). 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection, with appliances installed and operable. 
(21)  Ceiling fans/air destratification system in common rooms. 
a.  Benefit: Ceiling fans and air-handling systems help to reduce the accumulation of warm air at ceiling level and exfiltration through the ceiling during the winter; and they circulate air in the summer, making a room feel cooler. 
b.  Qualification: Show units/systems in construction plans. 
c.  Points: 1 per fan to a maximum of 4. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(22)  Installation of whole-house fan natural cooling/ventilation system. 
a.  Benefit: Help cool a structure by flushing warm air from inside living space, as well as the attic. Such ventilation systems can help reduce or eliminate air-conditioning cooling loads. 
b.  Qualification: Whole-house fan natural cooling/ventilation systems installed in the ceilings and attic. Systems must operable manually and by automated thermostat. Fans should be sized to produce between four (4) to five (5) air changes per hour (ACH) at maximum speed. For design purposes, use the following formula: 
    Minimum fan CFMs = Volume of house x 4-5 ACH/60, where Volume = square footage of house interior x average ceiling height. 
c.  Points: 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(23)  Centralized heat recovery ventilation (HRV). 
a.  Benefit: An HRV unit integrated with a forced-air heating system increases heating efficiency. It can be operated independent of the furnace to circulate and freshen indoor air during winter and summer. 
b.  Qualification: Majority of total mechanical ventilation must go through an HRV unit for points. 
c.  Points: 8. 
d.  Confirmation will be at heating inspection. 
(24)  Exterior lighting minimized. 
a.  Benefit: Reduces nighttime light pollution, glaring and offensive light sources and conserves energy. 
b.  Qualification: Exterior lighting plan to be submitted with construction plans. Total exterior lighting must be less than five thousand five hundred (5,500) lumens for points. (One-hundred-watt incandescent or twenty-three-watt CFL light bulbs produce around one thousand six hundred (1,600) lumens; sixty-watt incandescent or thirteen-watt CFL bulbs produce around eight hundred (800) lumens; and forty-watt incandescent or nine-watt CFL bulbs produce around four hundred fifty (450) lumens, according to Energy Star). LED bulbs produce approximately twenty (20) lumens per watt. 
c.  Points: 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(25)  Efficient lighting. 
a.  Benefit: Alternatives to incandescent bulbs use twenty percent (20%) or less wattage for equivalent lumens. 
b.  Qualification: Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFLs), T8s, T5s, LEDs or equivalent comply. Over fifty percent (50%) of the bulbs installed must be alternatives to incandescent. 
c.  Points: 2; 4 points for fifty percent (50%) LEDs. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
Note: CFL bulbs contain mercury and must be disposed of properly (as hazardous waste) when broken or burned out. More info at www. cdphe. state. co. us /hm /mercury /cflfact sheet. pdf . 
(26)  Motion-detecting light switches. 
a.  Benefit: Lighting operated by motion detection saves energy while increasing safety and security. 
b.  Qualification: Install motion-detection-controlled lighting as an integrated unit or by a remote motion sensor for closets, basements, etc. 
c.  Points: 1 to 4 - 1 point is given for each motion detection switch installed, up to 4 points. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(e)  Renewable energy sources. 
(1)  Passive solar design. 
a.  Benefit: Effective passive solar design allows for southeast-facing solar heat gain and heat storage in thermal mass of the interior during the winter, while properly shading south-facing windows to prevent unwanted heat gain during the summer. 
b.  Qualification: Site must have reasonably unobstructed solar access. Deciduous trees are allowable to the south, and desirable to the east and west, for summer shading. Site plan must show a Sun Angles Dial along with the North Arrow, showing at minimum angles of sunrise, angles of the sun at noon and angles of sunset for summer solstice, equinox and winter solstice respectively. In Basalt, the angles of the noon sun are sixty-eight (68), forty-seven (47) and twenty-five (25) degrees for summer solstice, equinox and winter solstice, respectively. 
1.  Optimize glazing. 
a)  Install south-facing (within at least twenty [20] degrees east of due south) glass equivalent to seven percent (7%) or more of total heated floor area. Effective south-facing windows require a high Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC) - typically 0.60 or higher - to maximize heat gain. 
b)  Points: 10. 
2.  Shading. 
a)  Install south-facing glass equivalent to twelve percent (12%) or less of total heated floor area and provide proper shading according to the formula E = H / 3.38, or conversely, H = E x 3.38, where E = eave depth and H = height of bottom of window from the eave. 
b)  Points: 10. 
3.  Thermal mass. 
a)  For each square foot of south-facing glass, provide at minimum an equivalent square footage of thermal mass interior walls and/or floor reached by the solar gain. Examples of thermal mass include concrete, Gyp-Crete, tile, masonry or stone floors; double-layered sheetrock, masonry, stone, adobe walls. 
b)  Points: 5. 
c.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(2)  Solar hot water system. 
a.  For domestic hot water. 
1.  Benefit: Supply or supplement hot water for domestic use with little or no energy consumption. 
2.  Qualification: Install a solar hot water system, which includes rooftop or ground-mounted panel collectors connected to a heat exchanger and/or insulated storage tank for domestic hot water supply. System must have unobstructed solar access. Systems may be active, using solar or electric pumps, or they may utilize a thermal siphon. Collectors must be facing within twenty (20) degrees of due south and between thirty (30) and fifty (50) degrees from horizontal. System size is dependent on number of bedrooms. Evacuated-tube collectors are typically twenty-five percent (25%) more efficient than flat-plate collectors. Parenthesized areas are minimum requirements for evacuated-tube collectors. 
a)  One (1) bedroom - forty (40) square feet of collectors (thirty [30] square feet), fifty (50) gallons storage. 
b)  Two (2) bedrooms - forty-eight (48) square feet of collectors (thirty-six [36] square feet), sixty (60) gallons storage. 
c)  Three (3) bedrooms - sixty-four (64) square feet of collectors (forty-eight [48] square feet), eighty (80) gallons storage. 
d)  Four (4) + bedrooms - ninety-six (96) square feet of collectors (seventy-two [72] square feet), one hundred twenty (120) gallons storage. 
3.  Points: 8. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
b.  Integrated solar hot water system that supplements both radiant floor heat and domestic hot water. 
1.  Benefit: Supply or supplement hot water for domestic use and space heating with little or no energy consumption. 
2.  Qualification: Install a solar hot water system sized as previous (bedroom based) that provides heat for radiant floor heating as well as domestic hot water. Show system in construction plans and schematics. 
3.  Points: 16. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
c.  Solar hot water system rough-in only. 
1.  Benefit: Simplifies solar retrofit if undertaken in the future. 
2.  Qualifications: Two (2) runs of copper plumbing pipe, three-quarter-inch minimum, insulated to an R-6 minimum, must be installed in an interior wall and start in the mechanical room or near the area that will house the storage tank/heat exchanger. An 18/2 wire must also be run at the same location for future control installations. The plumbing and wiring should terminate in an attic space under the roof that will support the solar collectors, and it shall be above the insulation for easy sighting. If there isn't an attic space, the piping and wiring shall end after penetrating the roof that will support the collectors. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(3)  On-site power generation. 
a.  Benefit: Power generated on site from natural processes reduces demands on regional power plants. 
1.  Solar photovoltaic system. 
a)  Benefit: Photovoltaic (PV devices) change sunlight directly into household electricity. 
b)  Qualification: Applicant must submit plans from a qualified architect, engineer or designer certifying the kW capacity and proper system design. Photovoltaic panels should be mounted within twenty (20) degrees of due south and between thirty (30) and fifty (50) degrees from horizontal. System must have reasonably unobstructed solar access. Proper protection to prevent electric islanding must be in place in the event of a power outage. Thin film PV is acceptable. 
c)  Points: 10 for every one (1) kW installed, to a maximum of 50 or net zero. 
d)  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
2.  Solar photovoltaic system rough-in only. 
a)  Benefit: Simplifies solar retrofit if undertaken in the future. 
b)  Qualifications: A one-inch conduit must be installed between the attic/roof and the future inverter location, in the general vicinity of the electrical panel. Ends of the conduit shall be labeled "solar." Conduit terminating in an attic space under the roof that will support the solar collectors shall be above the insulation for easy sighting. If there isn't an attic space, the piping and wiring shall end on the roof that will support the collectors, in a sealed junction box. Provide three (3) feet by three (3) feet of wall space thirty (30) inches deep (FAR exempt) for a future inverter. Reserve two (2) slots in the main breaker panel for a 240-volt breaker. 
c)  Points: 2. 
d)  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
3.  Ground source heat pump (geothermal) system. 
a)  Benefit: Ground source heat pumps utilize glycol loop systems drilled into the ground to heat or cool a structure. 
b)  Qualification: Points are given for each quantity level of the structure's heating/cooling needs met by the system. If utilized for a snowmelt system, total energy calculations must include exterior energy use as well. 
c)  Points: 10 to 40 - 10 points per quantity level. For example, if the system met sixty percent (60%) of the structure's heating/cooling needs, quantity level 3 (51-75%), at 10 points per quantity level, 30 points would be given. 
d)  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
4.  High-efficiency wood-burning stove. 
a)  Benefit: Wood- and biomass-fuel burning technology has improved tremendously in recent years. Woodstove efficiency has increased, and emissions rates have been reduced with pellet, soapstone, catalytic and noncatalytic stoves. Additional information may be found at www.static. hpba.org/fileadmin/factsheets/product/EPACertWoodburning.pdf . 
b)  Qualification: Specify stove make and model number on plans. Stoves may generate no more than two (2) grams/hour of particulate and must exceed seventy-five-percent efficiency as determined by EPA (New Source Performance Standard for New Residential Wood Heaters) test methods using Low-Heat Value protocol. Provide EPA "Temporary Label," manufacturer's (IRS) certification statement or other documentation at plan review. Installation must conform to manufacturer's recommendations at final inspection. 
c)  Points: 4. 
d)  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
5.  A five-year commitment of wind energy from Holy Cross Energy or Xcel Energy. 
a)  Benefit: Wind is a clean, inexhaustible, indigenous energy resource. On-site wind power is not practical in the Town; however, wind energy credits are available through Holy Cross Energy ( www.holycross.com ). For around two and one-half cents ($0.025) per kWh above the current rate, residents can purchase wind energy for their home use equivalent. 
b)  Qualification: Submit copy of applicable electric bill from utility showing level of wind energy commitment (if available), as well as signed document from the applicant stating a minimum five-year commitment at given levels. 
c)  Points: 2 per Quantity Level - For example, if your wind energy commitment represented one hundred percent (100%) of your average monthly use, then Quantity Level 4 (76%-100%) would apply, 2 points per quantity level, giving the applicant 8 points. 
d)  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
(f)  Indoor air quality. 
(1)  Formaldehyde-free and/or low-toxic insulation. 
a.  Benefit: Formaldehyde resins have been used in the manufacture of fiberglass batts. Out-gassing of formaldehyde, a probable human carcinogen, has been found to contaminate indoor air. Use of alternative insulating products reduces exposure to occupants. 
b.  Qualification: Insulation must be labeled as formaldehyde-free or Green Guard certified at www.greenguard.org. 
c.  Points: Required. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and insulation inspection. 
(2)  Low- or zero-VOC and/or low-toxic interior paint, stain/finishes and adhesives. 
a.  Benefit: Interior paint contributes to total VOC levels. 
b.  Qualification: EPA regulations call for no more than two hundred fifty (250) gm/L of Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) in low-VOC latex paints and no more than three hundred eighty (380) gm/L for low-VOC oil-based paints/ stains. Products must be either labeled "Low VOC," Green Guard certified ( www.greenguard.org ) or show that VOC levels are below EPA thresholds. 
c.  Points: Required. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(3)  Low- or non-toxic floor coverings. 
a.  Benefit: Carpet and other traditional floor coverings contribute VOCs to indoor air. 
b.  Qualification: Materials either listed on www.greenguard.org or show that coverings are below EPA thresholds for low- or non-toxicity. 
c.  Points: 1 per Quantity Level - Quantity Level is determined by the percentage of total floor area meeting the above criteria. For example, if eighty percent (80%) of the total flooring was non-toxic, then Quantity Level 4 (76-100%) would apply, 1 point per Quantity Level, so 4 points would be given. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(4)  "Smart" vapor retarder in walls. 
a.  Benefit: Eliminating moisture from wall cavities prevents mold and decay fungi from developing. This product allows closed building envelope systems to increase their drying potential with seasonal climatic changes. 
b.  Qualification: Install a vapor-retarder system in exterior walls that allows for moisture permeability above sixty percent (60%) relative humidity. Specify on wall sections. 
c.  Points: 5. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and insulation inspection. 
(5)  All furnaces, fireplaces, boilers, gas water heaters, sealed-combustion/direct-vented. 
a.  Benefit: Sealed-combustion/ direct-vented gas appliances reduce the risk of combustion byproducts entering the indoor environment and supply combustion air from outside directly to the combustion chamber. 
b.  Qualification: Submit appliance specifications with construction plans. 
c.  Points: 4. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and heating inspection. 
(6)  High-efficiency filter on HVAC system (HEPA, UV, etc.). 
a.  Benefit: High-efficiency filters remove contaminates down to 0.3 microns in size from circulating air. Ultraviolet light which kills virtually all microorganisms (98.9%) can be installed. 
b.  Qualification: Install a high-efficiency filter on a forced-air distribution system. Installed filter must be rated at ninety-nine percent (99%) efficiency or higher. 
c.  Points: HEPA 4; UV 5. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(7)  Heat recovery ventilation. 
a.  Benefit: An HRV system captures potentially lost warm air while ventilating interior space with fresh air. It is an energy-efficient way to remove moisture, odors, allergens and harmful gasses from indoor air while minimizing heat loss. 
b.  Qualification: Majority of total mechanical ventilation must go through an HRV unit for points. 
c.  Points: 5. 
d.  Confirmation will be at mechanical rough-in inspection. 
(8)  Range hood exhausted outside or through HRV. 
a.  Benefit: Removes moisture generated from cooking, as well as cooking odors and products of combustion from gas appliances. 
b.  Qualification: Install a range hood to exhaust not more than two hundred (200) CFM to the outside. Larger hoods are required to provide make-up air to prevent depressurization. Hoods larger than six hundred (600) CFM are not permitted in a residence. (So much make-up air is required that it will need tempering.) 
c.  Points: 2. 
d.  Confirmation will be at permit application and final inspection. 
(9)  Radon mitigation. 
a.  Benefit: Radon is a natural radioactive gas that you can't see, smell or taste. The EPA has determined that it is a carcinogen. 
b.  Qualification: Design and install radon mitigation system that removes radon or other soil gas from under the slab/crawlspace and vent per EPA guidelines. More information may be found at www.epa.gov/radon/index and www.buildingscience.com . 
c.  Points: 3. 
d.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
(g)  Innovation points. 
(1)  Innovative product use and/or design points will be given points on a case-by-case basis. 
(2)  The item must specifically meet the intent of the sustainable building regulations as stated at the beginning of this Article. Points will be scaled as the item would apply to similar comparable items in the guidelines, as determined by the plans examiner. 
(3)  Some options eligible for innovation points may include, but are not limited to: Energy 10 Analysis; American Lung Association-certified home; modulating or sequentially staged boilers; net-zero energy home; "Passive House"; frost-protected shallow foundation, trombe wall/interior thermal massing systems, evapotranspiration watering system, on-site cogeneration power system, passive solar lighting, etc. 
(Ord. 11 §1, 2009; Ord. 21 §4, 2015) 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. 21 , adopted Dec. 8, 2015, changed the title of § 18-25 from "Point details" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-26. - Type II Sustainable Building Regulations-Non-Residential and Multi-family Residential. 
(a)  Purpose. The intent of the Sustainable Building Regulations Program is to encourage cost-effective sustainable building methods to create durable, energy efficient structures that conserve natural resources, promote the efficient use of building materials, and improve the quality of the indoor environment for non-residential and multi-family residential development. 
(b)  Applicability and checklist. Type II Sustainable Building Regulations apply to all new non-residential, mixed use, and/or multi-family construction not covered by the Type I Sustainable Building Regulations. Type II Sustainable Building Regulations also apply to additions; reconstruction of over fifty percent (50%) of the existing floor area. A completed Sustainable Building Regulations checklist must be submitted along with a building permit application, demonstrating compliance with the appropriate threshold level based on type of use. References in this section to the IECC shall mean the 2015 IECC. The required categories do not apply to tenant finish permits as long as the tenant finish permit meets the required tenant finish threshold set in this section. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Manufactured housing approved by Colorado Department of Housing; and 
(2)  LEED certified buildings are excepted from compliance with the Type II Sustainable Building Regulations. Projects achieving LEED gold or better will receive a twenty-five percent (25%) building permit rebate, not to exceed the rebate amount specified in the Town of Basalt Fee Schedule. 
(d)  Definitions. 
    Building component is one (1) of the following: framing, wall, siding, flooring, trim, and other primary elements of a building as determined by the Town Building Official. 
    Conditioned building area is the area in building, inside insulated walls, being heated or cooled, containing uninsulated ducts, or with a fixed opening directly into an adjacent conditioned space. 
    Construction element is one (1) of the following: framing material, siding, flooring, trim, and other primary elements of a building as determined by the Town Building Official. 
    Engineered lumber is a composite wood product made from pieces of recycled/reconstituted/scrap wood and fibers bonded together with adhesive to create a durable and resource friendly substitute for raw-sawn lumber. 
    Occupancy is the occupancy as designated by the building code in affect at the time of perm it submittal. 
    Renewable energy source is incoming solar radiation and photosynthetic processes; natural phenomenon including wind, hydropower, and lake or pond thermal differences; from decomposition of waste material; and processes that use regenerative materials, including wood and bio-based products; and from the internal heat of the earth. 
(e)  Point requirements. All Type II construction must demonstrate compliance with these standards by demonstrating that it meets the minimum point thresholds. The minimum points required for applicable construction projects range from 30-68 points depending on the project type as shown below. 
Required Thresholds Commercial building (complete) 68 points Commercial building (core and shell) 65 points Commercial tenant finish 30 points Multi-family (apartments or condos) 65 points Hotel 68 points  
    Projects not meeting the minimum points shall pay a mitigation fee as follows: 
Fee = Square footage of project x number of points short x $ .15. 
For example, a 4,000 square foot project that is 5 points short would be assessed a fee as follows: 
4,000 x 5 x $ .15 = $3,000.00 
(f)  Commitments must be maintained. Commitments to construction methods and materials are binding toward issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or must be mitigated. Commitments that are credited towards satisfying the Type II cannot be removed after issuance of a certificate of occupancy unless sufficient mitigation is provided for the commitment removed to the satisfaction of the Town Building Official. 
(g)  Point details. 
(1)  Site/water conservation. 
a.  1.01 Construction activity pollution prevention (CAPP). 
1.  Benefit: Proper erosion control measures prevent off-site sedimentation in storm sewers, and ultimately, our rivers. 
2.  Qualification: Include on construction management plan, and field implement. Limits of disturbance to have sediment fencing, staked hay bales in swales/drainage ditches, and revegetation matting in any areas outside fencing disturbed by construction. 
3.  Points: Required. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and footing inspection. 
b.  1.02 Site is either a redevelopment location or brownfield redevelopment. 
1.  Benefit: Redevelopment is preferable to sprawl. Brownfields are previously developed industrial and commercial sites that are potentially contaminated. Brownfield redevelopment additionally eliminates the hazard of contaminants. 
2.  Qualification: Show on site plan location of existing or pre-existing structures. Deconstruction is required for existing structures for any reusable/recyclable items. For brownfield redevelopment, show documentation demonstrating previous or existing site contamination and clean-up. 
3.  Points: Redevelopment 5 points. Brownfield redevelopment 10 points 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
c.  1.03 Development density and community connectivity. 
1.  Benefit: High-density development as defined in Site Section Credit 2 of LEED limits sprawl and preserves our natural surroundings and Community connectivity encourages basic services within easy reach of residential neighborhoods as defined in Site Section Credit 2 of LEED. 
2.  Qualification: Demonstrate at plan review that they satisfy both density and connectivity. 
3.  Points: 5. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
d.  1.04 RFTA bus stop. 
1.  Benefit: Convenience promotes bus ridership. 
2.  Qualification: Development is within one-fourth mile of a RFTA bus stop. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
e.  1.05 Proximity to schools. 
1.  Benefit: A close proximity to schools allows children to easily bike or walk to school and alleviates need for use of vehicles. 
2.  Qualification: Demonstrate that property is within one-half mile of schools. 
3.  Points: 1 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
f.  1.06 Walkability/bikability: The site/design provides connection to a multi-use path network. 
1.  Benefit: A close proximity to bike paths allows employees to easily bike, or walk, to work; or to get to work easily and safely from a bus stop. 
2.  Qualification: Show direct connection to path network on site/vicinity plan that are within 1/2 of a mile of a RFTA bus stop. Measurement shall be along the most direct pedestrian with a sidewalk or improved trail. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
g.  1.07 Covered bicycle racks. 
1.  Benefit: Convenient weather protection and security for bikes. 
2.  Qualification: Planned and constructed bike storage must be covered, at a minimum, and include rack space or other means of security for at least one bike per 10 occupants as defined by the building code. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
h.  1.08 Employee changing rooms. 
1.  Benefit: This may encourage employees to bike to work which Benefits not only the environment, but also the employees' fitness level. 
2.  Qualification: Changing rooms must have lockers and shower facilities for employees in commercial buildings. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
i.  1.09 Bike share facility. 
1.  Benefit: Having bikes readily available promotes their use for short trips as an alternative to driving. 
2.  Qualification: Development must be within one-fourth mile of a bike share facility. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
j.  1.10 On-site affordable housing unit, live-work mixed use beyond code-required minimum. 
1.  Benefit: Living where you work makes for a short commute. 
2.  Qualification: Show on-site dwelling unit(s) that meet the Town of Basalt Affordable Housing Guidelines for either a deed restricted for sale unit or rental unit, which are beyond the code-required minimum mitigation. 
3.  Points: 5 per unit; 25 maximum. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
k.  1.11 Maximize open space and habitat. 
1.  Benefit: Lessens visual impact of development; increases visual appeal. Natural habitat supports biodiversity. 
2.  Qualification: Total lot coverage is less than 75% of maximum allowable for lot and total surface parking and hardscape area is less than building footprint(s). 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
l.  1.12 Stormwater design. 
1.  Benefit: Provides a portion of irrigation needs from natural precipitation, eliminates direct discharge of potential pollutants or sediment, and promotes groundwater recharge. 
2.  Qualification: 100% of surface water runoff travels through bioswales, landscaped detention areas, or combination thereof. 
3.  Points: 3. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
m.  1.13 Diverse native landscaping. 
1.  Benefit: Increases survivability rate of plantings; and limits invasive species. 
2.  Qualification: Landscaping plan includes 10 or more native species over 90% of landscaped area. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
n.  1.14 Water efficient landscaping. 
1.  Benefit: Reduces irrigation demands and conserves water. 
2.  Qualification: Irrigated turf area must be equal or less than 40% of landscaped area, or 1,000 square feet, whichever is smaller. Show turf areas and drip-irrigation lines/beds on landscaping plan. Irrigation systems shall be controlled with automatic timer and rain sensors. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
i.  1.14.1 Use of low-water-demand or xeriscape-rated plants only. 
a.  Benefit: Reduced irrigation demands and water conservation at the next level. 
b.  Qualification: Landscaping plan must only show xeriscape plants listed by Colorado State University Extension Horticulture office, listed on www.xratedgardening.com, or source recognized by the Town Building Official. Any turf area (must meet above standard) shall use species that utilizes at least 25% less water than Kentucky blue grass. 
c.  Points: 1 additional point 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
ii.  1.14.2 Landscape design requires no permanent irrigation. 
a.  Benefit: Conserves water. 
b.  Qualification: Landscape plan must meet landscaping minimum standards. (Temporary irrigation is permissible during plant establishment period.) Landscaping must be planted prior to CO to be eligible. 
c.  Points: 4 total. 
d.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
o.  1.15 Interior water use reduction. 
1.  Benefit: Conserves water. 
2.  Qualification: Demonstrate all water use reductions on interior fixtures, including but not limited to: toilets, showers, sinks, faucets, dishwashers, clothes washers and urinals. Estimates are based on average occupant usage pursuant to the 1992 Energy Policy Act (EPACT) for fixture flow rates. (Need to know what this is.) 
3.  Points: 2 for 20% reduction; and 3 points for 30% or more reduction in use. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
p.  1.16 Fill/Excavation Transport Reduction. 
1.  Benefit: Reduces truck traffic necessary to haul excavation spoils and bring in fill. 
2.  Qualification: Dispose of or store excavation spoils within 1 mile of development. Source fill materials within 1 mile of development. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review. 
q.  1.17 Heat island reduction. 
1.  Benefit: Limits heat island effects on microclimates, the built environment, and nature. 
2.  Qualification: Shade parking lots; use solar-reflective building materials. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(2)  Recycling, reuse, materials. 
a.  2.01 Storage and collection of recyclables in design. 
1.  Benefit: Provides for convenient recycling. 
2.  Qualification: Show on construction plans areas for storage of recycling containers next to trash container(s). Adequate space for a cardboard 2-yard minimum container, and toters for co-mingled and newspaper/mixed paper required. 
3.  Points: Required. 
4.  Confirmation: will be at final inspection. 
b.  2.02 Construction waste recycling. 
1.  Benefit: Reduces construction waste to landfills. 
2.  Qualification: Provide labeled containers during construction for recycling cardboard, wood waste, and/or metal scrap. 
3.  Points: 2 per material type; 6 maximum. 
4.  Confirmation: Labeled containers clean of trash with evidence of use must be in place during inspections. 
c.  2.03 Efficient framing techniques. 
1.  Benefit: Optimum value engineering (OVE) reduces building materials and can increase overall energy envelope performance. 
2.  Qualification: Design and construct using advanced framing techniques consistent with OVE. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at framing inspection. 
d.  2.04 Use of beetle kill pine. 
1.  Benefit: Use of cosmetically blemished natural resource from Colorado. Left in forests the timber will either decay or burn in forest fires, either way releasing the CO2 they stored while growing. 
2.  Qualification: Structural use as dimensional framing material, or as cross laminated timber (CLT); and/or nonstructural uses such as siding, flooring, trim, etc. Material must be used for over 50% of total construction element. 
3.  Points: 2 for structural; 2 for nonstructural. 
4.  Confirmation will be at framing and/or final inspection. 
e.  2.05 Reclaimed and/or recycled-content materials. 
1.  Benefit: Supports recycling market and reduces use of virgin materials. 
2.  Qualification: Use of construction materials that are either reclaimed from another structure, and/or any materials with recycle-content in them qualify. Materials that are purchased from a reclaimed materials distributor, deconstructed by the owner/applicant from another structure, or that are purchased from a used building materials exchange all qualify as reclaimed materials (must provide documentation). Some common recycle-content materials include composite decking, recycle-content faux shake/slate roofing, cellulose or shredded cotton batt insulation, recycle-content carpets, counter tops, recycle-content tile, etc. Provide material info onsite; field inspected. More than 50% of the material type in place must be reclaimed and/or recycled. 
3.  Points: 2 per material type; 6 maximum. 
4.  Confirmation: Material information/documentation must be on job site with field set of plans for inspection. 
f.  2.06 FSC or SFI certified materials or steel studs. 
1.  Benefit: Promotes sustainable stewardship of forest resources. Steel framing requires less lumber, is recyclable, and reduces scrap material. 
2.  Qualification: FSC (Forest Stewardship Council) or SFI (Sustainable Forestry Initiative) stamped certification on material(s) required. Material must be used in over 50% of the construction element. 
3.  Points: 2 per material type. 
4.  Confirmation: Field inspected. 
g.  2.07 Materials manufactured within Colorado and/or rapidly renewable materials. 
1.  Benefit: Reducing travel distance reduces carbon footprint. Rapidly renewable materials have less of an environmental impact. 
2.  Qualification: Show documentation for any materials used that were manufactured within Colorado, or that consist of rapidly renewable materials (naturally reproducing within 15 years). Material type must be used in over 50% of the building component. 
3.  Points: 2 per material type. 
4.  Confirmation: Field inspected. 
(3)  Energy. 
a.  3.01 Building energy, envelope and systems commissioning. 
1.  Benefit: Confirms performance levels of design and construction that may not be obvious from visual inspection. 
2.  Qualification: A commissioning plan must be provided for buildings over 5,000 s.f. the plan must be followed by an inspection report. 
3.  Points: Required (for all new systems). 
4.  Confirmation will be prior to certificate of occupancy. (Opportunity for innovation points for providing ongoing monitoring system.) 
b.  3.02 Infrared heat loss analysis and remediation. 
1.  Benefit: Infrared cameras can be effective tools for pinpointing areas of heat loss (interior-exterior temperature difference must be at least 25 degrees). 
2.  Qualification: Provide detailed report from an accredited professional on analysis performed, areas of heat loss, and demonstrated remediation (if stated in analysis). 
3.  Points: 3. 
4.  Confirmation will be prior to certificate of occupancy 
c.  3.03 No recessed lights on ceiling to exterior. 
1.  Benefit: Ceiling penetrations allow heat loss and moisture transfer. 
2.  Qualification: Avoid recessed light fixtures in the ceiling of the building envelope. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
d.  3.04 Efficient boiler/furnace. 
1.  Benefit: Energy saving. 
2.  Qualification: Design and install heating equipment with an efficiency rating percentage over 87%. For multiple boilers/furnaces, ratings area averaged. 
3.  Points: 1 to 7 (1 point for each percent increase over an AFUE efficiency rating percentage of 87%.) 
4.  Confirmation will be at heating appliance inspection. 
e.  3.05 Cold climate heat pump. 
1.  Benefit: Heat pump technology heats and cools efficiently and is cheaper to operate. 
2.  Qualification: Specify and install heat pump(s) for primary heating and cooling. 
3.  Points: 1 per unit. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection 
f.  3.06 Geoexchange system. 
1.  Benefit: Reduce use of fossil fuels. 
2.  Qualification: Must be designed and constructed to serve the entire building. 
3.  Points: 6. 
4.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
g.  3.07 Tankless water heater(s). 
1.  Benefit: Energy saving. 
2.  Qualification: Gas or electric tankless on-demand water heater models qualify, must meet over 50% of total hot water needs. Units must have an intermittent ignition device (IID) instead of a standing pilot light to qualify. 
3.  Points: 1 to 3 (Tankless systems get 3 points. Side-arm boilers qualify for one point as part of a modulating condensing boiler 90% AFUE efficiency or above.) 
4.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
h.  3.08 Evaporative cooling only or no mechanical air conditioning. 
1.  Benefit: Evaporative cooling works efficiently in arid dry climates in Colorado and is considered more energy efficient than air conditioning. 
2.  Qualification: HVAC design must specify evaporative cooling. Evaporative cooling is defined as cooling which relies only on evaporation of water for its cooling needs. 
3.  Points: 2 for evaporative cooling; 4 for other less energy consumptive alternatives such as passive cooling or ceiling fans. 
4.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
i.  3.09 HVAC Economizer System. 
1.  Benefit: Saves energy by using unconditioned outside air for cooling. Use of outside air also improves indoor air quality. 
2.  Qualification: Specify and install an economizer system for over 50% of heated area of the structure. 
3.  Points: 1 for 50% of heated area, 2 for 100% of heated area. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
j.  3.10 Radiant in-floor heat. 
1.  Benefit: Radiant heat warms building occupants rather than the air, which allows boiler to operate at lower temperatures, thus saving energy. 
2.  Qualification: Hydronic in-floor heating in over 50% of the heated area of the structure 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
k.  3.11 Air-to-air heat exchanger. 
1.  Benefit: An air-to-air heat exchanger (also referred to as a Heat Recovery Ventilator (HRV) or Energy Recovery Ventilator (ERV)) pre-warms or cools outside air by providing a heat exchange with exhaust air. 
2.  Qualification: Majority of total mechanical ventilation must go through a heat exchanger for points. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
l.  3.12 Roof/ceiling insulation. 
1.  Benefit: Reduces heat loss. 
2.  Qualification: One point awarded for each manufacturer-rated R-value of insulation, above IECC minimum, installed in the roof assembly. For structures/roof assemblies with multiple different R-values, a weighted average is used. 
3.  Points: 1 to 8. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and insulation inspection. 
m.  3.13 Wall insulation. 
1.  Benefit: Reduces heat loss. 
2.  Qualification: One point awarded for each manufacturer-rated R-value of insulation, above IECC minimum, installed in the exterior wall assembly. For multiple wall types with different R-values, a weighted average is used. 
3.  Points: 1 to 8. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and insulation inspection. 
n.  3.14 Under-slab insulation. 

1.  Benefit: Reduces heat loss. Most of the heat loss occurs at the slab perimeter. For commercial buildings the IECC requires perimeter insulation of R-10 for 24", unheated; and R-15 for 36", heated. For residential it is R-15 for 24", unheated; and R-20 for 48", heated. Increasing R-value beyond R-15 has little effect on heat loss, but increasing perimeter coverage or providing full coverage has significant Benefits. 
Slab on Grade

2.  Qualification: insulate the outer 48" of the slab perimeter (commercial only); or full continuous with a minimum of R-10 for unheated slabs and a minimum of R-15 for heated slabs. Isolate slab. 
3.  Points: 48" perimeter: 2; full, continuous: 4. 
4.  Confirmation: Field inspected prior to pouring slab. 
o.  3.15 Crawl Space/Basement Foundation Wall Insulation. 

1.  Benefit: Reduces heat loss. Most of the heat loss occurs at the upper walls. Placing the insulation on the exterior is preferred for better thermal performance and moisture control. 
2.  Qualification: Insulate crawl space or basement foundation walls (either inside or outside) beyond applicable code minimums. 
3.  Points: 0.5 for each manufacturer-rated R-value of insulation, above IECC minimum; 1 additional point for exterior applied insulation 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and insulation inspection. 
p.  3.16 Blown or sprayed insulation. 
1.  Benefit: The higher density of these types of insulation reduces airflow (infiltration and exfiltration). 
2.  Qualification: Blown-in, or minimum 2.0 pcf density foam, insulation specified and installed in attics/ceilings, walls, and basements/crawlspaces qualifies. 
3.  Points: 1-4 (1 per Quantity Level). For example, if 80% of the insulated area of a structure is blown-in, then quantity level 4 (76-100%) or 4 points would be given. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and insulation inspection. 
q.  3.17 High performance windows. 
1.  Benefit: Reduce heat loss and solar gain. 
2.  Qualification: Specify U-values for all glazing designed and installed. 
3.  Points: 1-8 (1 point for each U-.01 below IECC minimum). 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and framing inspection. 
r.  3.18 Insulating window shades. 
1.  Benefit: Reduce window heat loss. 
2.  Qualification: 75% or more of total windows must have insulating window coverings installed. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(4)  Renewable Energy. 
a.  4.1 Onsite renewable energy. 
1.  Benefit: This is the epitome of sustainability. 
2.  Qualification: Provide calculations demonstrating any onsite renewable energy systems as a function of total energy use offset for that energy source (total electricity or total gas). 
3.  Points: Required 2% of energy budget or 25% of common load for core and shell buildings. 
Over 2%-5% offset: 3 points 
Over 5%-10% offset: 5 points 
Over 10%-25% offset: 10 points 
Over 25%-50% offset: 15 points 
Over 50%-75% offset: 20 points 
Over 75% offset 25 points 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
b.  4.02 Future solar. 
1.  Benefit: Eases future installation of a solar system. 
2.  Qualification: Provide a chase from the mechanical room to the roof. Space must be provided on the roof and in the mechanical room. 
3.  Points: Required. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
(5)  Indoor quality. 
a.  5.01 Radon mitigation system. 
1.  Benefit: High concentrations of radon gas are considered to be a health risk by the EPA, ranking high as a carcinogen. 
2.  Qualification: Install a passive radon mitigation system that eliminates potential for radon or other soil gases from entering habitable areas of the structure. Must ventilate below floor or slab vapor barrier to exterior. Mechanical ventilation of radon system is not necessary unless otherwise specified. 
3.  Points: Required. 
4.  Confirmation will be at framing and final inspection. 
b.  5.02 HEPA filter in HVAC. 
1.  Benefit: Improves indoor-air quality. 
2.  Qualification: Specify and install a High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) or MERV 13 (0.1 micron) or higher filter that effectively filters 100% of HVAC system. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
c.  5.03 Low- or non-toxic floor coverings. 
1.  Benefit: Improves indoor-air quality. 
2.  Qualification: Materials are either listed on www.greenguard.org; or otherwise demonstrated to be below EPA thresholds for low toxicity. In general, most tile, wood, and natural carpets meet low-toxic standards. For other coverings, provide documentation demonstrating compliance. 
3.  Points: 1-4 (1 point per Quantity Level) Quantity Level is determined by the percentage of total floor area meeting the above criteria. For example, if 80% of the total flooring was non-toxic, then quantity level 4 (76-100%) would apply, so 4 points would be given. 
4.  Confirmation will be at final inspection. 
d.  5.04 Construction IAQ plan. 
1.  Benefit: Protects construction workers as well as eventual occupants of the building. 
2.  Qualification: Provide and implement plan (need to elaborate on what's to be included on plan.) 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation: From LEED: It is important to remember that IAQ management is not a one-time compliance event that can be checked off a list-it must be an ongoing effort for the duration of the construction process. 
e.  5.05 Indoor chemical and pollutant control. 
1.  Benefit: Prevents contamination of indoor air. 
2.  Qualification: Any onsite hazardous material storage must be air-tight; provided with an exhaust fan; and must provide spill/leakage containment. Also, install a minimum 4x4' grated area with void below for all major entryways that reduces potential for dirt and other pollutants from entering the structure. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
f.  5.06 Mechanical ventilation beyond Code. 
1.  Benefit: Improves indoor air quality by removing contaminates. 
2.  Qualification: Provide mechanical ventilation at least 20% over ASHRAE Standard 62.1-2013 that operates on occupancy controls (motion activated or CO2 activated). An air-to-air heat exchanger (ERV or HRV) that pre-heats or cools fresh intake air is required with this option. 
3.  Points: 2. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
g.  5.07 Daylighting. 
1.  Benefit: Provides building occupants with a daylight connection to outdoors. 
2.  Qualification: Bring daylight to occupied areas of the building without hindering tasks. 
3.  Points: 4 maximum, 1 per each 25% of occupied area to which daylight is provided 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspection. 
h.  5.08 Quality views. 
1.  Benefit: Provides building occupants with a visual connection to outdoors. 
2.  Qualification: 75% of occupied spaces have a direct line of sight to the outdoor environment. 
3.  Points: 1. 
4.  Confirmation will be at plan review and final inspections. 
(6)  Innovation points. Innovative product use and/or design points will be given points on a case by case basis. The item must specifically meet the intent of the SBR guidelines as stated at the beginning, and points will be scaled as the item would apply to similar comparable items in this code section. Possibilities include additional daylighting and views above 5.08 above to LEED standards. 
( Ord. 21 § 5(Exh. B), 2015 
Secs. 18-27-18-40. - Reserved.

(Ord. 13 §1, 2007; Ord. 27 §1, 2016)
