ARTICLE IV - Air Quality 

Sec. 18-61. - Air quality and declaration of policy. 
(a)  The Town Council hereby finds and declares air quality to be an important part of the health, safety and welfare of the community, and that the Town Council has a duty to protect the air quality in the Town. 
(b)  Emissions from wood stoves, fireplaces and coal burning have been determined by numerous studies and reports to be a major factor in air quality problems and may constitute a threat to the health of the citizens of the Town, a public nuisance and a threat to the economic well-being of the Town; therefore, it is the intent of the Town Council to enact a system to regulate the construction and installation of these devices. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Sec. 18-62. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Article, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Approved solid fuel-burning device is one which has been approved and certified by the Air Quality Control Commission pursuant to its authority under Section 25-7-401, et seq., C.R.S., or which complies with all of the following: 
a.  An air-to-fuel ratio in the combustion chamber averaging less than 35-to-1 as determined by EPA method 28A as set forth in the Federal Regulations 40 CFR Part 60 Subpart AAA, Appendix A. 
b.  A usable firebox volume of less than twenty (20) cubic feet. 
c.  A minimum burn rate of less than five (5) kilograms per hour. 
d.  A maximum weight of eight hundred (800) kilograms. 
    Dwelling units . For the purposes of this Article, the definitions of dwelling unit, single-family dwelling unit, two-family dwelling unit and multiple-family dwelling unit shall be interpreted in accordance with Section 16-4 of this Code. 
    Fireplace means a structure designed for the burning of wood which is an integral part of the construction of a building, which would commonly be considered a fireplace and which does not meet the definition of a wood stove. 
    Natural gas fireplace means a fireplace that operates on natural gas and is installed per Building Official approval, including a properly installed fire box, flues and gas log apparatus. 
    Solid fuel-burning device means any fireplace, stove, firebox or device intended and/or used for the purpose of burning wood, coal, pulp, paper or other nonliquid or nongaseous fuel. 
    Wood-burning stove means an appliance designed for or capable of burning wood, including a fireplace insert, capable of and intended for domestic space heating or domestic water heating. These stoves come with an airtight firebox and controlled air flow features for more precise burning. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Sec. 18-63. - Regulation of wood stoves. 
(a)  No wood stove shall be installed within any dwelling unit or commercial building within the Town unless such device is an approved wood stove. 
(b)  The number of approved wood stoves installed in any new residential or commercial building, for which a building permit is issued after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article, shall not exceed the following: 
(1)  Single-family dwellings, and two-family dwellings with a minimum of one thousand (1,000) square feet per dwelling unit: one (1) approved wood stove per dwelling unit. 
(2)  Multi-family dwellings: one (1) approved wood stove per building to be located in a common area and not in an individual unit. 
(3)  Commercial building: one (1) approved wood stove per building or commercial enterprise, whichever is more restrictive. This category, for the purposes of this Article, shall include commercial hotels, motels and lodges. 
(c)  In dwelling units or commercial buildings in existence on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article, installation of additional wood stoves is prohibited if the resulting number of preexisting and new wood stoves exceeds the limitations on the number of woodstoves per dwelling unit contained in Subsection (b) above. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Sec. 18-64. - Regulation of fireplaces. 
    In areas where natural gas service is currently available or where natural gas lines are located within three hundred (300) feet of a building, it shall be unlawful to install or construct a fireplace, unless it is a natural gas fireplace or an approved solid fuel-burning device. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Sec. 18-65. - Regulation of coal-fired devices. 
    No solid fuel-burning device shall be allowed to burn coal except for those devices already being used to burn coal on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article. It shall be unlawful for any person to install or have installed any solid fuel-burning decorative appliance that does not comply with Section 25-7-407, C.R.S. Installation of appliances purchased out of state or purchased used shall be unlawful unless said appliance bears an emissions performance label showing compliance with Colorado Emissions Standards for the control of pollution caused by wood smoke. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Sec. 18-66. - Nonconforming devices. 
    Any solid fuel-burning device which has been installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article and is not in compliance with this Article shall be considered a legal nonconforming device and may continue in existence subject to the condition that it shall not be changed to or replaced by any device except an approved device or other lawful heating system in accordance with this Code. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Sec. 18-67. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The provisions of this Article shall be enforced at the time of building permit application or when the Town has reasonable grounds based upon its investigation or written complaints which sufficiently demonstrate reasonable grounds that a person has violated the provisions of this Article. 
(b)  The Town shall enforce the provisions of this Article in accordance with Section 1-82 of this Code. 
(Ord. 13 §1, 2007) 
Secs. 18-68-18-80. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI - Supplemental Building Regulations 

Sec. 18-101. - Restriction on the use of reflective building materials. 
    No structure shall produce glare from building materials, other than glare from windows. Solar reflectance values for finish materials on the exterior of all structures, including but not limited to siding and roofing materials, shall not exceed thirty-five percent (35%). 
    Solar energy facilities shall be exempt from this provision. Reflective flashing shall also be exempt from this provision, provided the flashing is kept to the minimum needed to comply with the Building Code. 
( Ord. 05 §I, 2012)

APPENDIX B 
BASALT TOWN ROAD SPECIFICATIONS 
TOWN ROAD SPECIFICATIONS 
The Board of Trustees, having discussed this subject matter and having made a motion to adopt and approve this document, the Town Road Specifications, the policy of the Board of Trustees is set forth herein under the heading of Town Road Specifications and can be found in the Appendix of the Basalt Municipal Code. 
TOWN ROAD REGULATIONS 
1.  GENERAL; PURPOSE 
    The following regulations are the criteria which shall govern the application for construction, design and construction of roadways to be dedicated to the Town of Basalt and construction within any right-of-way for existing and proposed city roads. 
2.  DEFINITIONS 
A.  Administration : The Town of Basalt through the Town Administrator, or his qualified agent, administers the Town road system including, but not limited to, maintenance, layout, alterations, deletions, additions, property acquisition and traffic regulation. Town jurisdiction extends to all roads other than state or federal highways within incorporated lands of the Town of Basalt. 
B.  Planning Commission : In regard to the Town road system, the Basalt Planning Commission acts as an advisory board to the Board of Trustees in matters of route and circulation planning and development standards and shall conduct public hearings on the same. 
C.  Town Transportation Plan : At such time that a Town Transportation Plan is adopted by the Board of Trustees, it shall be the Plan's purpose to protect rights-of-way for future road development and anticipate expansion, additions and alterations to the Town road system. 
D.  Town Road Types : All Town roads are divided into the following 5 types for planning purposes: 
1)  Type 1 - Freeways and Expressways - A freeway is a divided, multi-lane arterial for through traffic with full control of access and all grade crossings eliminated. An expressway is a divided, multi-lane arterial for through traffic with controlled access and with some crossings at grade. 
2)  Type 2 - Arterials - An arterial is a continuous access controlled road for through traffic with crossings at grade. Points of access are limited, some existing crossings may not be at grade. 
3)  Type 3 - Collectors - A collector is a vicinity-wide continuous access road connecting local access roads to arterials. 
4)  Type 4 - Local Access Roads - A local access road provides direct access from abutting properties to other roads. 
5)  Type 5 - Frontage Roads - A frontage road serves as a collector or local access road used contiguous to higher type roads to control access. 
3.  TOWN ROAD DEVELOPMENT 
    New roads are added to the Town roads system by resolutions passed by the Board of Trustees. Sources of new roads are: Annexations, realignments, abandoned state or county highways, subdivisions and other developments. The addition of roads to the Town road system involving "special cases" may be considered on an individual basis. Ordinarily, before a new road becomes a part of the Town road system, it passes through six steps: planning, design, right-of-way acquisition or dedication, construction, inspection and acceptance. 
A.  Planning Criteria : Prior to the design of a new road, the road type, the terrain classification and the design speed must be determined. The road types are defined in Section I. The road type must be selected to conform to the standards of the Town Planning Commission and is subject to the approval of the Town Administrator. 
1)  Terrain Classification - For the purpose of this regulation, the terrain in Basalt is divided into three categories: 
a)  Flat or Rolling ; Average cross slope less than 15% and the ridges and draws are not well-defined. 
b)  Mountainous ; Average cross slope greater than 15% and the ridges and draws are steep and well-defined. 
c)  Residual Areas : Conforms to current Planning Commission requirements. 
2)  Design Speed- Design speed is a speed selected to correlate design of those physical elements of road that influence vehicle operation. The choice of design speed is influenced primarily by the terrain classification, road type, construction and cost of the road. 
Terrain Road Type Classification 1 2 3 4 - 5 Flat or Rolling 55-65 50-55 40-50 30-40 Mountainous 55-65 50-55 30-40 20-30 Residential 25-35 15-25  
B.  Design Standards : 
1)  Road Patterns and Horizontal Alignment - The streets and roads shall bear a logical relationship to topography and location of existing or probable future roads in adjacent tracts of land. 
In mountainous terrain, it may be preferable to provide wider standard alignment for the right-of-way than for the road itself. The roadbed will then be permitted to wind around within the right-of-way to reduce cuts and unnecessary scarring, provided that minimum standards are met. The wider standard right-of-way will permit improvement of the alignment as traffic warrants. 
Roads should not be located too close when parallel to streams and rivers subject to flooding. There should be a vegetated strip to trap soil carried by runoff between the toe of the fill and the thread line of the water channel. 
Where developable but unplatted land is separated from an existing public right-of-way by a proposed subdivision, the proposed subdivision shall provide roads extending to the boundary common to both tracts to prevent land locking of the unplatted tract. These access roads shall be coordinated with and provided at no cost to the unplatted land owner. These points of access shall also conform to the latest "circulation plan" prepared by the Basalt Planning Staff. 
Dead end roads, permanent or temporary, shall not be more than 500 feet in length unless specific approval is given by the Planning Commission and the Town Board of Trustees. These dead end roads shall be provided with cul-de-sacs with a minimum diameter of 90 feet, measured from outside shoulder of the road bed. The minimum paved diameter is 60 feet. Adequate snow storage areas shall be provided at the cul-de-sac. For local access roads, a T-shaped or Y-shaped terminus may be provided on steep terrain as an alternative to a cul-de-sac. All details must be approved by the Planning Commission and snow storage areas shall be provided. 
Roads should intersect at right angles. A maximum of 10° from a right angle may be permitted if approved by the Town Board. 
Opposing intersections or access openings shall be directly opposite each other or offset at least 150 feet from each other. 
2)  Vertical Alignment - the grade line is controlled mainly by topography, the factors of horizontal alignment, safety, sight distance, design speed, drainage and construction costs. The grade line shall be positioned with relation to the cross section as follows: 
a)  It should coincide with the road centerline on two lane and multi-lane undivided roads. 
b)  Separate grade lines may be required on divided multi-lane roads. 
c)  Minimum Road Grade - to allow for drainage these minimum grades should be maintained: 
Surface Type Terrain Classification Flat or Rolling Mountainous Asphalt or Concrete .2% .5% Gravel .5% 1.0%  
d)  Maximum Road Grade - this shall be as follows: 
Terrain Road Type Classification 1 2 3 4 - 5 Mountainous 5% 5% 5% 7% Flat or Rolling 4% 5% 5% 7%  
Steeper grades will be considered only for special cases. Road grades shall not exceed 4% within 100 feet of the center of an intersection or point of curvature on a switchback. 
e)  Vertical Curves - Grade changes shall be accomplished by vertical curves of sufficient length to maintain safe sight distances. Minimum lengths for vertical curves shall be 400 feet for design speeds above 30 mph and 200 feet for design speeds 30 mph and below. Special cases may be considered by the Town Administrator. 
3)  Horizontal and Vertical Alignment must provide at least the minimum stopping sight distance for the design speed at all points. This includes visibility at intersections as well as around curves and roadside encroachments. 
The required stopping sight distance for a given design speed on dry pavement is as follows:

Following is a table which gives the minimum radius of curvature for specific design speeds. This table is based upon speed alone; it ignores the sight distance factor and superelevation. 
Design Speed MPH Minimum Curve Radius 
Minimum Curve Radius (feet) 15 60 20 100 25 175 30 250 35 375 40 550 50 850  
Sight distance and minimum radii for speeds over 50 MPH shall use Colorado State Highway design criteria. 
In locations where switchbacks may be required, the circular curve radius of the roadbed may be a minimum of 50 feet. 
Every effort should be made to exceed the minimum values. 
Sudden reductions in designed radii introduce the element of surprise to the driver and should be avoided. Where physical restrictions cannot be overcome and it becomes necessary to introduce curvature of lower standard than the design speed for the project, the design speed between successive curves shall not change by more than 20 miles per hour increments. Under no conditions shall a curve for a design speed lower than the design speed of the project be introduced at the end of a long tangent or at other locations where high approach speeds may be anticipated. 
Reversing curves without an intervening tangent will not be permitted. Where reverse curves are needed the following minimum tangent lengths shall be provided for Road Types 3, 4 and 5. 
Design Speed Tangent 15 50 20 75 25 100 30 150 35 200 40 and above 250  
For Road Types 1 and 2 minimum tangent lengths between curves shall be 400 feet. 
Broken-back curves are to be avoided. Ending a curve on a bridge is to be avoided. 
Additional right-of-way shall be required to provide a minimum clear distance of 10 feet between the curb or pavement edge and the right-of-way for type 4 roads and 15 feet for Types 1, 2, and 3 roads. Curb returns on pavement rounding radius at intersections are to be selected from the following table. 
Terrain Road Type Classification 1 2 3 4 - 5 Flat or Rolling 50 ft. 35 ft. 35 ft. 20 ft. Mountainous 40 ft. 25 ft. 25 ft. 10 ft.  
4)  Alignment Coordination - Wherever possible, vertical curves should be superimposed on horizontal curves to reduce the number of sight distance restrictions. For safety reasons, the horizontal curve should overlap the vertical curve. 
A sharp horizontal curve should not be introduced at or near a pronounced summit or grade sag. This is particularly hazardous at night. 
Horizontal and vertical curvature at intersections should be as flat as physical conditions permit. 
In mountainous terrain, undulating grades are preferable to long sustained grades in order to reduce cuts and fills, reduce scarring of vegetative cover and avoid accumulation of erosive drainage in long sustained roadside ditches. 
5)  Geometric Cross Section 
a)  Typical Sections : The Town Planning Commission and the Board of Trustees must approve the developers' street classifications prior to final road design. In areas of steep slopes, the right-of-way width may of necessity be wider than that shown below in order that the minimum road bed width may be maintained. Street widths and pavements shall not be less than those shown in the following table: 
Road 
Type Min. Dedicated 
ROW Width Min. Roadbed 
Width Min. Pavement 
Width 2-Arterial 80' - 120' Roadbed and pavement widths of arterial roads will be determined on an individual basis 3-Collector 60' - 80' 40' 36' 4-Local Access 50' 30' 26' 5-Frontage Road 35' 26' 6-Cul-de-sac 40' - 50' 30' 26'  
The basic minimum is sufficient only to accommodate the specified geometric cross sectional elements and Additional right-of-way must be provided for curb returns, cuts and fills, drainage improvements, interchanges and other appurtenances. 
The minimum clearance from the right-of-way line to the point of cut or fill slope should be five feet. When feasible, at least 10 feet should be provided. 
The minimum right-of-way clearance for cuts higher than 15 feet shall be 1 /3 the cut height but not to exceed 50 feet in width. 
b)  Crown Slope : On undivided roads in tangent alignment, the high point of the crown shall be centered on the pavement and the pavement sloped toward the edges on a uniform grade. In mountainous terrain, unpaved Type 4 roads may be sloped toward the cut side of the road on a 3% slope to alleviate surface erosion, provided that safe speed requirements are met. 
Type of Surface Crown Slope % Portland Cement Concrete 1.5 Bituminous Mix 2.0 Penetration Treated Earth or Gravel 3.0 Unsurfaced Graded Section 3.0  
c)  Superelevation : Curves need not be superelevated on Type 3 and Type 4 roads provided that safe speeds are equal to or greater than the design speed. Superelevation is to be provided on Types 1 and 2 roads. Rate of superelevation, axis of rotation and superelevation transition shall be considered where superelevation is required. 
d)  Side Slopes : Side slopes should be designed for functional effectiveness, ease of maintenance and pleasing appearance. Flatter slopes shall be required in unstable sections. 
In areas of heavy snowfall, consideration should be given to snow removal problems and snow storage in slope design. It is considered advisable to use flatter slopes in cuts on the southerly side of the roadway where this will provide additional exposure of the pavement to the sun. 
Slopes shall be revegetated to reduce erosion and to present a more pleasing appearance. 
e)  Slope Benches : The necessity for benches, their width and vertical spacing shall be established only after an adequate materials investigation. Benching should be used sparingly and only where they are justified by sound engineering reasons including: 
1)  In unstable material where it is recommended by a qualified soils engineer in lieu of flattening the side slope. 
2)  To intercept and store loose material resulting from minor slides or erosion. 
3)  For snow storage in special cases as in long through cuts. 
f)  Clearance : The minimum horizontal clearance to major structures from the edge of the traveled way shall be 10 feet. The minimum vertical clearance to major overhead structures shall be 15 feet above the roadbed. For minor overhead structures, such as signs, cables, etc. the minimum vertical clearance shall be 18 feet. 
g)  Sidewalks : Sidewalks are required: 
1)  In areas where densities have been planned on the basis of public water and sewers being available and designated to be served by sidewalks in the current zoning and subdivision regulations. 
2)  Along roads where significant pedestrian usage is anticipated. 
h)  Curbs and Gutters : Curbs and gutters are required as follows: 
1)  In areas where densities have been planned on the basis of public water and sewers being available and designated to be served by sidewalks in the current zoning and subdivision regulations. 
2)  Where required due to drainage, traffic or public safety. 
3)  To replace existing curbs and gutters. 
C.  Drainage : The primary objective of drainage design shall be the protection of Town roads and property while minimizing the possible flood damage to surrounding properties and structures. Good drainage is one of the most important factors in road design. 
Culverts under all roads are to be designed to accommodate a 25-year frequency storm runoff on Road Types 3 and 4 and 100-year frequency storm runoff on Road Types 1 and 2, utilizing the maximum available head. A comparative analysis for snowmelt runoff shall also be made; the greater flow figure shall be used. The maximum available head shall be determined by the uppermost ponding elevation, so chosen as to not cause flood damage to upstream properties. Inlets and other facilities draining the road surface shall be designed to accommodate the 25-year frequency runoff or snowmelt runoff, whichever is greater. No culvert shall be less than 18 inches in diameter. 
All drainage installations shall also be designed to permit free unobstructed passage of debris and silt. Settlement basins are to be provided when the Town Administrator determines a silting problem may exist downstream. Modification of natural channels or transferring runoff from one basin to another is not to be permitted without approval by the Town Administrator. 
1)  Side Ditches - Shall be designed such that water flow velocities will not cause erosion of the ditch lining. The allowable velocity will depend on the nature of the soils through which the ditch is excavated, but shall in no case exceed 5 feet per second at peak design flow in unlined ditches. 
During peak design flow, the water level inside ditches shall be no higher than the bottom of the sub-base. 
Side slopes of ditches shall be no steeper than 2 horizontal to 1 vertical. Channels and ditches are to be designed so as to not create roadside safety hazards. 
The minimum flow line shall be .2% if the channel is paved and .3% for unpaved channels of other materials. 
Maximum slopes shall be controlled by the maximum permissible velocities, being 5 feet per second in unlined ditches and 6 feet per second in other cases. Mannings equation (V=1.486/Nr 2/3 S1/2) shall be used to estimate flow velocities. 
2)  Culverts - Shall be located as required to allow complete drainage of rainfall and snowmelt runoff and where drainages intersect the road bed. 
Alignment of the culvert should generally conform to the alignment and grade of the intersecting drainage channel. 
Velocities of flow in culverts shall be calculated using acceptable design charts and formulas. Culverts should be designed to be self-cleaning where possible. 
The outlet should be designed so as not to discharge on unprotected fills or unstable material. Where design discharge velocity at the culvert discharge exceed 10 feet per second, rip rap with a minimum dimension of 10 inches shall be placed for distance of 20 feet beyond the culvert outlet and velocities reduced in that area to no more than the maximum stated above. 
At design flow, the water elevation at the culvert entrance shall be no higher than the bottom of the roadbed sub-base. Culverts shall be designed and constructed such that the design flood may be carried without flooding the upstream side of the culvert. 
Culverts shall be designed structurally for an H-20 live load in accordance with the American Association of State Highway Officials (AASHO) recommendations. Corrugated steel pipe, reinforced concrete pipe or reinforced concrete boxes shall be used. In the case of metal pipe culverts, the material shall be galvanized and have a minimum diameter of 18 inches. 
The top of the metal pipe or arch culverts shall be no closer than 12 inches to the top of the roadbed surface but no higher than the roadbed sub-base. 
Manholes or clean-out access shall be provided at each angle point and at each change in grade. In straight sections clean-out access shall be provided at least every 200 feet for pipes 24 inches and smaller and at least every 400 feet for larger pipes. 
3)  Guard Rails and Retaining Walls - Shall be installed where hazardous conditions exist, as determined by the Town Administrator at the owner's expense. Retaining walls and like structures shall be designed and inspected during construction by a registered soils and structural engineering firm at the owner's expense. Guard rails shall conform to Colorado State Highway Department requirement. 
4)  Signs and Road Stripping - Shall be provided as part of the general roadwork where required by the Town Administrator. 
5)  Bridges - Plans and specifications for bridges shall conform to the Colorado Department of Highways requirements and be approved by the Town Administrator before construction. 
6)  Subsurface Drainage - Subgrades subject to poor drainage, underground seepage or a high water table must be adequately drained for roadbed stabilization. Drains must be installed to control or prevent the high ground water level from coming to within 4 feet of the roadway pavement surface. 
7)  Inlet Structures - Designs for inlet structures must be approved by the Town Administrator. Curb openings with protection bars are preferred. Grates are not permitted where pedestrians, bicycles or debris-laden flows are anticipated. 
D.  Structural Requirements : Materials and quality of work shall conform to the current edition of the Colorado Department of Transportation specifications and standard drawings, except that the Town Administrator shall decide all options. 
4.  REQUIRED INFORMATION AND PROCEDURE 
    Prior to beginning the road design, the applicant shall meet with the Basalt Planning Commission (or its official representative) and the Town Administrator to discuss the general concepts of level or road service, type, construction and any special conditions involved in that particular project. If the road is to be a part of a subdivision, these matters shall be taken up at the time of the preapplication conference for the subdivision. 
Plans and specifications are to be prepared based on appropriate planning criteria and applicable standards and requirements. All design work is to be prepared and signed by a registered professional engineer. 
Plans are to be completed in sufficient detail to facilitate review and are to be submitted to both the Town Administrator and the Town Planning Commission (or its official representative) at least 35 days prior to the regular Planning Commission meeting at which the road plans will be considered. If the roads are to be part of a subdivision, they will be reviewed at the time the Preliminary Plan is reviewed. 
If the road is not to be a part of a subdivision, the road plans shall be reviewed by the Town Administrator and the Planning Commission prior to presentation to the Board of Trustees for its approval or disapproval. 
Approval of plans shall be good for one year. After one year, the procedure must be repeated and revisions in standards made in the interim shall apply. 
Ten (10) copies of plans and specifications shall be supplied at the time of the first review. 
Plans shall include: 
A.  General Location Map drawn at a scale of approximately 1" = 500'. It should show locations of streets, roads, and highways within a distance of approximately 1/2 mile of the proposed development and shall include natural drainage courses and tributary area. 
B.  Topographic Map (for subdivision roads). If roads are to be a part of a proposed subdivision, the topographic map which will be used in the preliminary filing of the subdivision shall accompany the application for a road construction permit. 
C.  Plans and Profiles of the proposed road shall be prepared from field survey data. Information shall include but not be limited to: 
1)  Profile of existing ground surface along proposed centerline of roadbed. 
2)  Profile of proposed final grade showing; grades, length of vertical curves, stationing and elevations of BVC's, EVC's and PIVC's. The vertical scale is to be distorted 10 to 1. Ditch grade shall also be shown. 
3)  Plan of road showing length of tangents and curves, widths of right-of-way, slope lines to prove that the right-of-way is of sufficient width, stationing of PT's, PC's, PI's, curve radii, delta angles, bearings, distances, centerline stationing at 100-foot intervals, dimensions of all road elements, curbs, gutters, utilities, easements and other structures. Location and size of culverts, designating the type and gauge or strength classification and the estimated flow along with data assumed in estimating the flow. 
4)  Cross sections of the entire right-of-way for each variance in roadbed design and at all drainage crossings shall be submitted. Information shall included engineers classifications of subgrade, thickness of sub-base and base course. Asphalt mat shall also be shown if applicable. Size, slope, inlet and outlet conditions and depth of cover of culverts shall also be shown. 
5)  Plan shall also included north arrow, scale, street names, drainage patterns, typical cross sections, section corners and lines and usable bench marks in the area. 
D.  Construction Plans for all structures, bridges, box culverts, retaining walls, guard rails, etc. 
E.  Plans for Revegetation and Sodding of cut and fill slopes. 
F.  A Letter of Intent stating the scope and estimated time limit of each stage of construction. Statement indicating party or parties responsible for the construction. 
G.  Letters from ditch companies or other interested parties or agencies involved stating their approval of any structure constructed within their right-of-way or which may influence their rights or interests. 
H.  A Detailed Cost Estimate of the Project shall also be provided to facilitate the estimate of the amount of bonding required for the road improvements. 
I.  A Drainage Study of areas affecting the proposed road system should include the expected runoff, at road crossing and other critical locations which would result from a 25 year frequency storm or snow runoff conditions whichever is greater. This study should be related and refer to the plan and profile, the general location map and cross sections of the roadway at culvert locations. 
J.  Materials and Soils Testing - A report shall be submitted covering the suitability of materials which are proposed for use in the sub-base and base course. The Project Engineer shall keep a record of soils tests including comments, test results and soil logs from each location. Such information shall be made available at the Town Administrator's request. 
5.  INSPECTIONS AND TEST 
A.  Inspections - Adequate inspections assure compliance to Town standards; they are the basis for the Town Administrator's recommendation to the Board of Trustees for releases of bonds and final acceptance of roadways. 
It is the responsibility of the contractor or the developer to contact the Town Administrator one day in advance of the required inspection. "In progress" inspections of all stages of roadwork will eliminate the need for extensive testing after completion of roadbed. 
Any work or material which does not conform to Town standards will be brought to the attention of the contractor or developer, and if immediate corrections are not made, construction may be stopped. 
The general types of inspections required are as follows: 
Culverts : Trenching, grade, bedding, installations of pipe, backfill and compaction. Inspection to be required when backfill is completed to 1/2 depth of the culvert. 
Structures : Finished excavation, grade, forming, reinforcing steel, concrete pour, finish and test cylinders. Inspections required: 
1)  Prior to placing steel; and 
2)  prior to the concrete pour. 
Roadbed : Subgrade, sub-base, base course, prime, paving and during concrete pours to be called for at each completed stage. Locations of required field tests will be determined by the Town Administrator or Project Engineer. 
Final : A request for the final inspection and acceptance for maintenance or release from bond must be made in writing to the Town Administrator after all other inspections have been passed. 
B.  Testing - When required by the Town Administrator, a recognized testing firm shall certify to the quality of materials and construction. All testing shall be by recognized methods and shall be at the contractor's, developer's or owner's expense. 
Until such time as a segment of road is officially accepted for maintenance by the Town, the developer or owner shall be fully responsible for the maintenance, snowplowing and correction of any faulty construction, including unsuitable road cuts and chuckholes. 
6.  FEES 
    All applicants will be assessed a fee to cover the costs of application review. This fee must be paid prior to review of the road plan. Fees will be determined for each individual application, by the Town Administrator in accordance with the Basalt Municipal Code. 
7.  ACCEPTANCE OF ROADS FOR MAINTENANCE 
A.  Subdivision Roads - Acceptance of platted subdivision by the Town does not constitute acceptance of the roads and right-of-ways for maintenance. Until each road is specifically accepted by the Board of Trustees for maintenance, the maintenance, any additional construction and work are the sole responsibility of the owners of the land embraced within the subdivision. 
B.  Rights-of-Way - On occasion, individuals, organizations or other agencies may wish to dedicate land to the Town for future roads. The procedure shall be as follows: 
1)  Submit a written request 15 days prior to the next regularly scheduled Basalt Planning Commission meeting to the planning office stating reasons for wanting the right-of-way accepted including a map showing the topography and land parcels involved along with the legal descriptions. 
2)  The Basalt Planning Commission shall review the request, make a recommendation and submit it to the Board of Trustees for consideration. 
3)  If the Board of Trustees approves the request, the applicant must submit a deed acceptable to the Town Attorney to the property in question for execution by the Board of Trustees. 
8.  EXISTING TOWN ROADS 
A.  Encroachment Permits - Contractors, developers, owners or governmental agencies in accordance with the Basalt Code must obtain a road cut permit from the Town Administrator for any work performed within the Town road right-of-way. Upon completion of work in the Town road right-of-way, the condition of structures and land shall be returned to the same or better conditions than existed before the encroachment was permitted. In situations where there are subsurface utilities in the area of encroachment, the party doing the work shall be responsible for locating all such utilities and coordinating such work with the Town Administrator and take steps to insure these utilities will not be damaged. The agency encroaching upon the right-of-way shall post bond for possible damage as provided in the Basalt Municipal Code, Section 11-53. 
B.  Overload and Oversize Permit - Before vehicles or other equipment that do not conform to the limitation set by the Model Traffic Code are used upon any Town road, the operator must obtain specific permission from the Town Administrator. The Town Administrator will require any provisions such as hours of operation, protection devices, etc., as he or she may deem necessary to protect the road affected by the use of such nonconforming equipment. 
C.  Road and Easement Vacations - On occasion, vacation of Town roads or various easements may become warranted due to peculiar circumstances or changes in the overall development patterns. 
The Board of Trustees may vacate any Town road or any portion thereof. No road or part shall be vacated that will leave a parcel of land without access to a public road. 
9.  BONDING REQUIREMENTS 
    The term "bond" shall be uncancelable surety secured unto the Town and acceptable to the Town Attorney. Bond shall be in the amount of the estimated construction cost as approved by the Town Administrator. 
If work has not commenced or has not been completed in a satisfactory manner within the prescribed time as contained in the Bonding Agreement, the Town Administrator, as provided in the Basalt Municipal Code, shall cause the bond to instrumented. As logical units of work are completed and approved by the Town Administrator, application may be made for a partial release of the bond. 
(Ord. 19, § 2, 1994)
